Logging this as it's own run, even though it kinda wasn't. Got back from the 10 miler with RnF, and Jon Peterson asked if I'd go with him for his double. So I did. Probably had 10 minutes between the two.

Ran with a brick for about a mile cuz some kids drove by about 4 or 5 times and called us N*****s. Of course once we decided to break their windows they didn't come back. The last time I told them to get out of the car, and they did stop. I sprinted at them - the window that was open - fully intending to hurt someone, and the peeled off. Lots of middle fingers involved.

Around Harriet with John. Good conversation, and I didn't feel awful - my right Achilles was back to be being sore, but nothing alarming. I'll just take care of it and, you know. Back off a bit. Or not at all.
Down to SW to time for TCTC. ended up running the 5k relay with john. 800, 800, 400, 400, and dave/ders kicked for us. 14:07. Tired, pretty much no warmup.
Maggot squirrel cut-off loop. Stroked it for the first ten miles with Joe Renier. Good to catch up and make out a little.
really slow first four with Kurt, then a baller night run around Harriet with John and Joe. Good conversation, hilarious stories.

A little scamper with John up through Wirth park. Pretty sweet change of scenery. Almost done with this nonsense week....

Absolutely beautiful day out.

8x1:2, just to open the legs up a bit. Felt so so so so strange. Aerobically I felt like a monster. My legs we'ren't snappy, though, but still strong.

Saw gruenwald and gabe Anderson... Those two are fit right now.

slow slow slow. Any time I saw 6:xx, I'd back off. Cooldown pace the whole time, but I don't want tomorrow to be a total ride on the struggle bus. pretty uneventful run - just sloggin away. One more day of this insanity.

DONE!

With John down east river, into fort snelling state park, around lake snelling, a lap around pike island, back through Crosby and Hidden Falls. 

I really doubted, for a long time if I could make it, but I did it healthily - to future Nick looking back your log someday and contemplating going for higher - Don't do it. kinda sucked. It was sweet, but tiring, and probably not the best for training. I'm sad, and happy that it's over at the same time. 

Now time to back off, recover, crush some more speed, and then go see how much pain the Gusties are willing to tolerate before they realize this just isn't the year to dethrone the kings.

Official start of the shit talking. Brendo: ready your troops. We're going to come down and kill you guys. 

Me- 150, John- 120, Anders-100, Dave- 100, James- doesn't matter, cuz he's an animal.

easy around bass lake preserve. Feeling good. 6 long, hard.... strides afterward.

19 days until operation hurricane makes landfall.
slow starting jaunt westward on the greenway with John. Just trying to loosen up a bit. Beautiful morning.

Started with the guys at Run n Fun, but trailed off the back as soon as the penises came out for comparison purposes and the pace started to go south of 7's. I suppose they weren't actually going that fast, but if I stand a chance at not pushing this workout tomorrow back to Thursday, I figured I needed to be real about being slow today. Would have liked to go even a bit slower, perhaps. Ran with Nate hall for the second half, and it turns out he shares my views on Captain K.

Welp, not recovered from last week I guess. Aerobically I was fine, but my stomach was bit twisted, and my quads were just checked out. Nothing was tight or sore or anything, my legs were just tired. And rightfully so. I'm still at about 120miles in the last rolling 7 days. Gotta actually recover a little bit and let that 150 mile investment pay it's dividends. I should have/contemplated waiting until tomorrow to do this, but I was mentally ready and I didn't want it hanging over my head anymore, So John and I just went to gut it out today. John did gut it out, and in doing so, really stuck it in me today. 

3x5k The goal was to start at 5:30's and get faster. I didn't really consider that that might actually be hard. did laps around the lakes.

16:55 (5:26 pace)
16:57 (5:27 pace) 
10:49 (stopped at 2 miles because my quads had just gone to sleep) (5:24 pace)

Bumped into Jack and Adrian on the cooldown, ran with Jack for a few blocks and chatted.

Good enough day as far as effort goes, too close to the big week for it to really be any sort of quality. That's the last 'strength' workout of this cycle. EASY progressive long run this weekend, then it's all raw speed until the half!

Westward on the greenway. The plan was to start running toward Plymouth and Marit would start biking toward Mineapolis. After I crossed 169 I thought something wasn't right, so I turned around. My idiot self neglected to remember that the Luce Line pops out in Wirth Park and then you head south via Cedar Lake. Oops.
Around the woodchip trails and some other loop at the Wayazata alumni meet after watching Anders.

Solo on the big loop. 8 miles easy (55:00), 8 miles at a light, tempo-ish pace (46:23 - 5:47's), 3 miles jog back home.

Felt good. Strong. And with this workout, and the beginning of GAC early camp today, it's time to pull back on the miles, hit some hard speed sessions, and go dark in my training log.

See you in two weeks, friends :)

Hurricane: 13 days.

'I was made to slay them, ten thousand hours I'm so damn close I can taste it.'
A bit stiff starting out, loosened up and felt good by the end.
Creek West with John
Easy, strides after

with Anders at SW. This heat wave is killer. 95+ for over a week straight. 400's today with ample recovery. God Anders can just put it in me in these.

64.7, 63.9, 64.9, 64.5, 65.6, 65.7, 64.8

Not bad for 96 degrees and not a dollop of shade.
Bryn Mar 12. O/B to maggot squirrel, then boardwalk home. Felt good

top five worst runs of all time. Started at like 9pm and it was still 100 degrees. Full of food, and inhaled enough bugs to make the DNR worried that I may have disrupted the food chain. Walked the last mile home.
Just trying to make up for last night. felt much better. Still hot as dick.
ended up moving pretty quick simply because I wanted to be done and get back into air conditioning.

at SW with John. Pressure cooker, once again. 4x(4x200)

32, 33, 33, 33
31, 31, 32, 31,
31, 31, 31, 31
29, 29, 29, 30

Dripping.
Long with John. Early so he could go to the state fair. Post long run and these temps? No thanks. I'll stay inside and be a lazy piece of crap, thank you.
On CLT for 6x 2:2 just to do.... something. Needed some speed, but again, hot. this wasn't anything flashy.
Strides after
Challenge and then some with the team. What a night last night. I love alumni weekend. This run felt so so so short. I guess it's been a while since I've only done 15 for a long run.
With Jack and John down on the creek/lake harriet loop
just a shake out
River loop from Ford to Washington. Beautiful night, still hot, but relatively awesome. 10x1:1 in the middle. Felt strong.
awful. felt zapped. With John

Finally felt good(ish) for a workout, and just in time. My achillies didn't bother me after the first few blocks. Went down to Harriet to start off the standard taper. 2x2miles @goal half pace. I was shooting for around 10:20-10:22, but I figured I wouldn't check pace on my watch if I could help it. On paper, this went really well.

Waited until midday to do this, and it was 94 degrees out when I went out the door. So that, and all the McDonalds that MAY have fallen into my digestive system this morning didn't exactly get my hopes up for hitting those 10:20's. 

Started out relaxed and just tried to imagine being in the middle miles of a half, and exerted effort accordingly.

(4:58, 5:09) - 10:07
(4:58, 5:13) - 10:11

The heat was noticeably getting to me in the last half mile of the second one, and I was going 5:05 pace, so I thought it better the back down a tad than dig myself a hole, especially once I started getting heat chills. Good stuff.
With El Petero. Nothing flashy, little sub 6 at the end for giggles.
Shaggin around harriet. Taper. Can't sleep.

Out across stone arch, green light game back through downtown. Oh the people that are out downtown after dark.... floating. 

4 good strides after.

I saw Taylor Swift's motorcade.... just three massive, beautiful RV's outside the Hotel Ivy downtown.

With John down to SW. Final taper workout - 4x800m @ Quick, half pace (2:35ish), half pace, Quick.

2:16, 2:37, 2:36, 2:15

Felt smooth. chatting during the middle two with Anders and dave who were biking on the track in their america apparel. Made it through summer.
didn't feel floaty-amazing-awesome, but I felt like things were coming together at the right time. Northwest Cedar neighborhoods and a little trail time. Cool, finally :)
First msp run with the man, the myth, the legend, Eric Finan.

In Philadelphia along the river. A few strides after. Not the most graceful things on Earth, but if this summer's training hasn't made me fit, then eff running conventions. The course looks like a few loops - don't like having to pass the start/finish multiple times, but oh well. As long as it's not windy, it should be a good day. Slowest female finishing time of the last 3 years here has been 1:07 mid. Soooo... I've never lost to a girl. Guess it's step the game up or get rocked. 

Here goes.
shakeout in Philly along the river. Rough first 2 minutes, but then my legs actually felt really good.
solo pike island, because I had the day off from work. Super nice down there.
With Greeno, Finan, and Sathre around Pike island from Dan's place. Good convo, great route, and ok guys. What more can you ask for?

Easy trot on the creek west. Saw 2 large bucks in the bird sanctuary. The smaller of the two, still a respectable 8 pt, just kept walking toward dave and I like it was domesticated. I think we stepped it off at 7 yards at the closest? (and we were backing up, cuz what kind of deer does that??) The second was a really nice 9pt, and neither of them could have cared less about us being there. I wish that were the case during hunting season. Good run.
Pike island again with Dave and JL. Body/head felt in a funk on this one. Legs a bit out of it too.
Conservative guess on distance - JOhnny and I just did 2 hours out on the MN river trails - Love them. Gorgeous out. a few strides after, time to get back to not being a pussy.
back at it. Morning run. First one where my teeth chattered when I was standing on the porch. just a short short shakeout to get up, get out, and get the legs moving. XC season starts today :)
first 7 with John, then a calhoun lap solo. Finally feeling strong again. The run was just peachy.

moved yesterday's workout up because I felt alright. 3x10 minutes at threshold, 6x1 minute fast. the 10 minutes were 5:27, 5:27, 5:38 (up franklin hill). Just stayed relaxed and resisted the urge to time trial. pretty smooth, no complaints.
Legs felt a bit heavy, thought I was running slower than this. Bumped into Dave from TCTC out on Calhoun and ran with him for a bit, then a harriet loop solo. Hope I got some recovery from this.
morning calhoun lap.
With John on some nature run.  5 strides after. apparently I have to race soon? That should be neat.
Easy prerace. 2 light strides.

Felt good out the door, and after running relaxed the first five and still feeling good, I figured what the heck. I gotta find fitness somehow, so I dropped to mid 5 pace for 8.5 miles, then an easy 5 back home. 10 mile split was 61:30, 1:19 at the half. Funny that even in clunky trainers I ran faster than in Philly.
Just a solo morning shag. Thank god it's monday though. I fricken love the work week.

Was shooting for ten, but my stomach was in knots. I hope I can break out of this funk soon. On paper training has been fine, but my head isn't in it. The fire just... Isn't hot. it's hard to get your heart behind something when all I have to show for the summer is... Well... Nothing.

ran down to SW to do some broken 800's. I wore really soft shoes, and I'm sure that didn't help on the soft track, but this workout was awful. I didn't want to even run that fast - just like 4:40 pace, and then maybe 31s for the 200s. My first 600 was 1:46 and it wasn't... easy. and then the 200 was 34. one and half more and I stepped off the track and went and did 8 untimed hard hill sprints, and ran home. Just nothing in the tank today. I don't know what my deal is. Trying to be confident but it's just not working. Might take tomorrow off and try to collect myself.
Here it is calendar gods. My sacrifice to you. Now enough of this nonsense. Lets be fast again, ok?

down at lilydale regional park. They really switched the trails around down there with the new construction. still awesome, and arguably more-so. The takeaway point here, though, is that the park is still perfect for dead-drops, drug deals, and craigslist hookups.
With The man, the myth, the legend Eric Finan. Interesting observations: He's really freaking fit, and I can't talk at 7 minute pace. Love this sport
Took yesterday off cuz my plantar fascia was being a dick.
With Dave. beautiful out. Finally actually enjoyed a run. it's been a while.
First few with John, last 5 solo. One pickup near the end just to see. Not much there.
morning trot before work. feeling pretty rough.
just to wake up and get moving

Cedar with 3x4 minute thresholds w/ 1 minute jogging recovery. Was breathing pretty hard, but it's to be expected. did some bomb-ass strides after which felt great just to get me to 8 miles (not that I count strides as mileage), simply because I refuse to do 7 mile runs.

morning shag around Harriet. Gosh my right hamstring was tight the whole way. could have done without that.

Some dude and his female companion were out muskie fishing on the lake, and I stopped to watch cuz the lady was fighting a huge muskie. They guy kept touching her line, lifting her rod, guiding her, etc. He was waiting with the big net, and after 5 minutes or so it got off. The dude shouts, 'DAMNIT!' And the proceeds to yell at the lady (wife?).

Settle the fuck down. From what I could tell, she was doing nothing wrong. Maybe just step back and let her enjoy it, do her thing. coaching is something you should be doing before it's needed, not while she's trying to fight this fish. Second, how about you encourage her and maybe make her feel proud of what she was able to do so she actually enjoys the sport? Belittling her isn't join to help anything. Dick.

seven miles at 7 mile creek park with the Kuhntang. Such a gorgeous run. Clear, crisp, and bright, bright colors. We did stray from the main trails at one point, and ended up having to climb back up on our hands and knees as it was too steep to walk.

Shotgunned some beer 30's in the parking lot after, because there are some things that it just is about.

Megan and Jeff's wedding after. Party time.
With JL and Kuhn around Kato post-wedding. twisted my ankle a bit. That was pleasant.
Over to SLP with John in the rain. Cold. ankle still hurt.

Ran into Adrian and Hoika on the south end of Isles, so I took a lap with them. Jaunted off to target field and back after. Felt good, smooth, strong.

What a weekend...
With John and TCTC for a few. Celebratory beer shotgunning with The People's Champion Joe Moore afterward behind GEAR. felt good.

started out with Finan and JL, and ran down to the creek all romantic-like. There was some hand-holding, a little bit of deep eye gazing, and then all at once John and I watched Finan's heart break when we pulled away for a lap and a half of speed on harriet. 5,4,3,2,1 at oughtly 5:30, 5:20, 5:10, 5:00, 4:50, less recovery as we went down. Nothing crazy, but nice to be back in the swing of things, anyway.
Isles big loop with John. Felt fine, a little winded.

St. Peter 'halloween run' down at Gustie. I always maintain that the worst part of the small town races is the hours leading up to it when you don't yet know how hard you'll have to work for it. I felt ready to compete, but not overly quick, so I figured it was going to be a grinder if it had to be. Turns out it was me and brendo. I wanted 4:50 for the first mile because I knew the hills were going to be slow, and brenden wanted 5:20, so we compromised. Opened side by side in 5:08 (actually fairly windy) but I felt fine. about 200m past the mile I looked at him and said, 'Unfortunately, Brenden, you're a better kicker than I am, so I'm going to have to do this now...' and then I pulled away before the hills. my lungs just aren't strong enough for running fast uphill yet... 5:08 first mile, 5:28 second on the hills, then back to a breezy 5:08 to come home. I ran off course at once point to high-five Jed, and seriously contemplated hugging joe in the final 100m, but I figured that'd look arrogant. Which I am. So I'm still not sure why I didn't. 16:14 with no kick, just cruising. No complaints. Like Jake 'the Jiggy-jack' Marotz once said, sometimes it's all about the victories.
Solo stonearch/U of M loop. Felt smooth and strong. Easy sleezy.

Easy hour with Finan. Afterward he invited me over, cooked me dinner, talked about being single, and insisted that contrary to the evidence at hand, that he's heterosexual.

I didn't really eat today, so my stomach hurt during the run, but otherwise a good day.
Just a light workout, 6x4min with 1 minute slow jog between. around the lake.

West river standard. Pretty surreal run - The fog was so dense that I couldn't distinguish the water from the sky, and though I've run this loop a million times, I was pretty certain that I was lost for a while. Soaked when I got home, even though it wasn't raining. That was nice.
With Eric around the sculpture garden, then over to Cedar Lake.

easy jaunt around isles  and calhoun with Adrian. Felt fine. Cut it short because my stupid self agreed to do Finan's run with him tomorrow in t-10 hours, and it's way out of the realm of my current fitness. Like John said, 'You got guts, kid. You're stupid, but you have guts. I guess that's what makes you good.'

Here's what happened. I called Finan yesterday to see if he wanted to go to the State meet, and then MIACs, and he came back with something like, 'Oh yeah, that'd be fun. But blah blah blah running blah blah more important than other things etc etc.' And then followed it up with 'If you don't do my workout with me I wont go, or be your friend anymore.' A real dick, this guy.

Anyway, being ever the sweetheart that I am, I decided WTF. I've done this kind of thing enough times, I'm sure I can fake it through one more, even though I'm not fit right now. at all. 

So this chump makes me wake up before 4:30 am to do this frolick in the total darkness. I got up, had some coffee, two bites of malt-o-meal and was out the door. We went out 3 miles on the greenway west, and then started 14 miles of sub LT work. He told me 5:40's, but on the warm-up said that we'd ease into it (I had some lurid analogies at this point...) 5:50's would be fine, he said. Even 6's or 6:0x's. Well, Jimmy McQuicklegs soon decided we'd just jump the eff in. I took a 45 second pit stop after the mile 13 (10 of the workout) because the coffee called, but then got back onthe horse and set off to catch Finan. got him at the flip by the river, but in the last mile he pulled away from me, and I didn't feel like kicking so I just watched him flutter away. Splits were:

7:17, 7:02, 6:48
5:47, 5:39, 5:46, 5:41, 5:45, 5:35, 5:39, 5:40, 5:51, 5:38, 5:44, 5:38, 5:45, 5:38*

My last mile of speed was actually .7 miles because Eric was done at that point. 3:56 for .7 is 5:38 pace.

Then a super rough cooldown. It's been a while since I went 20(ish).

Sparknotes version: Finan is fat and out of shape.

with Finan for 5, the a few solo, then ran into Adrian again on calhoun. felt decent enough. Today I shot a chicken, twice, within Eagan city limits with my pistol.

AAAAAAAAAMERICA!

Just went west on the greenway to 169 and did a little quit-being-a-pussy run.

2x 2.5 miles at some pace between 5:00 and 5:40, as long as it was smooth and felt easy.

splits were:
1st rep: 5:35, 5:26, 2:45
2nd rep: 2:44, 5:30, 5:11

Felt fine. It was snowing though... which made it hard to keep my eyes open, and made the trail just slick enough that I was slipping a little with each step of the 2nd rep. pretty breezy too. All in the dark, which blew, but welcome to winter. 5 months of desolate, dark, life-sucking hopelessness.

I suppose it's time.

positively did not want to be out there today. felt fine, but i just jogged. Some guy downtown asked me if I had any coke... If I did, I'd be in the comfort of my home, probably in front of my fireplace tweaking the eff out in comfort. And where, good sir, would I have it? tucked into my spandex? And if I did, would you still want it?

Stopped at Finan's on my way home, and he offered me some chili. How domestic.

Jolly trotting around Seward and the river for some sped with John. 10x1:2 at probably 90% effort. Aerobically I could handle it, I just can't get my legs to spin faster right now.

Then I got nice and hungry, went to the grocery store and spent $145. Didn't get a single thing I can make a meal out of, but I am now the proud owner for 'megastuffed' oreos (double-doublestuffed), Pumpkin spice eggnog, and more chips and salsa than the entire Yucatan peninsula. 

You can kick me off campus, but you can't ever make me graduate from college.
slow harriet/east calhoun. No motivation today, dark and cold. But i really have been upping the quality lately, so recovery is probably alright.

on the treadmills after a long day of deer hunting - which isn't exhausting, but by the end, I'm always so tired. The thought of doing a run seemed daunting, but for whatever reason a workout seemed fine. Maybe because it's segmented? I dunno. standard treadmill workout - 15min, 10min, 5 min with 3 minutes jogging recovery. The goal paces were 5:20's, then 5:10's, then 5:00.

A bit out of my league aerobically tonight, maybe because I was tired? Not sure... but I didn't want to sacrifice paces, so I went 15 minutes @ 5:20's, 8 minutes @ 5:10, and 4 minutes @ 5:00.

wu/cd to make 10

standard double-run loop in Hastings. felt good to run there again. Short, but I'm tight on time today - snuck this in between morning and afternoon deer hunts. short, under the guise of 'recovery'. Felt fine.
easy trot around cedar with Matt Wiersum. few strides after. felt really easy, and i guess it was super slow.

easy with Twin cities track club. felt kind of sick the whole time. really erratic pacing. started over 7's, down to 6 flats, back up, down, etc. strange. Beers at the store after, and some good conversations. After talking to Steph Price, I hope RnF ladies crush TCTC in Oregon.

It's going to be tough.

With Johnny down to the river and back. We did a 30 minute easy tempo - made it 5.35 miles (5:36 pace average). Split 28:08 through 5 miles, 27:57 through 8k. Conversational for at least the first 3 miles. Pretty relaxed, which is a little encouraging.

5:42, 5:38, 5:38, 5:29, 5:41, 1:52

No clue how i ever went (or ever will go) 3 minutes faster again.
just an easy in-the-dark 12 with John on some adapted version of the maggot squirrel (aka 'Maggie') run.
easy morning jog before going to do watch Mar run at regions. A bit chilly, but pretty easy breezy sleazy.
Bridges with Alayna. This obscenely cute girl kept following us on a bike. I'd kill for her number.

Kind of a long run because yesterday was a bit light in the numbers. Felt really easy - ran over to Finan's and did 3 with him, ran home and did 7 with John, then I did Harriet solo. I don't know where everyone goes in the winter. Lake Calhoun fitness joggers, man... They must be migratory. 

4 strides after.
Stonearch solo. In the daylight even! Feeling like I should maybe get back to training...
Easy with the twin cities track club guys. Saw a fox on the east side of harriet, and you know what he said? Nothing. The fox said nothing because foxes can't speak.

Solo workout. Nothing too strenuous, but if i'm going to race next week, and moreso, play cross country one more time this year, I have to at least try a little bit. out on the greenway/Isles

2.5 up, 2.5 down

3x2:1, 1 mile uptempo (4:59), 3x2:1, 4x 30 seconds.

the 2 minute segments were quick, but it's only two minutes. the mile was just... blah. moving, but not really pushing it, the 30s were all out, but it was windy, snowing, and the greenway was glazed with the 1mm of icy death that makes you slip a half inch with each step and feel like you're always about to die. Felt like I recovered quickly. pretty minimal rest time. First workout in tights too. That really blows. I don't have much range of motion anyway, but that really kills it.

Ran 5 with Finan, mostly so he could mail a letter. Dude needs to find a closer mailbox. Then did a lap of Calhoun solo, and for the first time that I remember, I didn't see a single person on foot or bike the entire way.

Easy jaunt down to the creek, over to West river, then back on the greenway. felt absurdly easy, and other than the whole 15 degrees, it was fairly pleasant out. With John, and for the first time in a long while, I was super antsy to get going right away in the morning, while John ran errands and dragged his feet. Followed up with Friendsgiving with Mark, John, Kurt, and Mark's parents. I smoked the turkey. It was fantastic.

Kuhn was in town and asked if I'd join for his long run, and my training isn't super focused right now, other than getting stronger, so I figured why not. We ran from Dan the man Greeno's house down through Pike Island (love that place), across to hidden falls, and then messed around on the trails below Minnehaha for a while (hence the slower pace). Anyone who knows Greeno knows that if he even uses language as strong as 'dang', that there is going to be some passionate conversation to follow. So, hearing him casually drop the term 'meat flute' got my attention, needless to say. 

We talked about running, his fast and furious love life, and something about Kuhn's dad's science classroom that I wish I could strike from my memory. 

A bit early, a bit cold, and another semi-long run. But hey... Trial of Miles of, baby.
Easy, bit of a recovery run. Early morning. Few hard pickups at the end.

Was going for 10, but I felt super nauseous and ended up shuffling home. Oh well. 

Don't know what happened. Something I ate?
Calhoun, few strides after. Guess I'm pretty tapered. oops.
Easy with John. stomach was a bit upset, but otherwise good. Cheers to a week where I run half as many miles as the previous.

14 with JL and Finan, 3 solo. Ft. Snelling to downtown, across Wabasha, through Lilydale and back over the Mendota bridge. Pike island OAB solo. Legs are feeling pretty beat up as I write this, but stopping at Mel-O-Glaze for donuts after pretty much negates anything bad that happened, ever.

Early with some good company. Ran from Mike Reneau's place with Him, Metz, Eric T, Jory, Saturday, Ben Kampf, and all their respective wives + Steph Price. Felt good, some sparkling conversation. The second half was just me and Saturday, mostly talking about how the main reason he can't get a girl is that his Chevy Malibu doesn't have vertical doors.

First real snowfall of the year. As much as I hate the stuff, I have to admit that running through the stands of pine along basset creek up in Wirth was pretty darn gorgeous. That aside, I rolled my left ankle about 4 times, and was soaked when I finished. Welcome to injury season.

My first 'F-this' run of the winter. Just a guess on distance, I know it was at least 5. I wouldn't call it ice, the stuff on the trails, it was more like thin, compressed slush. And it was miserable. I tried paths, roads, grass... It was all awful. Zero traction, just slipping very step. Any turn over about 20 degrees, and I had to literally stop. I tried just doing loops on the grass at the park northwest of Calhoun, but that was bad too. 

I'm not going to hurt myself this winter by being stubborn. And if that makes me soft, then I guess I'm soft. Pulled the plug early.
75 or 80 minutes on skis with Anders at elm. Boy.... Wake up call.

Was supposed to be at the U of M at 4:45 for some 800's, but the first snowstorm of the year had different plans for me, including spending 4 and a half hours in a car with several south saint paul to st. louis park and back trips. So I hopped on my favorite hamster wheel and started whirring away. Couldn't do speed, because the things don't go fast enough. 

The red wings/flyers game was on, and I actually don't mind watching hockey, so that was cool. Also, some other sitcom was on so I intermittently payed attention to that. Funny excerpt from it:

Mom driving a minivan while her elementary-aged daughter is in the back seat.

Daughter: I think I like a boy.
Mom: Oh yeah? Tell me about him.
Daughter: He likes the swings, and sits by the flags. And he can count to 100.
Mom: Well gosh! He sounds like the complete package!
Daughter: Just one problem...
Mom: What's that?
Daughter: I don't think he notices me...
Mom: (yelling) WELL THEN YOU MAKE HIM NOTICE YOU! You don't want to wake up one day, a lonely 9 year old and wonder where all the time went...

lol.

Anyway, standard 'Nothing sounds like a good idea' workout.

3 miles @ 5:20 pace,
2 miles @ 5:10 pace
1 mile @ 5:00 pace

3 minute jog between

2 up, 2 down. Aerobically felt relaxed. Legs a bit tired from skiing last night.

If only I could take my aerobic capacity and the economy of my stride at 5:20 pace and translate that to the skinny skis....

Started my morning with Finan standing on my porch pelvic thrusting - obviously more chipper about 7 degrees and the -14 windchill than I was. Went down to the creek, slipped around, broke my ankle again a few times, but overall wasn't too terrible. Most notable feature of this run was Finan running across the highway 35 pedestrian bridge with his buttcheeks out yelling, 'Suck on this Minnesota!'

I guess that's one way to deal with it.

-3, WC -17

Calhoun/Harriet standard. Figured the trails may at least be plowed, and other than the uneven terrain - mostly on Harriet's south side - it wasn't awful

took a few miles before I could feel my feet. Welcome to Alberta.
60 minute ski out at Lake Elmo. Pretty splotchy - must have been groomed a while ago, so I was all over the place.

Wayzata Women's XC.

That's all that matters today. I still haven't come down.
Slow going through the snow. But the 4 degrees felt balmy - even got a bit sweaty.

Had decided to take today off from running, but I was antsy and Anders and I had talked about skiing. Still negative a jillion degrees out there, but do-able.

1hr 45 ski at Elm with Anders. Took a break around an hour to put our wankers under the hand dryers to warm up a bit.

The snow was so slow tonight, it was like skiing on carpet. I'll feel this tomorrow.

Snowy, no traction. Freezing.

Nothing new.

At the U with John and Merch.

Reneau was there flirting with SP a bit, but didn't run with us. I just did 4x400, 4x200.

Felt super easy as far as the legs/lungs, but I could get moving because turning on my left ankle was really painful (sharp) every step that wasn't straight. So I basically started with a few hard steps each rep, and then rode the momentum the rest of the way. Goal was quick, but easy.

Two takes: Getting track fast is not something that just is. You work for that shit.
And: I feel fat. Like really fat. I was so... cumbersome out there. I couldn't really feel it at 5 minute pace for tempo runs, but getting down to 4 minute pace, and I just felt so sloppy. Like everything was just loose.

400's: 67, 68, 68, 68
200's (ran these clockwise to try to help my ankle): 31, 31, 30, 31

Slow going through the snow with JL. Harriet. Felt good.

I hope this is the last XC race of my life.
This course is beyond words. I have never seen something so difficult. I'm kinda disheartened. Honestly, if i can hold sub 6's and not get injured, that'll be enough.

stiff-legged amble down to and along the Deschutes river in Oregon. Felt a lot better by the end. Could tell that my legs went through the ringer the previous day. Probably going to do some hiking later today, it'll be good to keep moving, I suppose.

Ran with Finan at like 6am from the Kampf's house. River Road loop with Finan, Heather, Dani Stack, Ben, and Dominic. got to hear about Heather's strangely detailed dreams, make fun of Jon Petersen, and Ran past a confused Dan Greeno.

Just been skiing the past few days, but all systems felt good.

another early morning before taking Finan to the airport. Inner Wirth loop. By the MLPS mount Krumpet we had to hop the bike path and run uphill though a minimum of 10 inches of snow. Finan, the perpetual cake-eater was complaining about that like it was somehow cancerous. Welcome to MN, buddy. At least it wasn't slippery. Then karma caught up and I broke my ankle again about 30 seconds later. I love running.

20k Skate ski on the Birkie trails with Marit.

Because I love her, and for absolutely no other reason.

20k+ skate on a hillier section of trail with Marit again. Bitch hill was pretty fun, if you like  the feeling of being on a stair-stepper, after three lines of cocaine with congenital tachycardia.

Actually a pretty darned gorgeous place, and a great weekend.
A little frigid trot around the lakes. Started cruising on the south side of harriet because the cold was irritating.
Short run, just didn't much care about being out there any longer than I was.

1hr 30 classic ski with the Sonnesyn's at French after a garbage run this morning. First time in 7 years on classics... that was nifty. Didn't have the greatest kick, but manged just fine* beautiful out - upper 20's.

*fine is a relative term.
slow on Kings, 6:30's on the creek. felt easy, felt good. I wish Minneapolis would plow. Jumping the snow berms every block is making me a hell of a steepler.

1hr 45min ski at french. Met Adrian out there and did a lot of this with him. Double poled the classic loop on skate skis, including the uphills. My triceps are sore now - but on my little across the bridge double pole sprint at the end, I was flying. Came off the ground when I'd come up over my skis. I'm sure it looked funny, my hopping out there.

Did my last solo lap about as hard as I could give 'er.

Chili at Marit's after. nomnomnom.

Hastings > Minneapolis.

Other than the bike path along the river, the dam, and across the dike, The trails were clear. Pavement. 37 degrees and wet pavement at that. And anyone who knows me knows how excited I get about running on wet pavement. It felt like a glorious spring day out there today, and after a galavantingly slow first 4 miles I couldn't keep the demons back any longer and I started to float some quicker miles. 5:50's, mostly. Wasn't hard, by any means, but I could tell two things: 1) my legs have some volume in them from this skiing nonsense and 2) I have not done any sort of fast-twitch activation work in For. Ev. Er. So I at least did a half dozen hard strides at the end. 

I did get the welcome home I expected from the Hastings community. Good for them for not progressing a bit in their ignorant na�vety. I was wearing spandex tights, a t-shirt with a half zip over it, and a baseball cap. Normal, yes? Somewhere along the river a woman - who interrupted her own phone call to tell me something - said, 'It disgusts me that you think it's ok to just wear spandex in public.' I put on my biggest shit-grin and kindly said back, 'Happy holidays! Isn't it a beautiful day out?' Then I proceeded to prance my spandex-clad self away so as to no longer disturb her delicate psyche. Then, crossing 55 on Pleasant (I actually waited my turn to cross today) I was crossing in the crosswalk, on green, and even had the little walk light. So totally in the clear, no? Well eastbound traffic was stopped on red, cars in both lanes. This dude in the right turn lane (ostensibly unable to see me as I was obscured by the cars) rolls right through the cross walk, like he is going to turn right (on red, mind you) without even considering stopping. I put my hand out to brace myself, and he braked, but way too late. So I did the only logical thing, and that was to jump on the hood of his minivan/suv looking thing. I jumped off the other side, and kept running, when the driver decided to honk at me. I turned around, flipped him off, and saw that it was a high school aged boy, and he was screaming something at me behind closed windows. So I gestured for him to come over. He pulls up along side of me by the library, rolls down his window and says, 'Stay out of the fucking road! Do you not know what a highway is? There are sidewalks for a reason.' I replied, cavalierly, (all while still running 6 minute pace) 'Have you never heard of a crosswalk? In fact, it's that thing that connects those two sidewalks that I was running on. And your light was red. And I had a walk light. Stay in school - I know these are all really challenging concepts.'

He said something about kicking my ass and then drove off. It was nice out, I had some adrenaline pumping, and I kind of wish he would have tried that.

BUT, no one called me a fag today. H-town for the win.

French with the intention of a 2 hour ski. but it was a hockey rink. Skating was pretty impossible because there wasn't even any snow on top of the ice to push off of. after 1hr 15 I just stopped. On to some freezing weather!
With Adrian in -14 degree nonsense. Pretty awful out there.
1hr 45 ski at baker with Marit. Not icy like french, but it did start to feel pretty styrofoamy by the end. cold.

four miserable blocks to snap, then hopped on the treadmill. my earbuds wouldn't stay in my ears, then my iPod died, and after 3 miles I started getting some icky heartburn. The world has it out for me. I dropped to 5:00 pace just to see how out of shape I've become, and surprisingly it felt fine. Like, boring fine. Then the heartburn got the best of me, and I'm just not focused enough to fight right now. With how messed up my ankle is on turns, I don't know that I'll be able to run indoor, and I have nothing on my horizon. I do really want to run, just not in the weather.

With John in cold, but positive temps. (3?) - hence why we felt like doing an actual run today. I know none of what I'm doing makes sense, but it's survival. That's it. getting through the cold, no-footing nonsense alive. Cruising right along, when at lower riverside park I slipped off the path and rolled my ankle. hard. debatably the worst of the year, pending how long it takes for it to get better. When I did it in October with Kuhn was the other really bad time, and it still hasn't healed. I can't take left turns any faster than like 6:00 pace from that still. But I thought I broke something. This time I rolled the other way (supination) and took one step immediately after and it could not bear any weight at all. so down I went, fetal position, in the snow, in front of a half dozen drivers. One guy stopped and offered a ride up Franklin hill - said he saw the fall - but I felt like i needed to keep it moving. so after a few minutes and massaging I limped a bit, and somehow made it the 7 miles home. as long as my footfall is completely flat and straight, I could run fine. any sort of non-level surface, turns, or hills, and nuh-uh. As I write this in the morning, it's tender to the touch, and there's some discoloration. I certainly sprained it, to some degree. I don't bruise, so this is unique. As long as the bones are intact, which I'm certain they are.

Winter.

3hr 5min skate ski at Hyland with Anders, and Kory for the first hour. Hyland's man made loop was really sweet, and pretty challenging. The 'Scenic Foothills' were tough, and the steep hill on the backside was like nothing I've ever seen. But I did it 3 or 4 times.

At about 2hrs 45 I started to bonk. 3 hours is a long way to go on a cup of coffee and a bunch of happy thoughts.

Most painful part of my body: My wrists. Go figure.
Running later, as the impending arctic death storm will make the next 3 days questionable in regard to anything physical.

Welp, ran to complete fatigue today. Got home from skiing, had a protein shake, two pieces of toast, a beer and a multi-vitamin - because I knew I'd be running soon. Started off easy, 7:10 maybe, then quickly ratcheted it down. 6:30 - 6:00. Averaged sub 6:30's though six, and likely through 9, but I didn't check. Then the wheels came off. high 7's for 10, well over 8's for 11, then I couldn't run anymore. There was nothing left to burn, and I was getting kind of dizzy. So I walked the last half mile home. With -55 wc on deck, I wanted to do something today that would take some time to recover from, and I thought I succeeded. Though as I write this Sunday morning, I feel fine.

Like the great philosopher of our generation, Cornell Iral Haynes, Jr, said: 'What good is all the fame if you ain't f*ckin' the models.'
treadmill. 2 easy, 1 @ 5:30, 1 @ 5:00, 2 easy. wasn't even breathing hard. Short, but I couldn't stand all the resolution joggers.

On the treadmill. Broke up the boredom with some easy pickups.

10minutes @ 5:40
10minutes @ 5:30
10minutes @ 5:20

Grinders gonna what, boys?

Easy on the treadmill. Watched a guy repeatedly fail at picking up the same girl.

Girl on treadmill, guy sitting on weight machine. The guy walks up to the girl (who just started jogging)

Guy: Hey, I've been here all night, and only have one set left - How long are you planning on running?
Girl: Um, you know I'd like to go for a while yet, I just started, actually.
Guy: Cool, well I'm gonna go do my lifts and then maybe we can do something.

walks away

maybe 5 minutes later

Guy: Ok, I'm done. For real, you ready to go or what?
Girl: I think I'm going to keep going a while longer. Thanks though.
Guy: Why?
Girl: *awkwardly ignores him*

Dude was bold. Stupid, but bold.

Ugh. 

I don't know what's been going on the last day or two, but my mind just hasn't been... right. I have absolutely no reason to feel icky, so that in itself is kind of frustrating. I Left work around 3 to get a run in and clear my head - Tried Lilydale but that hasn't been touched by a plow all winter, so I went up to Summit, and the sidewalks were the kind of snow that happens when it's not plowed, but people walk over it for weeks and it compresses into lumpy ice. So this ended up being pretty short. Oh well I guess.

And now i'm back at work until 10 tonight. Bleh. Not the most wonderful of days.
Just lake looping with John. Pretty bad footing for about half of it.

Morning from the bandshell with Jack, John, ET, and Jon Gray. Footing sucked, nothing notable. Talked abut the most (physical) pain we'd ever been in - being elementary aged, wearing footie pajamas and zipping the tip of my penis in the zipper FTW. ...Had to unzip back over it.

50.55k skate ski at Hyland with Anders. Absolutely love that I can have an enjoyable morning before participating in this sport. Right before this, Mar and I split a large 6 egg omelet, a few pieces of toast, and a pot of coffee. No problems. While skiing I ate 3 Gu's some water, and V8 strawberry/banana juice. A bite of a bagel. Fairly continuous, stopped at my car to grab Gu's, fill up a water belt, and stopped once to chit chat with Erica Hett, her sister, Mar, and probably other people who I didn't notice because I wasn't paying attention. 

3hr 15min running time (I stopped my watch when we took the aforementioned stops, which apparently is a no no in skiing. But then I just won't stop. Can't stand the idea that a clock is running and I'm not moving). 

Only did the big hill in back every third lap, so... 4 times?
Ran up to the U to watch John race the mile. 6:22 pace for the 7.25 up there, then cooled down with him a bit easier.
Easy, short run through some yucky wind around Calhoun. Lots of new snow, drifting but dry, so footing wasn't horrendous. Prerace?

5k skate race at Elm. Fun, encouraging, and disappointing all at the same time.

The race started out and Anders and 2 other guys went to the front, and then a group of 10 or so of us skied behind. At the final right-turning uphill before the downhill leading to the wall, I moved to get up to the front of our group, and as I was passing a Fulton dude I was shoved off the side of the trail. My right ski sunk under a foot of powder, and I went down. Couldn't stand back up either, because my right pole was under my ski, under the snow. So I quickly took my strap off, stood up, climbed back onto the trail, put my pole back on and took off all by my lonesome. I would guess it took 20ish seconds. From that point on, it was just a sprint because I was determined to catch the guy who pushed me. With a little under 2k to go I saw people again, and I caught one, then another, and then with maybe 1200 left I saw the Fulton guy. V2'd harder than I probably ever have, got up to him, and then he splayed his poles and started skiing back and forth across the trail, so I couldn't go by. Got a little pissed, cuz this is wednesday night at elm, not the World Cup, and just skied across the tops of his skis. Went by. Beat him. Couldn't reel Kory back in, which was the goal at the start. Ended up 12th out of 20, 15:34. 

Anders got 3rd, according to the results, but it was a photo finish, and with the blizzard-like conditions, no one could see the finish line (not so much a problem for me, I just stopped when I got to Ander's parents). Trails were well groomed, but had a lot of drifting new snow over them, which sucked a little. Windy as heck out there - felt bad for the classic people, because their tracks were filled with snow. Oh well. You shouldn't classic after college. There are rules.

Treadmill around dinner time. 
 Probably should have just recovered a bit today, but I felt fine and it's winter so I don't have to train sensibly. Just cram that aerobic quality.... maybe then I'll come into spring fit after fewer vO2/muscle activation sessions.

6x5 minutes @

5:21, 5:18, 5:18, 5:18, 5:18, 5:00

Aerobically easy, quads a little tired. Even did strength after. Dips, push ups, carriages, and planks.

No rest for the weary. West river standard with John. Interestingly, even though I'm hardly running at all right now, I feel like 1) Any workout I've ever done, I could do. It would take a lot longer to recover from, but I could do anything once, and 2) get rid of all the snow, make it 60 degrees, give me 4 weeks and I'll be in or equivalent to the best shape of my life.

So, so far so good with surviving winter. 

Today was a ball buster though. Not hard on the whole, but the greenway all the way back from west river was an ice rink. I stopped running and could slide about 10 feet. so that sucked for 4.5 miles. 

Cold. Headwind. I just want to hide under a lot of blankets right now.

Easy day, my legs needed it after the past 3. I'm getting soft.

Skied for 90ish minutes after watching Mar/Alayna/Kiddie easily win the sibling category up at the JNQ. Went north from OO until I met Dr. S, turned around and skied with him until he thought he was going to bonk, then we went back.

Three observations about that man:
1. He knows every single person who skis on the Birkie trails, and will talk to every single one.
2. His quietest voice is JUST edged out for decibel levels by the Boeing AC-130, but people respond to him as if nothing is out of the ordinary - luckily, living with John has me conditioned.
3. If you're ever going to bonk, being with him is a good idea, because it's very likely that he has some half eaten, frozen food item in one of his clothing pockets that he's forgotten about for >7 days

Skied from OO to Telemark, mostly with Jill. I did a few surges, but I just didn't feel strong, and on those trails you're always climbing or gliding, and that made it impossible to find a rhythm. I have a long way to go. I wish there was just some magic way to learn technique - I'm sloppy, I know I'm sloppy (and I know what it SHOULD look like) and it's frustrating. 

But a lovely ski, nonetheless. 2 hours? Did a jillion crunches because we got lost and skied a while - all double polling - through untouched snow along the power lines before reconnecting with the Korte trail.

After feeling the -14 wc, and the bleak, dark hopelessness of outside, I grabbed some shorts and went to the gym. Holy resolution joggers. Everywhere. I'm ready for them to give up. I had to stand there and awkwardly wait for a treadmill to open up, because God knows I'm not about to do something different. One opened up - probably objectively the least desirable one there. It's in the corner, no TV's, just a blank wall. I didn't bring my iPod either, so I just did that wonderful thing that 10's of thousands of miles does to you, and I just dissociated. Turned it on and went to sleep.

2 mile w/u, 800m pick up, then 5 miles at whatever pace felt swift but easy (had a t-shirt over the screen so I couldn't see pace/distance). Finished the 5 miles in 26:34 (5:18 average). Wasn't even breathing hard at the end, just felt kinda.... eh... unimpressed. At least I suppose it's a good indicator that my lackadaisical training isn't hurting me too much. 2 mile c/d. Lifted after, since I was there anyway. Pushups, dips, carriages, planks, core. all to failure, 2 times.

Another one down. To brighter days.

6 whole miles! wooo.... Kinda like a day off, except I was slightly less comfortable than had I not run at all. Oh well, it's something.

On track for a 200 mile January, which I would imagine (injuries notwithstanding) would be my lowest month since high school or something.

Feeling fine.

Went back to Hastings because at least the treadmills go a few ticks under 5:00 pace. Felt composed on the warmup, so I figured I'd just max it out from the first one. As little as i'm running right now, there's no time to be a baby when I do get moving.

4x1 mile in 4:50, 4:50, 4:50, 4:50

6 minute jog

5k in 15:39 (5:02 avg)

Full strength/core routine after.

Everything felt good - wish I could have gone faster, actually. Easy. Except for the fact that about a mile in to the 5k, my mom walked in (random, right?) and started to talk to me about tax paperwork. Still no idea what we talked about.

If I can scrape together fast skis, and enough efficiency to make next Sunday purely aerobic, then, in the words of Lil Wayne: 'Shawty, I'mma hit it hit it like I can't miss.'

2 hours at Hyland. Felt pretty strong, but could tell my legs were a bit beat up. Snowing pretty steadily, which made it a little tough to keep my eyes open at times, and the inch or two of powder on the trails was mildly irritating. Good workout, tried to really give it toward the end, but my legs just didn't have much more to offer.

80 minute easy skate. What sucked about this was that I was too lazy to re-wax, and I had old CH8 on. And it was sub zero. Climbing hills felt like velcro. Cold, but a good day. Kelly gave me some Podiums that came with clear lenses, which was cool, cuz not having to squint from the wind is nice.

I don't know if I should keep hammering this week skiing, or back off and hope for the best. All things considered, it probably doesn't matter. When it's game time, it's game time.

'I may be little but I'm coming for the crown.'

2 mile w/u, 5k in 15:30, 1 mile c/d

Cut the cool down short because I started getting some pretty bad heartburn? That was strange. Legs were definitely more tired today than when I did a workout last Thursday. Today wasn't.... going-to-the-well difficult by any means, but toward the end I did the un-focus your eyes, stare into the middle distance and go to your happy place thing that every runner knows.

Full strength circuit after.

I've also descended into race-week mode. I know this isn't my sport, but I still find myself with the singular-objective feeling. No question, on Sunday there will be dozens and dozens of stronger skiers in the race than me - and I will lose to every one of them. But since I started logging on here my sophomore year of college, I've run 20,000 miles, who knows how many before that, and if anyone in that field can grind, God knows I can grind with the best of them. Maybe I'll blow up, and I'd be at peace with that, knowing that I tried. That said, I know how to race, and I would not doubt that as far as aerobic strength goes, I'm the strongest person in that field. Looking over the 800 some people who are registered so far, if it were a distance running race on Sunday, I would win.

Anders' edit: 'I may be starting last (literally), but I'm coming for the crown.' 

I'm ready.
Easy gallop. pretty unremarkable.

30k skate at elm. Solo, no stopping, no food/water (but I did wear a belt).

Ended up being a bit progressive? Felt fine.

5k splits by my watch:
16:25
15:49
16:15
15:47
15:22
14:40
=1:34:18

Crown.
Skied at elm for I don't know how long. Not very, because the open 2.5k loop was wayyy too windy and cold, and I wasn't dressed for it, and the woods weren't groomed. So I cut it pretty short.
hour, hour and 15 at Wirth. Slow snow, but that considered I still felt pretty lethargic today. Things will turn around.
Just an easy run on the hamster wheel to shake out and let my.... ski muscles? recuperate. Ready to go tomorrow, I think.

Well... Skiing.

I got to start in the second to last row of the very last wave, which I knew going into it would be frustrating at times. I probably could have started at the front of my wave, but I stayed in the warming tent unit about 3 minutes before the start. It was like -3, calm and sunny at the start, and I wasn't cold. I was about 6-8 rows of people back, so the gun went off and even though I was double poling as hard as I could, I still was caught in the mess when the trail collapsed. The first 10k was like an interval workout. I'd get caught behind people and ski slower than just casual ski pace, and then I'd see and opening and sprint to the next little aneurysm of skiers and then hang out behind them again. I know that everyone has to start in the back of their first race and work their way forward, and I just kept telling myself that. But my running-racing mentality was absolutely killing me out there. I'd estimate I had to stop (completely stop for some period of time) about 12 times throughout the race. The worst was when the trail for the marathon and the trail for the tour skate combined at a climb just after Wirth Lake, and there were small children trying to climb in front of and next to me. This was also where another Loppet skier skied over the tip of my right ski as I was trying to climb, and I fell. By the time I got to Lake of the Isles, it was finally clear enough that I felt like I could ski my own race. I found a rhythm and began making up ground. Until maybe 6 or 7k to go I felt really energetic - and I thought that if I could have drank something toward the end it would have helped. Buuuut my water bottle was frozen, so I just had to do without. Marit gave me something by 394 - some warm, salty/sweet liquid that I'm sure would taste rancid in normal life, but it was heavenly considering the circumstances. I beat all the Johnnies, catching the last one on Calhoun's east side, but that accomplishment is tainted, because they raced the day before as well. Marit's dad made me look like a child, beating me by like 6 minutes. Of which over 4 of them came in just the first half (he was wave 4, which would still really suck). 

For the circumstances, I'm pretty happy with how it all went. Frustrating, sure, but it was fun. I was the 202nd finisher overall, but adjusted for time from the wave starts (I started 25 minutes back), I placed 91st of 819 finishers, in 2:26:33 - even too since the first 10k was congested, and the last 5k was really tired. My first 21k was only 1 second per mile faster than my second 21k. Of the people who finished, I had to physically ski around 617 other skiers - no small task on the Wirth trails (470 skiers in the first 21k alone). I won my wave, beat all but 2 people from wave 4, all but 5 people from wave 3, everyone in wave 2 (except the two elites who started late), and most of wave 1. I felt strong, energetic, and like I have room to improve. I loved seeing, and a huge thank you, to Marit, Alayna, Kiddie, John, Kate, and anyone else who was out there. Pretty sweet to have that kind of support. It really, really helped.

According to Anders, this finish will put me in the elite wave next year, which I'm excited for for two reasons: 1) I look forward to seeing how I can ski without having to ski thought 5 waves of people, and 2) That will at least assure I can start in wave 3 of the Birkie next year even if I don't do a qualifying race - and that was my goal going in today. 2014: Qualify at CoL for Birkie wave 3, 2015: Qualify at Birkie for the elite wave, 2016: Birkie elite wave vs Steve Sonnesyn head to head.

And now, Me and Anders, 2015, CoL top.... number to be decided later.

Thanks to Anders as well, I had faster skis than anyone around me.
Easy with John. Talked about what kind of dogs we wanted and the prospect of warmer, brighter days.
Ski at Hyland until I felt like being done. I was the only person there. Kinda eerie.

With John around the lakes, the the creek and back on Bryant. Pretty darn cold out there. I still hate winter. I don't think I even mind snow. If it could be snowy but... not below zero, I'd like that. Take me to that place?
Eating lots of gummy worms en route to Ishpeming. I think my biceps are sore from all the lifting.

4 hours of intermittent skiing. Skied around the course watching Mar, cooled down with the girls, skied like 90 minutes after on the olympic trails, solo, and then drove around Ishpeming (happening place) with a pair of Siamese twins looking for a book store that didn't exist.

Life.

Up at 6:30 to get a ski in before the race, but the sun doesn't rise in Michigan until after 8... So I dawdled a while, then skied an hour and a half. My wrists are sore now. I gotta get serious about training again if I want to be competitive this spring. Can't imagine doing track work right now.

A bit icy at times, but a good run with JL around downtown and back vis Loring Park/Bryant. Legs a little burned in the beginning, but felt good by the end. Looks like some warmer weather coming! (....relatively)

With John, Jack, and we ran into Ben W out by Cedar. Just a lovely run. Argued extensively about how fast we could run a steeple strictly off of the skill gained by hurdling snowbanks all winter. 

I love how every November, if you ask me what winter is, it's beautiful, fresh, sticky snow, 38 degrees and sunshine.

Reality: Brown compacted uneven ice-death that you can't see because it's dark and the warmest it's been in two weeks is 11.

Almost got to say I won my first ski race. Though it wasn't much of a real race. Just the 5k at Elm Creek, and there was really nobody there. Favorable conditions, didn't have super fast skis, but who's gonna wax for that one, right? Before the race, Amy Xu asked if I was feeling good. I said as good as any other day, I suppose, and she gave me race  'advice' I've never heard before. 'just take your time out there.' Lolz.

Started, and just was out the back before we were done double poling. I got into a rhythm, but I felt slow, and the gap kept opening. By 1k, the leader - Jeremy Blazar? was easily 100m ahead, and by 2k even more. But... Grinders gonna grind, and it slowly started to seem like I was catching up to Broham McRocketskis. As we cleared the woods with 500 to go, I passed him. My firmly held belief that if you're going to make a move, make it hard came to mind and I stepped on what little bit of gas I had left, hoping he'd let me go. I gapped him by 10m and held it, but with just under 100m to go he pulled back even, and we all out sprinted to the finish. All I really had left was to move my arms faster, and it wasn't enough. We both slid at the line, and it was a photo finish, but I'm positive he beat me. Not by more than a tenth, but there's no such thing as 'Almost Winning' Just losing by a little, or a lot.

Posted time was 13:49, which is almost 2 minutes faster than last time. So... That's good, right? 

Can't believe I caught that dude. 

5k warmup, 15k cooldown

Felt a little off my game after yesterday's race, but everything went well enough. Ran with John on the Hiawatha Bike trail into downtown and back. We got on the discussion of being steeplers again, and John said that in college Dale wanted him to do it, but he (and I quote) 'Neglected to recognize the fact that I have the grace and coordination of a drowning horse.' 

A good visual to end the run on.
Lakes with John. We found a page from a pornographic magazine on the sidewalk. Valentine's day. Love is in the air.

Solo ski workout at Hyland. 10k warmup, 5k hard, 5k easy, 5k of sprinting the hills and recovering on the flats, 5k with 4x2mins all out, 5k cool down.

Felt... ok. I don't know if it's cumulative fatigue, or the race 3 nights ago, but I felt flat. My arms were tired, my hips were sore, and my quads had just about had it by some point in the middle. I felt flat racing this week too, but I don't know. I don't really know how to gauge this sport like I can for running.

35k total - 2 inches of fresh powder over the whole course made the effort for this pretty darn excruciating at times.
Just a guess on time. In Hastings after bringing my mom home. Nothing was plowed so I just jogged.
OAB Greenway eastbound. Felt good, but my tights felt tighter than normal. Either skiing is making my quads bigger, or I'm getting fat... in the legs. I don't like it, either way.

A guess on time. Moving pretty quickly at times, shuffling at others. I practiced my steeple skills (of which there are none) all the way down Kings, then the creek to Cedar. adventured my way back home from there. Absolutely beautiful morning, unfortunately that resulted in really sloppy, slippery paths. That made 11 miles feel like a marathon. Funny how 30 degrees felt downright tropical, but the morning of the TC marathon 2012, when it was 30, I considered not racing.

Ski at elm, decided to race to pass the time. It was like 30 degrees so the snow was fast, but I haven't waxed my skis in a while and what was left on them was pretty hard stuff, so I felt slow. And my legs felt really heavy from yesterday's slush-trot. There were only six people in the 'race', so I won pretty handily. One guy who skis for the U (I understand they aren't good?) asked me post-race who I skied for, and when I replied that 'I don't really ski' I think he got mad at me. I didn't mean it as an insult. They lady running timing said I looked good and that if I kept skiing like that people would start to know who I am.... So take note, folks. Nick Ross, future Elm Creek hero. Lol. 13:40. short cool down. Legs still tired.
Through way too much snow around the lake with John. Running is going to really suck this next week.

Ran on the treadmill during the US/Canada game. Pretty poor playing on the US side, but it made the time go by. Started at 7:30 pace, finished at 5:30 pace. Just kept clicking the button. Everything felt easy.

Up at the Birkie with Marit and her family - I galloped around in the snow in my boots for a mile or two, but it was spaced out and not an actual workout. Freezing and windy, but such an awesome atmosphere. Felt inspired watching everyone race.
easy ski for.... not sure how long. Just a shakeout with Marit from OO.
guessing on time. Ran with Anders, and Kory joined for a bit too. Everything was ice, but everything was fine.
Out to the Hennepin bridge and back with JL. Felt really good, if only the ice would melt and/or I had the heart for a few sensible weeks of training. I'm not far out of fitness.

2 w/u, 2 c/d

5x mile at 5:00. 2 minutes of jogging recovery between.

the first two felt so loose and fluid and easy. then something happened that made the last three way less fun. Not... digging, or anything, just not smooth.

I guess that's just not being in shape.

core/lifting after. My arms are tired now.

My Kinvaras are just about blown. If only I knew a Saucony rep who could get me some new shoes... *CoughRickyLuppCough*

Hopped on the treadmill and went to sleep. Thought this was an uneventful run until I was walking back on the sidewalk behind two girls who had exited the yoga studio next door. I'm sure I tuned in mid-conversation, but one girl said to the other, 'And I bought my wedding dress after a 60 minute workout, so there's no way I'm going to actually fit into it at the wedding.'

How devastating.

On the indoor at the U of M. 

16 minutes w/u,

7x 400m in 67, 68, 68, 67, 68, 67, 68

15 minute cooldown

Talk about feeling out of sorts. I felt like I was in some foreign country, lost, and had no idea how to speak the native language. Except the physical version of that analogy. With Anders, and Marotz was there showing us that if you actually train all winter you can be in shape. We weren't sprinting by any means, but man... 67/68's should not feel that hard.

The ankle held up, but was not having a good time on the turns. My feet were bleeding at the end.

To track season. IF I have to.

I also told Gabe she needed to get off the track during one of her rest intervals because she stepped on Justin's heels. Then I felt awkward. Too soon, probably.
Slowest overall pace for a run in a long while. Regular effort, but it was compacted ice-death the whoooooole way. windchill -21. It was a sride on the struggle-bus.

Just another run, no concerns to note. I was rear-ended on my way to snap, but right in the middle of Fremont at Lagoon. The lady got out of her car, and I said, lets just pull ahead (there was a parking lot across the street) and she got back in her car. I crossed the street, she turned left on Lagoon and took off. Fairly unkind of her to do - I realize the roads are icy, but we should probably at least talk. Oh well, part of life :)

Strength/core after.
Icy run around the lakes with John. Winter has quite the death-grip still. Looking for those warmer days.

Such awful footing. My Achilles hurts now, which is splendid. Ran with John, Reneau, Steph Price, and Brandon Heebink for a little while.

I generally refuse to do 7 mile runs, but as of yesterday I'm on the Ricky Lupp grind, at least for the next 3 weeks, or until D-Mil's life settles down.

didn't do the strides, because there is nowhere in Minnesota that you can do strides now, other than possibly the freeway.

At the U for a workout with John and Anders.

2000, 1600, 1000, 2000, 1600, 1000 with 60 seconds of recovery (75 seconds after the 2000's). Nudged my VDOT value up one just because it felt more... correct, looking at some of the times. Anyway, all I was supposed to run was 5:20 pace, which seems really slow, but hey: If so sayeth the script, so sayeth the script.

Pretty much right on 5:20 pace the entire time, except for one lap in the second 1600 where I totally fell asleep. I was daydreaming out there and it wasn't until Anders yelled something at me that I came back to life. 

6:38, 5:19, 3:20, 6:39, 5:22, 3:20

Not a flashy workout, but you know what? The sun was shining, it was almost 20 degrees, I had flats on my feet, John and Anders on my shoulders, and I can daydream at 5:20 pace. Life is good.
Through mashed potatoes and over ice. Not too cold out, but I ended up running in the dark, and ran pretty hesitantly when I couldn't see what I was stepping on.
Greenway solo. Half clear pavement, half ridiculously slippery ice. My legs were not having it.

absolutely horrendous footing. Along the river I found a reasonable line and was able to make some time up. But man.... The greenway from the river to Hiawatha was just about un-runable. my hips/hamstrings don't like me after this.

Ran in Joey Camp on West River, so I turned and ran with him for a bit before deciding that getting farther from home may not be the best move. Good to catch up.

With Marit at Gustavus. My legs really never unlocked. Windy, but pleasant temps. We did the flying eagle thing down West 99. In memory of Jeremy Kuhn and his golf cart adventure. Didn't feel like adding on, and I think I'm alright with that, given the condition my legs are in/where I want them to be.

Lovely company.

A slop fest out there. Clear pavement, but ran through a bunch of puddles up to ankle deep, so I was thoroughly soaked. Had 4 sets of Russian 200's on deck, but with no track access and variable trail conditions, I just did a dozen or so 200ish meter pickups from miles 4 to 8. Then a mess of strides after. My hamstring pain never went away, but it never got worse, and as I write this it's completely shifted to my quad, just on the lateral side of the mid-line. Not worried though, just winter nonsense.

53 degrees, shorts and a t-shirt. Hard to complain about that.

Easy around the lakes with Jack. A bit windy and overcast, but on the whole, I'll take it. Legs a bit stiff from yesterday, but everything seems fine enough. 

Unrelated, but man did Finan and I have a strange conversation today. He tindered with some girl who went to gustavus, who didn't know me but knew of the library streakers. Finan's quote, 'Legendary Nick Ross. Doesn't know who you are, but has probably seen your junk.'

Then based on her first name and major I figured out her life story. And I mean life story. I like to believe Finan is still in a fetal position contemplating life right now. In fact I'll post my response here:

Things I knew: Her first name was Madison. She was a comm studies major at GAC. My text to Finan:

'Madison Pettit, from zumbrota Minnesota. Favorite activities are running, horseback riding, spending time with friends. She's interested in a career in sales, marketing, or advertising. She actually worked on a dairy farm, (just like me) milking cows and doing other farm related work. She's quite fond of the actress Kirsten Bell, and would like her to act as her should a movie ever be made about her life. Her parents are Joel and Sarah, originally from new Jersey. They met each other showing cows with their local 4-h club. They were married in July 1983 and lived together seven years before moving to Minnesota together (June 1990). Her moms favorite restaurant is 'newts' because the have the best burgers. Madison has an older sister kalie and a younger brother Jared. While at Gustavus, Madison was a writer for our school paper, and did her senior thesis on the civil war letters of olof Nelson. Her middle name is Marie. She likes cantaloupe and wore a light pink dress for her senior prom. All the men in her family drive Chevy trucks. She took a trip back in 2012 to the grand Cayman islands with her then boyfriend Kyle Olson. She's currently an account coordinator at prestige resorts and destinations. She had an internship at dominium, worked for target,  and ran track and cc in high school. Distance. I can give you prs if you really care. Her twitter handle is madisonpettit. Anything else you want?'

Finan: F*** ME. Dude. Wtf.

A pretty 'blah' workout. Probably could have run faster, but I wasn't willing to go above the pre-determined effort that I thought this workout would take. I can't even tell you what part of me was tired... because it was nothing, really. My legs were fine, my lungs were fine, I just couldn't find a rhythm and my breathing wouldn't settle. At the U of M indoor with Jake and Anders. did 7x800 w/ 2 minutes recovery. Goal was just 2:26-2:28, so not fast, really, but sort of that awkward speed between trying hard and daydreaming. Maybe that was the problem. I also was all over the place for pacing. On the third rep I took us out in like 34, hit the brakes, still was at 71 at 400, then came back soooooo slow for an awful positive split 2:28. My metronome just isn't calibrated yet.

2:27, 2:26, 2:28, 2:26, 2:29, 2:29, 2:29 

Not super confident after this one, but.... getting there.

Felt pretty sluggish, but 47 and clear skys? Sun's out, gun's out. Shorts and a T-shirt... and I was sweating by the end. Lakes with John, and there we so many people out there. 'The Bar Louie Crowd' as John pretty accurately titled them. hundreds of 24 to 28 year old young professionals in the latest Nike Frees, 3/4 tights, and some neon jacket that they got for Christmas.

Not a lot of people in shorts. But not many people were as ecstatic as I was that it wasn't overcast and -30.

Well, I couldn't fall asleep to save my life, and by.... just before 3am I was pretty sick of staring at my wall so I did about the only thing I know how to do - pulled  on a pair of tights, some shoes, and took a lap of Calhoun. 

I suppose I'll still do an actual run at some point today.
Easy hodgepodge around Loring Park with John.

Long run to the creek, across the Ford bridge into St. Paul, along East River, Back over Lake, and home on the Greenway. Body felt fine, but depleted already by mile 6. I didn't eat enough yesterday. But, it went well enough I suppose. 

Also ate too much before this, and as I knew it would, I got the heartburn around halfway. 

Buuuuuuut.... pretty swell weekend on the whole :)

Greenway west with John. Loop around Bass Lake Reserve, a little farther west, and then home. Things felt a bit stiff starting out, but was loose and easy by the end. Haven't been over 70 in a while. Slowing starting to resemble spring.
Ah. Supposed to go 10, but just felt rusty. I hope this leg-crud goes away soon. Cedar/Isles with JL.

Another run feeling out of sorts. I'm just... heavy, and my legs are unwilling. Did 6 strides after to hopefully get things pointed in the right direction, but man... I'm 'training' like such a weenie right now.

I just want shorts weather.

At the U indoor solo, but Marotz and A-town were there taking their own respective rides on the struggle bus.

8x threshold 1000's w/ 45 seconds recovery, 5x200m floats after.

Goal pace was just 3:20 for the 1000's

3:18, 3:19, 3:19, 3:20, 3:19, 3:20, 3:21, 3:20

32, 33, 33, 33, 32

Now I recognize going out for Mexican at lunch today may not have been the most conducive idea I've had, but regardless, I don't know what's going on. Aerobically, I'm fine, but my legs are lead. I felt like I would imagine a really fast motorcycle would feel like trying to pull a horse trailer. I'm trying not to get too down about all this, but my goodness. I'm not running that much. I'm taking recovery. I know I haven't done enough strides this season, but winter is just making us its bitch and there's not too much I can do about that. Unrelated, but apparently I have a doppelg�nger out there named Henry, because some girl called me Henry twice while I was running my cool down... She was surprised when I told her I wasn't him. But he's a cool guy apparently? Odd.

I do really, really think I need to get back on the morning run routine, but I don't have the spirit that Jack has to push through the dark, cold mornings. I know that will help though.

I did everything I was supposed to in this workout, and I still feel pretty discouraged. I just haven't felt normal in a long time.

60 hours now with no caffeine. Maybe that's my problem.

Long day. I intentionally ran as slowly as I could possibly run, without it being walking. No watch, but I was shuffling. not even jogging. I know it's dumb to do this so early in the season, but I have done zero fast-twitch activation this year, so I have to rely fully on aerobic grinding this weekend. And if I can't get my legs back under me, this race won't happen. Period.

Interestingly, The last 3 discouraging runs I've done I had a dove chocolate immediately after, and every one of them said, 'Believe in yourself'. I opened it today, and thought, no way. Too much of a coincidence. So I grabbed another. 'Believe in yourself'. And I've not had any that said that, from this bag, at any other time.

I've trusted stranger things.

Still trying to ride the recovery train. With John around Bass Lake. It was windy, overcast, and still winter.

I need out of this state.

http://notesfromalobsterfishingvillage.blogspot.com/2012/10/the-5-prettiest-fishing-villages-in.html
Morning run with JL and Finan. This isn't saying much, but today was the best I've felt in a while. Pretty excited when I saw that -10 windchill this morning.

Took today off. Partially because I feel like going from not running much over the winter to running every day for weeks on end may not be smart, and partially because my hip was a bit tight today to the point that it woke me up last night, and I can feel it going down my leg. 

Nothing major, and I'm not concerned - I certainly could run on it, but last week I decided that this week I'd take a day off. I feel lazy, but whatever. The show goes on.

Hopped on the Greenway and started heading west, the intention being that I run until I don't feel like it anymore. That turned out to be approximately the time that I got to my sidewalk, so I thought maybe I'd just sleep through ten easy miles. Was moving pretty quickly, and then ran into Victor Sanchez around a half hour in, so I did his run with him. We went a bit slower, but that was fine. Freezing out, again. I couldn't feel my fingers or toes for the first 3 miles.

Strides after. All is well.

Workout with Anders. 6x800m at 8k-ish pace, 8x100m hill sprints. Gouged my hand pretty bad on grass, of all things, and bled all over the place. Also found John under Target Field with a broken foot. Odd day. Felt fine. The sandy paths sucked, and it was windy, but no complaints.

Everyone, sign this: http://www.ipetitions.com/petition/save-gustavus-nordic-skiing/?utm_medium=social&utm_source=facebook&utm_campaign=button
Wirth, middle of a long day. 36 and a steady rain maybe this a pretty chilly one. Felt fine.
Bumped into Victor and Tesema and ran along with them for a while.
Shakeout on Lakeshore with Greeno, Marotz, and A-town. Windy out there. This would be an awful city to train in.
Creek/40th loop. The creek is flooding... Ran with Anders. Calves a bit tight, but not awful. Felt aerobically hard? Nothing about my life makes sense.

Ran Marit's workout with her. It was a lot colder out than I expected, but reasonable enough. She had 2mile, 4x1 mile on deck @ 10k pace, and I thought I could give that to her fairly consistently. 6:18's were the goal, but we did them on the roads so I didn't get 200/400m split feedback, and it was windy, so it wasn't perfect. I don't recall the splits exactly, but I think it was 12:27, 6:18, 6:08, 6:11, 6:26 (The last one was into a really strong wind and I'm reasonably sure my GPS wasn't reading correctly because we for sure started and ended faster than 6:18 pace. It felt like the fastest one IMO. 

Anywho, it was nice to be on clear trails, especially with the 9-12 inches of snow we are supposed to get Thursday. snow, 35 mph winds... I propose a new seasonal calendar for Minnesota: First winter, Second winter, Third winter, Furnace.

Mar killed it today, I think. Not just because of what the watch said, but (even if she felt like it) she never fell apart. Composure. Love it.

Did we get Toppers after? Yeah. I still feel sick as I write this. Wednesday morning.

Was going to just be an easy gallop around the lakes, but Twin Cities Track Club was out running so I turned around and ran with them a while. Felt a tad sluggish, but did a few strides at the end to shake out a bit.

Wanted to do something fast today, like Anders' TT, but MN decided to rain/hail/snow/sleet so I went inside to the warm embrace of the hamster wheel.
