Since I had an honest race this week, I actually have a VDOT that I'm not just making up so I decided to tailor an impromptu workout to that. I'll probably do some sort of progression this weekend, and then have a two week vO2 max/speed block and then hit some more racing.

did 6x 1 mile at threshold pace. Straight 5:18's the whole way, 90 seconds of recovery. A bit stiff getting going, but by the end I felt really good and could probably have rolled a few more. I could tell my legs had some work in them, but aerobically, this was absolutely cake. Which is good, because I'd really appreciate if this was marathon pace in the fall.
With Anders around the lakes. The snow drifts had overtaken the paths, leaving us with some nice single-track through snow. over pavement. MN.

So, i decided to move my progression run up a day, even though I knew I may not be recovered from the mile repeats. Turns out, I was right. Oh well. A decent effort, and somehow the wind was always in my face. Standard tempo route, out the greenway to 169, around that park, and back via cedar lake bike trail. The 'plan' was 5 miles @7:00, 5 miles at 6:00, 5 miles @5:30. An easyish progression to get my distance legs back under me. Didn't quite go as planned, but I'm still fine with it. I started out with Mar - always a plus :) At mile 12 I was stopped by a train for at least 5 minutes, and after the train I re-opened in 5:05 pace, and the wheels fell off promptly after that. After seeing my 13th mile split, I cut the workout, but then I felt guilty jogging home and decided at mile 14 to run one more fast one. So my splits were:

8:08, 6:48, 6:45, 6:33, 6:49

5:54, 5:46, 5:50, 5:55, 6:00

5:26, 5:28, 5:36, 6:05, 5:15

Another day. All is well.

Started out west on the greenway and met up with Dave on his bike. He flipped and we went backwards on the StLP route. Easy pace today, just getting some recovery. Maybe TT'ing with Anders tomorrow.

Dropped my shirt at 1.5 miles, first shirtless run of 2014. Some 7th grade girl told me (by the Tin Fish) that my shorts were, 'so swag.'

...Sure.

Met Anders at SW because he wanted to do his annual mile time trial. Pretty solid wind on the backstretch, and I had my doubts that I could pull him through very much. He asked for 2:13 through 800, and to my surprise I came around in 2:12.96. A little bit faster the first lap than the second, but nothing too significant. Haven't run that fast in quite some time, and I forgot how the worst part about that sort of speed is the sensation that your throat is on fire. When I pulled off at 800, I felt like kind of a dick making him run the awful third lap solo, and I jumped back in for the last lap.

Anders taught me two things today: 1) that he's a horse and is able to run fast regardless of his current fitness, weather, etc. and 2) apparently the shape of my chest/sternum suggests that I'm 'almost certainly going to die of an aortic aneurism'. I love having medically-minded friends. Just dropping that in casual conversation.

Then, contrary to what that gigantic sack wrote in his log, I didn't insist he run a seven mile cool down with me. I asked what he was doing for his cool down, he said, 'Whatever you are.' I said, 'I don't think you want to do that. I'm going 7.' and he said 'Ok'. I'm not sure who whined more, Anders on the cool down, or me when he said I had to run 66's today.

They also sealed the gap in the fence that we slipped through at the track. Looks like we have to get good at fence climbing, or get skinnier if we want in at SW this summer.

Down to the creek, over to Lake Nokomis, took a lap and came home. This run felt like it took all day. It didn't feel super far, but I felt like I ran for three hours. No pop in my legs, but they weren't sore or anything either. I just felt sluggish and tired.

Morning jaunt, faster than I wanted to go. Hips were tight, legs were heavy... I only vaguely recall a time when I loved morning runs, and they made my second run feel great, so here's to chasing that memory. Also, I need to get back into some volume someday, right?

I was heckled on the greenway by two visibly drunk individuals, who were openly drinking beer, and I saw a severed chicken's foot on the path. Somedays I don't understand this city.

Really wanted to run slower - jog, even - but today was the first day in MN over 70 and you would not believe the lakes today. It was wall to wall people. Not even people... lululemon models in 3/4 spandex, Nike frees, and some neon zip up that hurt my eyes even more than this new, acute sun angle we're now experiencing. Seriously, I've never seen such a high per capita rate of Lycra before in my life. 

Everyone was just playing fashion model on a 3 mile long catwalk, and I was somehow caught in the middle of the nightmare. I felt so agitated out there, dodging everyone, and I was heckled at least 10 times (shorts, no shirt). I didn't even make it to 31st and Hennepin (0.08 miles) without getting my first condescending comment. 

Spring, I like you, but your seasonal minions can go back to hibernation any time now.

On a positive note, I saw Vest Guy on Calhoun, and again on Harriet, and you guessed it: He had his red zip up on. Sooner or later I'm going to turn and run with him for a while and ask why he always has that damn thing on.

Token run, just getting back to that grind. 

Workout on deck for the PM, and it's going to be windy.

Ran down to SW with John, but the team was still practicing so I sat at a picnic table for like a half hour and got cold. They finally finished, I ran 3 laps to warm back up, did some strides, and off I went. Tough workout, a lot harder than I thought it'd be. I guess I was also only planning on 70's. The first 3 were cake, then they became honest, and the last 3 I was just trying to hold form, and relax, relax, relax. Didn't help that there was a 20mph wind, but at least in theory it was at my back part of the time. 60 seconds of recovery really quickly turns into not enough.

10x400 @ vO2 pace (70 or just under), with 60 seconds active(ish) recovery.

68, 68, 66, 66, 67, 68, 67, 69, 68, 67

When I finished, I changed shoes and started walking toward the gate, and a SW distance runner was leaning on the fence. He said he'd watched my workout (Flattering? Creepy?). We talked for quite a while about training, running, life. Slow jogged it home.
Easy morning galavant with Finan. Light on and off drizzle, nothing bad. Nice day, actually.
Isles with John and Finan. Really warm out. It's be pretty sweet if my legs decided to just feel good now.

Morning easy run before heading to GAC for the track meet! Saw the mythical Chris Erichsen out on CLT, which almost never happens. Surprising for a guy who lives two miles away and runs 5-6 thousand miles/year. 

The stuff of legends.

A little sub LT work with Adrian on the standard loop west. John ran our warmup with us, and then we parted ways. 3.65 on the warmup, 3 miles c/d, 10 miles in the middle of comfortable but fast. Pleasantly surprised by the overall average pace, especially since Adrian and I were chatting the whole time. I mean, we weren't spouting monologues, but we held pretty casual conversation. Opened up a bit the last mile. Wasn't pressing, aerobically it felt the same, I just... picked it up. Stayed away from the well.

Splits:

5:35, 5:42, 5:41, 5:32, 5:33, 5:30, 5:33, 5:35, 5:40, 5:07 = 55:28 for 10.

Conditions seemed yucky, but didn't notice them too much, until the last 4 miles where we got hit with a bit of a headwind. Good day, overall.

27 degrees, 15 windchill. That was cool. So, easy morning slog with Finan. Windier than the dickens out there, so we tucked in to the bird sanctuary and ran through those woods for the first time this year. I like it in there. Legs felt alright.
Easy Easy with Finan for 5, then 3 more solo. He's in a tough place right now. Thing's will come around, though. The wind was pretty biting, but all-in-all, not an awful jog.

Just a morning shakeout. Wasn't thrilled about the 8 degree windchill, so I dressed like it was -40. I hope this is the beginning of a pattern - this run actually felt alright. The first morning run I've had that felt kinda good... It's nice having the soft surface of Kings to run on, that certainly helped. Lighter workout this afternoon, though I'm sure it'll still hurt in it's own way. Looks like it's going to be chilly at LaX this Friday. I hope for only 2 things: little/no wind, and warm enough to wear regular running shorts. Fingers crossed.

With Anders down to SW. 1 mile tempo (5:20) followed by 16x 48th street hill sprints. Pretty easy workout, other than feeling dizzy, and it being freaking cold out. I want to lay under every blanket I have right now.

Shorter than I'd planned, but it was snowing, then it turned to sleet, and I just didn't have any fight left today. As soon as I left work today I've just felt... gloomy. I didn't have a bad day, by any objective measure, I just feel kinda down, and I'm guessing that added to the cruddy-ness of this run.

My post-run Dove said, 'Feel good about today'.

I'm trying, small piece of chocolate. I'm trying.
Morning lake lap with Anders. A few strides in the slush.
Shakeout.

Woof. Heavy, heavy legs today. Got home last night at 2:15, but couldn't sleep. I fell asleep sometime after 3, and woke up (not feeling tired, actually) on the earlier side to go watch Mar at Carleton. 10k training, no 1500 work, she finished at the top Gustie in the 1500. Prior to her race I went and frolicked in the Arb. I was hoping for 9, but it was a struggle before mile 2. I feel like my legs were hit by a truck. Surprising, because yesterday after the race they didn't feel that beat up.

Morning run. Happy Easter!! Still a bit groggy when I got up, but Finan had morning commitments so we went fairly early. I wore some new running slippers today, and man did my legs love me for that. I ran the first 10 with Finan, talking about how Minnesota is like an abusive relationship. 6 months of just getting pounded with awful, miserable circumstances, but then we get one morning run when the sun is out and it's warm enough to run shirtless and you're ready to put a ring on it. This morning was beautiful. He also brought up the point that sundresses are like cheat-codes girls can use on boys. I mulled this over, and it's true. Like Atmosphere said, 'Every day that gets to pass is a success. Every woman looks better in a sun dress.'

Now: Recover, Recover, Recover.

Easy frolic with Anders and John. Went up to Wirth, across maggot squirrel, and then got ourselves lost on the Wirth ski trails. Made it back to Cedar Lake, and then came home via sculpture garden. As soon as we got back, Anders and I shot a rabbit in the back yard. Cleaned it, and it's in the freezer. Call it disgusting, but if I'm ever stranded in the woods, I have no doubts that I'm going to make it. The 2014 metropolitan hunting season is upon us. I'm going to get some ducks this year, and we'll have the annual wild game feed :)

Morning shag with Finan, whom I awoke to doing pelvic thrusts on my porch in the sunrise. Majestic.

Felt alright. A little heavy, but nothing concerning.

Talk about choose your own adventure... Anders and I met up at Southwest after work to do a light workout for our respective assaults on the track this weekend. When we got there, there was a meet going on. Luckily, we drove, so we just went over to Washburn to run our intervals there. When we got there, there was a lacrosse game going on. 0 for 2. We drove to Blake, and their track was clear. We dropped our spikes off and went for a warmup. When we got back, there were probably 100 people with disabilities on the track - turns out there's special olympic track practice there from 6:30 to 7:30. We asked the coach if they used all the lanes, and she said yes. So having exhausted our usual options, we decided St. Louis Park's track was close enough, so we went there. Track meet. By this time, the meet at SW was probably over, but it seemed silly to go back, so we went to Hopkins. Their track was empty. We climbed the fence, and had the whole track to ourselves as the sun was slowly setting. Calm, cool, it was almost romantic.

Anders had a mess of 300's on the 2 minute, and I had 8x400 with 90 seconds rest. I didn't look at my watch on the first one, because the effort was more important than a number today (though I had an idea of splits in my head). I wanted them to be really relaxed. I started my first one, and just ran easy, lightly. It was a 68, which is exactly what I was thinking they'd be today. So I decided on straight 68's the whole way.

Went: 68, 68, 67, 68, 67, 68, 67, 64 (the 64 was 68 pace, but I flipped on the burners for the final 100m). All in all, this workout felt good. Easy. 90 seconds of rest felt like a lifetime. 

Anders executed his workout perfectly as well - I think if conditions are good this weekend (doubtful) we'll be ready to scald. 

What a day. 9:44 pm and I'm just now getting to dinner. Walking across the Hopkins parking lot, it dawned on me that for the time we spent looking for a track today we could have driven to GAC, warmed up, and been a few reps in by the time we finally found one. Oh well. Now it's time to rest.
same route as yesterday, same company, same finishing time.
Raining and my hip was tight. Meh. Short run. No concerns.
With John around Calhoun, then down to Harriet and back by myself. Still feel some residual race soreness, I really hope I can finish that off tomorrow.

Just a prerace jog. Strides after. My legs feel.... not normal? Still have the tightness in my right hip/quad, but it's just there enough to be annoying. That's all. I have no idea what sort of 5k shape I'm in, and historically it's my worst event. I should be able to split my PR, or faster, over and over again in longer races. I just have some... mental problem with the 5k. That said, Once I pull that jersey on, I'll be ready to game, and I feel pretty confident going into this one. Gustavus wind notwithstanding, it should be fast.
morning shakeout

This was just me being an unmotivated, lazy, post grad. Windy, raining, gloomy. 

In college, or the year or so after, I'd have never, Never, NEVER done this. But whatever. Perhaps I'm soft.

After not running yesterday, and skipping my morning run (that I hadn't ACTUALLY planned on doing today, but probably should have), I felt really guilty, and Anders wanted to run long. So 15 it was. Easy, slow, though I did feel fairly sick the first 4 miles. Raining and windy and gray and gross - but that's how the week is looking as a whole, so it's time to get used to it I guess. Four more days. Just gotta make it to the weekend.

Windy, sleeting, windchill in the 20's. Tights and three layers on top in April... I laid in bed in the early morning grayness and tried to find any rationalization I could to not do this... But you can't wish your way to fitness. Trial Gardens to Calhoun West.
Why?

Little bit of a workout today, seeing as 40, misting intermittently, and windy is the best conditions we're going to get this week. Legs felt fine going in, and strong enough throughout. The plan was 5 x mile @ threshold pace, and I wanted to keep them around 5:10-5:20 with 90 seconds recovery. I started to get a pretty upset stomach at the end of 2, and by the end of 3 I had to take a break and let my body settle down a bit before I could keep going. I felt guilty about the longer (much longer) recovery than I had planned so I did 6 repeats instead of 5. It didn't help that I ran in an old pair of Montreals, but the wet asphalt felt like it had very minimal traction. Slipped around a bit. I think I ran a little too fast for the conditions today (even though the wind was always perpendicular to me).

5:05, 5:14, 5:17, 5:12, 5:10, 4:59 (opened up the last quarter mile of #6)

In staying true to my preference for running slow, the first mile of my cool down was 8:56. I finished up with 4 fast strides when I got home.
Morning shake out. I could tell that there was a little work in my legs, but everything actually felt pretty good :)

Creek/40th bikeway loop. Probably ran a bit faster than I should have, but it felt smooth and I was jamming to some mental Regina Spektor the whole way. I'm sure I looked foolish playing air drums as I ran along the creek, but hey - life is for living. I heard my name at 36th and Bryant, and Parish was sitting in the intersection on his bike. I asked where he was going, and he said 'Actually I have a date!' (first of all, seeing him on a bike in Minneapolis is a bit strange, as he lives in Bloomington). He was headed to the Walker Art Center, and was concerned he wouldn't get another date because he was late. I told him he should be more concerned that he's showing up to his first date in a full Optum spandex race kit. He seemed unphased. Good run!
Morning jog. R hip tight. The bird sanctuary was like running on bread.

Hadn't run with John is quite a while. Harriet lap, and we brought up all the subjects that we love to argue the same point about, just to get fired up and make the run go by quickly. With about a mile to go, John said, 'So, to end on a depressing note, when it comes time to die...'

Nice to have thoughts that aren't my own, even if they are morbid.

Easy first half with Lance and Finan, quicker second half solo. From the Hamline meet - windy, but good performances from Marit and eFine.

Now, off to Finan's house where he has tacos waiting for me. Good weekend :)

Woke up and fairly hurried out the door, as I was running this with Max Renner, and he forgot he had an appointment today. After a long training consultation and 3.5 sweet-pork tacos with Finan last night, I decided on (was convinced to?) only do 11 miles at Sub-LT, vs the 13.1 I had originally thought I'd do. I didn't know how fast these should be, so I figured I'd cruise around marathon effort, and it'd be what it would be. I met the German legend, Otto Maxwell Renner, at the East Calhoun beach, and we went off frolicking to the greenway. Just over 3 miles on the warmup, and away we went. My nose was running and my eyes were watering the whole time, which was irritating. I must have looked like a mess. My breathing and heart rate also didn't get under control until mile 7 of the uptempo bit, which additionally was frustrating. I wasn't... working hard, but my insides thought I was. The last 4 or 5 miles were into the wind, but they also felt better than those before? I don' understand me. My last mile felt better than all those previous. splits were:

5:41, 5:37, 5:19, 5:31, 5:29, 5:28, 5:30, 5:35, 5:30, 5:30, 5:26

Total time: 60:36 (5:30.5 pace per mile) or the equivalent of 1:12:10 for the half marathon. That a little encouraging because it wasn't... hard. If I had to move in the last few miles, or keep going for a few extra, I could have. It wasn't effortless, but we were able to talk a bit throughout.

Ran down to the lake with Finan after his workout so he could jump in (after which he decided it'd be a good ice bath, and walked back in for 5 more minutes...) Then ran a bit with Anders and Dave on the bike, finished with Dave.

Stiff-legged shuffle for the first mile, but loosened up eventually. Bumped into Finan and Petersen in the bird sanctuary, so I turned around and ran with them. Had a good conversation, and decided Finan should have gone to Gustavus. Some kid told us (JP) that he liked our underwear. ....Close. We also hashed out a pretty imperative need to get Finan into the dating world. And I quote, 'Running on the track at the U yesterday [running super fast repeats], with all these cute girls around, I'm just awkward. Seriously, when they'd smile at me, my first instinct is to just look away.'

With John, and Finan ran with for the first 4 miles. 8x100m at the end at '94% effort' which just means all out, without letting myself believe it's all out. Legs felt pretty unresponsive the last 2. Nice day out, though!

Slow slow. Was planning to go further, but I had a tightness in the center of my left hamstring that wouldn't let go. So I traded my strides for foam rolling. Perhaps I can go 3 for 3 with being injured for the TC mile? Hope so. Man, it's so nice out, really sucked to bag this one.

TC 1 mile was cancelled, so Anders and I did an easy boardwalk loop. Started raining as soon as we stepped on my porch. Hamstring was still sore, but better than yesterday. Hopefully one more easy day and I'll be back on track to calculatedly massacre my legs again. This week is shot for mileage, but whatever. Gotta start getting on my Grandma's grind.

Just another short, easy run. Trying to stay cautious. Hamstring seems to be coming along. Still pretty sore, and a little tight, but generally better. MIACs tonight!!

Observed on this run: An old man (75?) with a white beard, riding a NiceRide bicycle wearing purple nylons, a solar system print tutu, and a monster energy drink helmet.

Lovely day out, and I figured I'd knock out the long run today so it was off my plate. A bit apprehensive since my hamstring had been giving me trouble, but we were all systems go. Fairly early so I could get to St. Olaf to watch Marit's 5k, but John ran the first 5.5 with me, so it wasn't bad at all. Not enough sleep last night, but it didn't seem to affect my energy levels. At 8 miles (West River) I picked the pace up - figuring I was 7 miles from the Midtown Transit Station - and decided I'd do 7 miles of sub-LT effort. Ended up going a bit fast, but it felt like second nature. Just cruise-controlling along out there. 

5:21, 5:21, 5:30, 5:31, 5:28, 5:20, 5:17

Then 2 miles easy to finish it out. Feeling good - I don't feel quick, but I feel pretty strong right now.

Then to finish out the day, Marit killed it at Olaf.

Down at Gustavusland. Nice weather, really humid. The overall pace isn't representative at all - I ran the first 3.5 with Marit and Alayna around 8 minute pace, then they ditched me in Kasota to fend for myself. Once they left me out on the road to Ramble On, I started running 6:20's to try to find them again, and I did catch back up. Right after they stopped. At Uhler.

Sort of a crappy week for mileage, but there was a good workout or two, and a few throw away days. All things considered, It's aiiiiiight.

The next 2 or 3 or 5 weeks are going to beat me up a bit, I think, so this is fine.

Easy workout in the rain. Light rain, and a light breeze, but generally pretty nice conditions for a workout. Just had 6x1200 @ threshold (3:55-3:58) with 60 seconds recovery. This afternoon I got a text from Finan that said I shouldn't do them on the track, and that it would be most favorable to do them over rolling hills, so I went to the cemetery, marked off a 0.75 mile stretch from a crack in the pavement to a stick I set in the road, and did them there. The cemetery is awesome for rolling intervals, as the grounds out there are like Griak, and there are a TON of roads/trails to run on. Completely empty, minus the security guard, who looked at me curiously and waved. These were not hard at all, just... less than comfortable. Which is good, because in 5 or 6 weeks, I get to run faster than this, for over 17 times as far. Thinking about that is more uncomfortable than the intervals were.

Went: 3:54, 3:57, 3:56, 3:53, 3:55, 3:55

3 w/u, 3+ c/d

Bird sanctuary, easy morning jog. My right lower back/right hip is still tight - That's been going on for a while now. All is well, though, except for I feel like such and old man. Honestly. I wake up and everything snaps and creaks and I have about the same range of motion as  a mummy. Is this only going to get worse? I need a massage.

A little VE>>AC run. Windy and cold, but not bad training weather. Had some HS kids race me on Harriet, and of course I couldn't just do my own thing and let them go, because I'm a child and I am not mature enough to leave well enough alone. First mile was 7:31, then 6:40, and then miles 3-10 were all 5:52-6:00. Whoops. Felt easy enough though. Should have worn heavier shoes??

On William Berry, I met a fellow at the stoplight who had on a heart rate monitor, iPod armband, hydration belt with two bottles (that I saw), visor, sunglasses... Straight up Lifetime Fitness poster child. He asked how far I was going, I told him 10. He said, 'Don't you need to hydrate?' I told him I had some water before I left. I didn't know what else to say.

A day in the books.

Creek west with John and Anders. Legs and body felt a bit tired today, which I suppose is to be expected. after some soul-searching I decided against racing tomorrow. Partially because I've done some work over the past few days and don't feel quick, but mostly because my heart just isn't there right now. After considering the distance and time investment, compared with the best possibly outcome, it just isn't worth it to me. Sad that to get a competitive meet these days you have to drive to either La Crosse, Rock Island IL, Naperville IL, Hillsdale MI, or once in a great while Souix Falls SD.

There are 7 guys at LaX between 14:38 and 15:04, so it'd be a good train to ride, but if I fell short, I think I'd be pretty disappointed. So, a few more days of getting stronger, then maybe Kraft.
Sloggin'. Right hip felt a bit off still, I think something is up with my pelvis. No big deal though, I don't think it's hindering anything.

3 mile warmup, played with this ridiculously adorable brown puppy named Cooper, and then did 16x hills at SW. These went better than last time, but I really don't have the power that Anders does. Ran them pretty hard, 3 mile cool down back home to a house with no heat. Typically this wouldn't be an issue in mid-May, but the climate doesn't know what it's doing right now and it's still in the 40's.

I'm going to skip tomorrow's morning run just because my hip and Achilles are both not quite perfect and I'd just assume the heal a little rather than get 4 more miles this week.

Easy boardwalk loop. Did this solo after taking apart everything associated with our furnace, and crash-course learning how to be an electrician for 2.5 hours this afternoon. But hey, it's not 50 degrees in our house anymore.

Felt alright out there, hopefully everything clicks along well tomorrow :)

17 with 10@marathon effort. Great day for it, even though the first 3 miles were into a lightish wind. The only time I actually noticed it was the third mile, where it kind of sucked a little. When I turned by 169 the mile time dropped (I think because I was still giving the same effort that I had been into the wind, so I backed off when I saw the split). Marit biked with me, which was pretty awesome, because as much as I love my own thoughts, or having the same line of the same song on replay in my head for 2 hours, it was awesome having someone else talking to me, even though I couldn't be super chatty back. It also eliminated the fabricated competition I sometimes feel when I'm doing a workout like this with one of the guys. It was just... Casual. I felt like we were out for an afternoon activity together. Good stuff. The pace felt really relaxed - I got a bit of a stomach ache somewhere during mile 8 maybe, but it wasn't bad. Greenway west standard loop, home via the sculpture garden. When I hit the last mile, I was feeling itchy - not sure if it's because I wanted to burn, or I wanted to be done, but either way I picked it up to (but not across) the red line. I was still running relaxed, no pressing, no kicking, no going to the well, I just aired it out a bit. Happy with the workout.

Splits:
5:27, 5:33, 5:31, 5:18, 5:35, 5:23, 5:30, 5:27, 5:28, 4:53 = 

54:05 for 10 miles( 5:24.5 avg pace)
slog with John. hit up the mountain bike trails east of Cedar, and then found a new trail west of Brownie. Felt tired today, which I guess makes sense.

Workout in the cemetery with Anders. 1200's at threshold again, 60 seconds rest. I screwed up on the first one and stopped early momentarily, because I forgot where they finished. Overcast, rainy, but not actually raining? If that makes any sense. 8 repeats this time (bumping up the volume a little), with the goal being 5:15 pace again (3:55) went:

3:51, 3:49, 3:54, 3:50, 3:54, 3:52, 3:55, 3:46

Just coasting along out there. Started to feel a little sick on rep 6, but held together fine. Anders pulled me through the first 6. All in all I'm pretty pleased with this workout. It's not meant to be fast, just strength building, and it felt 'easy'. Cruising. Good stuff.

Easy morning shakeout. Everything actually felt surprisingly good. I felt tired, but not really sore or anything. Didn't sleep too well last night, so getting up for this took some convincing. Anyway, solo jaunt down King's parkway - sort of a lot of people out there today. I would switch sides of the road or adjust my pace to not have to pass/interact with anyone. I still don't understand why I hate seeing people on morning runs so much. I like doing morning runs with people, but man do I hate seeing other people out waling/running/whatever. In the afternoons, it's totally fine, even appreciated. Strange.

Observation: There are SO MANY youngish mom's with toddlers on King's. There's a definite cohort that lives there. The seemingly newer moms were just pouring out of their homes with their running caps and strollers, maybe a dog by their side. I couldn't believe how many there seemed to be. Maybe it's a club. I wouldn't have guessed that area would be starter family homes, but reflecting on it, I think it would be a really good area if you weren't ready to leave the city yet, but wanted some tranquility. I think those houses are expensive though... Also, everybody, and I mean EVERYBODY that lives there drives a late model minivan, audi, or volvo. Period. every single one. There was maybe a stray prius or two that ventured too far from uptown. Anyway, I'm digressing. Good run. 8 + minute pace for the first 2 miles. Love it.

For about a half mile, I got to run under a long row of blossoming crab apple trees. So awesome. Legs felt a little tired, but not bad. 78 degrees, this is the first run this year that I finished glistening!

Morning frolic with Finan. Spent the first few miles talking about the girls that tried to pour out of the stands at Oxy to come meet him, but the security wouldn't let them onto the track. Then he started getting fb friend requests, and now ...Emily? is trying to move here from LA to be his bride. Then we segued into prospective dates for Greeno and Nicole to get married. Good, senseless banter to get through a morning run.

Man I did not feel like running again, even though it was perfect outside. So I ran as slowly as I could, and did a little of everything. Kings, Bird sanctuary, Harriet, Creek, neighborhoods, Bryant. I felt a little out of sorts today. Tired, a bit.

Probably the easiest workout I've done, at least it should have been if I didn't feel completely out of it. Anders and I went to StLP and had a warmup, some strides, 8x100 with the last 50 being all-out, 5 minutes, 2x1mile at marathon pace (went 5:27, 5:26).

It wasn't until the 8th 100 that Anders realized we'd started the workout. Some mis-communication, but it's still embarrassing that 7 times I had been running as fast as I could, and he legitimately didn't realize we'd started the workout.

I wore flats, because my Achilles has been progressively more annoying. I'll start taking care of it. Anyway, great weather, and not much of a workout. We kind of just played on the track.

Knocked this one out so I wouldn't have to do it over the weekend. Easy breezy 18, though from 14 to 16 my achilles/hip/life was hurting. Anders ran to my house, and we ran bird sanctuary, up to cedar, to the tempo loop backward, dropping him of at my mile 13/14 and then I ran home. Had to add on a little, which was a sad realization, but it worked out. I had a healthy breakfast, but then forgot to eat any sort of lunch, and when I got home Andes was at my house - I ate two packs of Jelly Belly sport beans and a banana power bar (why I had that flavor, I don't know) and went about my jogging. Felt alright, actually. Really warm out there, was pretty gross when I got home.

The run went by pretty quickly.
Easy single today. Trying to get this calf/Achilles thing in check.

Isles jaunt with Finan. Short and easy to make sure my calf/achilles continues to track properly. On the north end we saw who, if there is a good and just God, will one day be mother to Eric's children. I suspect it will happen. When we got back to Calhoun we got dusted by a woman who was going... 6:45's? We sat back for a while while she gapped up and I thought back to the darkest day of my past, 8/5/2013, the only other time someone ran past me and I didn't get them back. So, I was immature again, downshifted to 5:50's and went back past her, turned off the trail and went home. Saw John heading out on Isles while we were coming home - he yelled at me for wearing short shorts, I yelled at him for being on the bike path.

In unrelated news, I was 17th in the 5k. Which is gun timing because it's a championship race. I know this, and i agree with it. That said, by chip timing, I was 16th, and I beat Marotz ;) is that polishing a turd? Sure. But I have to say I beat Jake when I can, even if I didn't actually beat him.

Hot. Harriet to the creek to Chicago and home to a delicious meal of wild rice, chicken, golden raisins, cilantro, chives, and probably a bunch of other stuff in a garlic curry sauce. Whatcha think of that Finan? Yes, Marit made me dinner :)

After the 6AA section meet at Wayzata. Alayna ran well, heck, I was pretty darn impressed with a lot of the performances today. Started from Marit's house with Marit on roller skis and Anders. A little apprehensive getting started, because my achillies insists on sucking right now, but things were alright once we got moving. Did sort of some unstructured speed: Mile, 60 seconds, Mile, half mile jog w/bathroom break, another mile... 5:20, 5:18, 5:17. The first two miles were just floating (a bit fast considering I had squishy Pegasus's on) but the last 2 minutes of the last mile felt tiring. As soon as we finished the last mile, maybe a second after, I took off sprinting because the rule is I can do that any time I want and Anders has to catch me. I could tell he wouldn't be interested in it, so I did it. It wasn't fun for me either, though. Achillies was a bit sore on the cool down, but feels fine as I type this. Marit has really good technique - even though this was one of her first times out this year. And she could single-stick as fast as we could run. So there's that.

Pizza after :)

In all, a pretty good day.

Back in Hastings - I ran from my Grandma's house, because I told her I'd do some yard work/clear her 'to-do' list as long as I was in town. While I was out running, she completely detailed my car, so there's that. I almost didn't get out for the run, because she kept telling me that it was too hot, so I promised her I'd be back before Jeopardy was over, which I of course had no intention of doing. Didn't know where to go, so I just hodge-podged around. Actually pretty awesome. I forget how many cool places there are to run in Hastings. I took the Vermillion River Trail across the falls, through cow town, over to Lake Rebecca, Along the river to the lock and dam, across the dike (which was great - a nice cross wind coming off the water), and back via Pleasant. 

Only a thousand or so degrees, but I can't complain. Achillies was alright. Contemplated whether or not it'd be possible to survive a jump over the wood bridge across the falls. I doubt it, but I'd be willing to try.

Something of a botched workout. Hot and humid, and I'm not used to that yet. 3+ mile warmup, 3 laps of harriet, and home. Was shooting for 8 miles of 5:35, but I cut it at 7 because I was getting chills and had to work too hard to hold the pace I was at. Split 5:19, 5:28, 5:35, 5:31, 5:31, 5:40, 5:35 for the fast portion, and then my Achillies bugged me a little on the CD. Probably taking tomorrow off? I dunno. Hard to complain about how the spring has gone so far, I just need to get to the starting line in 3 weeks feeling good.

A bit hard to breathe today. Only encouragement on the bike bath today, and one older man biked along side me and talked for a while. Kinda nice. I also had a... 3 year old? Tell me I had cool shoes :)
Painful run with John around Isles
With Anders. Saw Folske today and I think it helped. Pretty pain free for the first 5 miles, but of course I pushed it a bit too far. oh well.

Encouraging run. My achillies was more sore today than previously, but higher up (which is way better). I almost didn't run, but thought it may be sore from Folske's bug zapper machine, and the soreness progressively subsided toward the end. Was never perfect, but  there was no inferior achillie's pain! Perhaps that man and his witchcraft will work once again... I know the electricity can make stuff pretty sore, so I'm hoping it's that. I'll see him again tomorrow, and Monday, and hopefully that does it. Finsihed the run with one stride. I feel a little less spunky, but aerobically fit. Give me one more big, good, encouraging workout. and one small sharpening one, and I'm ready for Gma's still.

Then I got to have dinner with Marit and her family, and FINAN BROKE 4 IN THE MILE AND HELD OFF LEO MANZANO!!!! 3:58.7!!!!!! So excited for him. I think I consider Finan the best friend I have that I haven't seen naked, so I'm pretty stoked for him. Makes sense. 

What his race today taught me is that winter training doesn't matter. Dude didn't even exercise. 

Feeling motivated :)
Wirth w/JL. Sore.
Calhoun Solo. Really painful. would have pulled the plug at 2 but... Come on.

Luce Line with Marit riding along side me. Regardless of anything else, it's hard to be unhappy when I get to do workouts with her. I did 4 easy miles, and the pain didn't seem to get any worse, so I picked it up to sub-LT for 6. 5:30, 5:34, 5:31, 5:39, 5:27, 5:33.

Those miles weren't easy, but they weren't terrible. I was feeling a bit hot, but I really wanted to at least do SOMETHING at HM pace, so after those 6 miles, I jogged one, than ran 5:08, 75 seconds rest, and then another at the same effort (my watch said 5:28, but I just don't think that's possible. 5:15 maybe). 

Running on the Luce Line was good for my legs. The downside was that the crushed rock wasn't giving me my whole purchase for the HM miles, but I don't care about that.

I was able to bike along with Alayna and Marit after my run for their run. I enjoyed that.

I decided I'm just going to do what I can until Grandma's, do what I can at Grandma's, and go from there. I can't complain with the spring I've had. Life is good.

Felt alright today - a few miles sucked, but I actually had a few stretches where I didn't notice it. I had literally one hour to get a run in today, and I did with it what I could. I have no idea what I'm doing this week or next, but I'm guessing 1-3 more workouts, hope I don't break, then do the 3 day taper. It's a hail mary, and I'm not in the shape I want to be in, but like world-renown exercise physiologist, Regina Spektor always said: 

This is how it works:
You're young until you're not
You love until you don't
You try until you can't

So try I shall :)

Boardwalk solo. Didn't have any pain from mile 1-6. Then it came on, but was fairly dull. Heading up to Wirth a man biked along side me and asked what I ate to stay so skinny. I told him what I'd had in the last 24 hours, and he said, 'That doesn't sound like a diet at all.' Duh. He then told me about how hard he used to work as a concrete layer, and how kids today don't want to work hard, etc. etc.

Went in the morning so I could have my evening off. I had some Achilles pain during the warmup, but wanted to go ahead with the workout anyway. 6x1mile at threshold pace, and was hoping that would be 5:15-5:20. 

5:06, 5:23, 5:13, 5:28, 5:17, 5:27

#'s 1,3, and 5 were with the wind, 2, 4, and 6 were against it.

Opened a bit quick, but hit the brakes after that. I felt pretty aerobically unfit, but I had no pain from the start of the workout to the end of the cool down. I really hope it's 20 degrees cooler than this at Grandma's. I don't like running fast in the heat.

'Morning' run, at like... 9? Because I'm too much a pile of crap to get out of bed early, and then of course when I did, I wanted to have coffee and reflect on life a bit first. Anyway, easy jog down to the creek. I was surprised that I didn't see the fleet of stroller-pushing young mothers down Kings, but on my way home, right at Kings and 48th, there was a brigade (3) of them, in formation (literally, mighty ducks style), with their jogging strollers, quarter-zip long sleeves, visors, and 3/4 length yoga pants. Balance has been restored to the universe. 

Achilles hurt fairly consistently throughout, but it was bearable. I guess I probably beat it up a bit yesterday.

Last longish, fastish thing before next weekend. Didn't feel great, and I didn't feel terrible. I felt sick - you think by now I'd know that I can't eat close to running, but I did anyway. warmed up, did 9 miles kinda fast, cooled down, watched a bike race. You know what, today was good all the way through.

5:44, 5:58, 5:36, 5:37, 5:41, 5:33, 5:35, 5:35, 5:41

Back in Hastings with Marit. Started by the Vermillion Falls, around CP, to the River, and back via Pine. Exactly what I was looking for today pace wise, 7:30+. Followed it up with a stop at the bakery, mom's house, and the dairy store. Even though my donut tasted like gasoline, was this a perfect day? Yeah. I think so. The rain held off for the most part,   and my legs felt pretty good. No Achilles pain to speak of.

:)

Zero percent of me was motivated to go today. I forced myself out to the sidewalk, figuring after a few minutes I'd come around. It never did. The only cool part is that there was some sort of huge party going on in the parking lot of the Flux apartments, and I finished down the Greenway to blasting 'Turn Down for What?' by Lil John. Kinda uplifting, although I would never choose to listen to that 'song'. You don't get to make up a phrase that literally means nothing - completely invented - repeat it 50 times over some computer-generated electronic rhythm, And make a million dollars off it. All told, there are 12 words in that song. Disgraceful.
Favorite day Mondays. Felt tired. I'm still not sleeping well at all :(

Down to SW, standard 4x800 tune up workout. Best workout idea? I dunno. But like a wise man once said, 'You gotta dance with who brought you', and this has been the race week workout for years now.

Hot, humid, and I haven't been on a track forever. That was a slap in the face - no top end, no gears to shift to, nothing. Heaviness, perhaps. 2:19, 2:33, 2:33, 2:19

I looked back in my log to see the last time I was this slow in this workout - it was 2012 before the TC marathon. Since then it's been 2:15/pace/pace/2:15, and last year I did a few 200's after 'just for fun'.

But, we're on the runway now. Time to rest up and give it what I have. Funny how one race can seem so significant, when really, no one run/race/workout/anything matters. Trial of Miles (Bill, not Tim).

Dupont jog. There was a little brown puppy around 43rd, and he decided to run with me (and by with, I mean directly in front of, jumping at my legs every step making me feel like I was going to step on him - occasionally I did). After running 2 or 3 blocks with him, I figured I should check his collar, but it didn't have any tags. I ran back with him to where we first met, and I waited for him to get bored and run off. Hope he finds his way. My stomach hurt for this run, but the rest of it was alright. I also saw a dog with two back wheels... His legs were casted and on top of the axel of the wheels. Interesting stuff.
in the rain with Anders. Felt alright, strides after went well too.

Easy pre-race from the Olson's in Hermantown with Marit. Everything feels about as good as it can, and so far today has been just about perfect, beside being humped by Ole, that mammoth. I ran my last run as laps around a garden - about 20 laps - because I didn't feel like an out and back.

Two strides, game time.

The first mile was really rough, but then I loosened up and things started to click. Normally after big races, either I'm tired of the training grind and I have to fight back to caring about the sport, or the fire is hot to get back to training. Luckily, today was the latter. I started thinking about the fall, and my racing plans, which are kind of up in the air. On one hand, Chicago would be really cool, but also really expensive, there'd be travel involved, etc. 

I don't want to run TC again, just because Summit is so, so, so awful. That said, after the race I wouldn't have to travel anywhere, the fan support is fantastic, and I'd like to think I could be top 25 or better overall on a good day. I didn't have a spectacular race in 2012 and I was 36th. I feel like I should be able to better that mark. 

In any case, Summer training is finally here, no races on the horizon to worry about being ready for, and all the time in the world to just train and get strong. I'm feeling really, really excited. I'm going to also do some strength/core work at least 3 times/week to start, and I'll log it on here for accountability.

Trials of miles. I'm sure I'll miss racing, but right now, I just want to run :)

Legs felt good, but the rest of me still felt out of sorts. Hips were sore, my tummy was sloshy (even though I didn't drink anything pre run?) I also accidentally dropped a 5:52 out there because I didn't want to be around people and I felt crowded. Great weather out there, though. Strength + Core after. I gave a lot of thought today to my fall racing plans.

66.
Easy morning scamper in the bird sanctuary with Little Kate.

I learned today that I can't run with people roller skiing. Marit, Me, Alayna, Scott, Josh, Haley, and another guy went to Elm Creek and I attempted to run while they skied. After our first two miles were 6:15, 5:52, I realized that wouldn't be happening, so I ran the 8 mile loop solo and then added on a bit. Other than really feeling like I'm not training enough, all was well. A good change of scenery.

65.
Morning run with Hartman. Every part of me is tired.
Over in Plymouth with Marit. Legs felt much better than this morning, but it was awfully humid still.

Awful, awful run. Creek to GW east. The first mile I felt tired and heavy, but I figured it'd go away as I loosened up. Never happened - and I wanted to turn and go home every step from mile 2 on. Additionally, it was hot, and super, super humid. I was soaked. Stopped for water every chance I had, and when I stopped at the falls, I seriously contemplated whether I'd be able to make it home. Not seeing any other options, I trucked over to the river, and started to head north. When I finally hit Bryant and saw mile 15, I stopped and walked home. Yuck. 

This run had 2 paces: 7:40 and 6:35. Slow because I was dying, then fast at the end because I was so desperate to get home. Achilles hurt because My form went to shit. Oh well. Time to recover.

Marit and I ran up around the Wirth area. I felt magnitudes better than yesterday, even though my achilles was sore for the first 2 miles. Pretty hot out again, but lower humidity and a breeze helped. Binged on Guacamole and then spent a chunk of the afternoon in a hammock enjoying the shit out of summer. Tomorrow is going to be a characteristically awful monday, but what an awesome weekend.
Really slow and awful for 2 miles, but then it got better. I felt pretty dizzy the whole time, too. Strides felt ok afterward, but I'm missing a few gears. Down day after a few bigger ones.
The first mile my Achilles hurt, but this was the best a morning run has felt in a long time. I need some new flows. 65 degrees and breezy. Loved it.
With Anders. Felt good again, other than some achilles problems around mile 8. Cool, windy, nice evening.
Morning jaunt hodge-podging around the northwest neighborhoods with John. Felt really good!

Ran Franklin Ford standard plus a little loop in Minnehaha with Marit :) I had such weird stomach pains during this run. I'm borderline considering a hysterectomy, but I think it's just because I took iron this morning. That always throws me for a few days. Absolutely gorgeous out, 73, dry, light breeze and bright blue skies. I had to stop and walk a few times, and I felt pretty awful about doing that, but it's just one day. Legs and lungs felt good. I miss a lot of the routes over there. I'm dying for some pike island/lake snelling/Hidden falls running. Right now I'd need a life jacket and a kayak for that, though.

So, so, so unmotivated to get out the door for this. I just felt lazy. Not awful after a few miles, but the achilles was sore getting going, and my. goodness. there was something wrong with me. Around mile 2 I started to feel the same abdominal pain/pressure I felt yesterday, and then the flood gates opened. I bet I stopped to pee 6 times, and every time my bladder was legitimately full. I bet I lost 5% of my body weight today. I had no idea I was retaining so much water, and no idea where I was keeping it all. That solved the bloated feeling I've had the past few days, and I felt much lighter and less... puffy the last 5 or so miles. I don't know why a body would retain so much fluid for s long, and then just purge all at once, unless someone slipped me some Furosemide? Anders? Is this a joke to you?

Anyway, finished feeling good, floated a few strides and they felt reasonable as well. I have only done core/lifting once this week, so I'm going to have to sneak two more days in, but it'll happen.
morning stumble. Felt alright, but man were the lakes packed.

Ran over to Anders' house, picked up anders and dave, and ran back to mine. Sub 7's out, slower on the way back, but was thoroughly occupied by Dave's story, which took all five miles. 92 miles in the last 7 days. Getting back to respectable training, but I feel it, and man I feel tired. I just want to lay in bed. Not sure how 110's will happen routinely (or if they will again :/ ) but you can't fake marathon training. Felt alright, overall. I think I was dehydrated, because I could see striations in my quads when I finished, and I'm too fat for that to be normal.
Didn't really have a choice but to run in the middle of the day today, so it was hot. Down to the creek again - no part of me felt bad during this run, I just feel tired.

Up before 7 to get this done prior to it getting too scorching. Even though it was only in the 70's, the humidity was ruthless and John and I were soaked by mile 4 or 5. Felt pretty tired out there, but I have to imagine I'm getting stronger. Ran John's long run with him and then added on, during which time I ran through standing water and soaked my feet. Maybe a bit ambitious today for where I'm at, but in the unfortunately immortal words of Shane Patton, 'Anything worth doing is worth overdoing. Moderation is for cowards.'

Addendum: I was so antsy just sitting around all day that I lifted/did core pretty much to exhaustion. So begins my 30 day 'try to actually be an athlete' challenge.
Morning run with John. Really heavy starting out, but it got better as the miles went on. On to my favorite day!

First workout of the cycle - the warmup ended being about 4.5 miles because first I went to the cemetery, and that was busy, then CLBT but the wind was too much, so I finally tucked in back in the kennilworth trail (still somehow windy half the time back there) and who did I overlap with but John, doing his workout and partially the same stretch. 5x threshold 1200's with 1 minute recovery. looking for 3:55-4:00

3:48, 3:56, 3:53, 3:55, 3:55

Opened too fast, but I have no feel for pace right now. Hit the brakes and settled, and then all was well. Achilles was mostly well behaved.

Just a guess on time because I turned my watch off. Marit biked over and we did an easy 6 together. Not super hot out, but I took iron in the morning and consequently my stomach went to knots by the end. Wont be doing that again.
Morning run around Calhoun. Legs actually felt alright. Cool out, wore my shirt the whole time.

CLBT to the river and back via 2nd/Loring park. Ran with Mar, and then grilled so much food afterward :) legs are pretty beat, and I had a calf cramp (?) that is still lingering, but I feel like I'm training finally (read: hating the physical aspects of my life.)

96 in the last 7. one more little push! ...And then hang on for 3 months.

really, really slow starting out. maybe 8:30 first mile because the knot in my calf was pretty tight, but it got a little better by the end. Ran laps around the Rose Garden because I didn't want to pound pavement with my leg in its current state. I saw some orange cones out in the grass, but didn't know what they were for, and wasn't paying attention until I heard someone count down from 5 and all of a sudden a bunch of high schoolers came out from behind some trees apparently running an interval. They were running the same exact pace I was, so I awkwardly ran in the middle of their group, in silence, until I got to the end of the park where they turned and I went home.

Ran over to Run n Fun on Calhoun because Perry asked me to lead a Lifetime fitness group run. That's the last time I do that. Every stereotype about Lifetime runners is true. First of all, a bunch of them showed up. A whole freak flapping flock of 'em. They all had on visors, oversized tri half tights, arm bands with huge phones/music players, and at least one guy was wearing a water belt. I sat quietly in my corner in my short shorts while they all tried on wear-test asics (which were all 4mm heel-toe drop, and they ate that right up.) They sat around talking about trail ultras and how one particularly tan guy there ran 'a marathon every week' (meaning he routinely ran 26 miles/week, not the race) and how he must burn through trainers. 

Then some dude from some rehab place by Run n Fun came over and asked if anyone wanted to try out the cryo chamber. Look it up. Anyway, it's a cool machine, but I see no benefit to using it pre run. The rep for the rehab place said that he 'guarantees that if you use the chamber pre-run, it will take 15% long to fatigue during the run' ...I'd like to see the research on that.

BUT, the group ate it up, and they all had to go do it. so the 6pm start time became 6:45, while I sat around and they binged on their gimmicks. Lifetime. No thanks. Those guys are about as serious about running as Dan Greeno is about maintaining a heterosexual image in public.

So we finally start, and they all want to run 10+ minute pace. Except one guy. Maybe a few years older than me. He takes off like a rabbit. I follow curiously, and ask him his story. Former UST student, runs 3-4 times per week when he's 'training seriously' but he's cruising. He didn't run in college, but ran a marathon 7 years ago in 3:58. He kept ratcheting it down, and I felt aerobically fine, so I just shadowed him. we went 6:46, 6:20, 6:05, 6:03, 6:08, 6:05, 6:11, 6:21 and then he pulled the plug. I was actually pretty impressed. He got to be breathing pretty hard by the end and I put in a few slow surges to see if he'd respond, but he really didn't. I never tried to roll him, it was just curiosity, and I felt like playing. 

Faster than I planned to run today, and my right lateral gastruc was still really sore, but I can feel the adhesions with light palpitations and it's in the muscle, so I'm not worried. Onward and upward.

Well, I'm taking the day off. I skipped the morning run hoping my calf would resolve, but When I started running today it was still really, really sore. I went a half mile with no improvement (though the pain was not sharp, and could have been run through), it seems like a silly time of year to risk it. It's not like today was even anything special, but this just makes certain that I won't hit 100 miles this week. Even though coming into 2014, I had one goal - to train intelligently, and not focus on the number - it's hard putting that into practice. I know a day off won't kill me, but it's crazy how weak, soft, and lazy it makes me feel.

It's only one day, it's only one day, it's only one day.

Not sure whose legs I was running on today, but the weren't mine. I felt gross. Right calf was 'good' using that term loosely, if not an all-out lie until about mile 7. But at 7 I was somewhere just north of Diamond lake road and had to get home. Raining, and what was possibly the most irritating about this run was that the pavement was wet and my shoes would slip each time I pushed off.
Still sidelined. Struggling :(
Calhoun with Mar. I saw Folske today, and it feels better. It wasn't perfect, but it was good enough. Hopefully this can be totally resolved by the end of the week.

18.25 mi. First time on roller skis in... 8 years? Almost? As it turns out, it felt like it, too. I'm not good enough at rollerskiing to get my heart rate up, so all I did was waste two hours, grind down some road tips, and make my elbows sore. The cool part was seeing how nice cyclists can be - they were all awesome about passing, and my being on the trail in general, except one dick who yelled at me to get on the walking path? I told him, politely, that he was wrong.

I really, really, really struggled out there, and I can't V2 to save my life. The balance thing is killer. That said I stayed upright the whole time, despite a few close calls. Luckily, there are still 3.5 years until Pyeongchang.

In Plymouth while Marit biked with me. I felt heavy and uncoordinated, but her mom made some excellent dinner/dessert afterward. And in the 3 hours that I was at her house, her brother probably ate 8,000 calories, and was not eating anything for a combined 11 minutes. I don't know if it's the lifting or what, but that kid is getting big. Gotta flash the biceps for those 9th grade girls!

Pretty stiff this morning, and my biceps are sore. Figured a little jog to loosen up couldn't hurt. I think my first mile was like 8:30ish. It went alright, and I felt better afterward. No calf pain to speak of, though my achilles was it usual self, mildly sucking for the first 5 minutes.

I had the refrain of Spaceman by The Killers on replay in my head the whole time. I'm really on a Killers tear right now, but man, those three lines got really old after a half hour.

The run was fine, but I got hit by a car (just past the alley where I expect to one day die - John, you know the one.) This dude in a black mercedes doing the 'only look one way and don't bother to consider stopping' just blows across the sidewalk in front of the Bank of the Lakes and I got my hand out and onto his hood so I could control my body a bit, but his damn mercedes emblem jabbed me in the hip when I hit his hood, which was less than pleasant. Of course he started yelling something to the effect of watch where you're going and other utterances that clearly voiced his discontent. I just asked him, matter-of-factly, 'So, what part of the sidewalk do you have the right of way over pedestrians?' He punched his dashboard, said something else I didn't hear, and drove off - all this transpiring with a wife and kids in the car. Way to be a role model.
Best worst run of my life? That's all I'll say about that. 7:04, 6:36, 6:17, 5:48, 5:47, 5:35
1 hr skateish ski with Mar and Macho Anders on their bikes, BBB was running with us - turned into a fartlek for him. Felt much more comfortable than last time.

Morning hodge podge around kings, harriet, the rose garden, some neighborhoods... The was a couple on the west side of lake harriet that had set up a table and were giving 'free advice' so I thought, what the heck, stopped and had a talk with them. the first 4 or 5 miles I had some soreness in my soleus, but right in the middle of my calf, between the gastrucs. As dumb as this sounds, that made me excited, because if I have to have problems somewhere in my lower leg, that's exactly where I want it, because you can treat that with eccentrics and a spoon. just stay away from my tendons. hot out today, and tomorrow we're looking for 3 digits :( biked with Marit for her 12 miles later on.

Cedar Creek Loop

Paul Douglas says a heat index of >100 today, so I went early. So did everyone else, as it turns out. As I made my way down the standard morning King's route, the women of South Dupont were out in full force. We're talking battalions of them. It was like some strange post-modernist performance that resembled a mash up of a core power yoga class, Lululemon on Black Friday, and the beaches of Normandy circa 1944. By this point my calf was loose and life was looking up, so I happily navigated the waves of strollers and made my way down to the creek. Maybe 4 miles in, I spied off in the distance some creature tethered to a lady, and in my morning grogginess/heat delusions, I momentarily had an honest notion that is was Falkor the Luck Dragon from The Neverending Story, but once I realized that wasn't possible, my mind immediately went to, 'oh, it must be a sheep'. Equally unlikely, and substantially amusing, I chuckled to myself. When I caught up, I asked her what kind of dog it was (clearly should have been my first assumption). Turns out, it's an Irish Wolfhound. And that's what it looked like. This skinny, long haired, tall wolf-creature that must have jumped in the creek at some point. Today, I would have too if I had a fur coat.

Navigated the rolling hills of the 40th street bikeway, and made it home in one piece. Two days in a row now, I haven't run and thought about how many miles I had left to go; that's a good feeling. My calf still isn't right, but it doesn't hurt, either. I just.... feel my Flexor Hallucis wrapping around from my heel to my lateral gastruc. A few more days like this, and I'll be ready to load it a bit, and see how it handles the stimulus. Came home to a freezing cold glass of tea and a bowl (Yes Marit, the whole container) of Chop Chop salad - perhaps my new favorite salad. 

Today felt good. Starting to feel like a real runner again - it's been a few months, and I must say, it feels pretty darn good :)
Lake Hiawatha. Pain Free!
Easy 3 just so I could try some strides. They went well! I did 4 strides (cautiously) and I didn't notice anything off. Ran into Jack early on, and he kept me company for a half mile or so.

Hard to get out of bed this morning. Around mile 3 I crossed paths with Max Renner, so I turned around and ran with him. I don't think either of us planned to go as far as we did, but I think we both didn't want to be the one to cut out early. So we both ended up going farther than planned. I felt good, except my hamstrings were a bit tired the last 2 miles? I think I probably needed to have eaten a little more in the past 24 hours. I don't really recall having lunch yesterday. Anyway, another good run, and I'll do some sort of training tonight - hard to say what that will look like, though.

Good start to the day!

50 minutes out to watch Torchlight, hung out there with Andrea and Tuesday while watching the race - and when Finan ran by, he held out his camera and took a selfie of the two of us... that kid. I don't get it. Then I went over to the U, down to Franklin, and home on the greenway. Minneapolis is SO awful for this roller skiing thing. I can't do it. Metal plates all over the place, switching from concrete to blacktop and back, and always with that dreaded 3 inch gap between them. I hated just about every second. Paul looked good, and I have to take Anders at his word that he wasn't trying. Paul, if you're reading this, I hope it gets in your head to come out and play in a month :) 

I'll be ready.

Morning run from SE Seward with Marit. Just did the Franklin Lake loop, plus a little, and went down below river road just after Franklin. Had a really good breakfast after at Birchwood cafe :) Pretty terrific morning, really.

No idea how I'm supposed to focus at work now - as such, here I am on r2w.

Ate a peanut butter and granola sandwich, and then Anders showed up at my house. So we went running.

Felt like throwing up the whole time.

Woof. Got some work to do.

Set out for a little workout today, and honestly, I felt like my legs were tired, my head was tired, and I really wanted to just stay in, watch a movie and eat jellybeans. And probably have a beer. But apparently I'm still pursuing this running thing, races are coming onto the horizon, and like Andy Rishavy always says...

So I settled on rolling-hill threshold 1200's in the cemetery. Given the 80 degrees, humidity, and fact that I haven't run 'fast' in over a month, I backed off my goal pace to 5:20's (4:00 per 1200). 60 seconds rest.

Ended up running really inconsistent splits of 4:00, 4:01, 4:05, 4:03, 4:07, 4:06

The good and bad is that I felt like I actually ran threshold today, just sucks that threshold pace is that slow right now. It'll come back. 2 months ago I did 8 of these in 3:46-3:55 all chatty - that has to still be in my legs somewhere :)

Out at Elm creek - Started at 8:30 while Marit and Mata started their ski. They looped back after 14 miles and picked me up. Mata, Marit and I went 5 miles together, then Mata finished, and Marit and I went out to the Coon Rapids dam and back. The run was sluggish, and the ski felt really good for about an hour. Only really awful for the last 15 minutes. 2 hours skate total? If you can call it that. I can't transfer weight to save my life. This whole balance thing.... Pretty tired after, but Marit and I went to Maggies and had breakfast, napped, had pressert at Honey & Mackie's, dinner, movie....

Really, really good day.

With some RnF guys from the Minneapolis store. Everyone pretty much wanted to walk for the first half, but we got moving eventually. Really nice weather, 60's or 70's, overcast and breezy. Felt tight for the first 3 miles, but then loosened up. Jeff Renlund was there, and started talking about Marcus Speca and consequently GAC nordic for the last 3 miles, which in turn resulted in probably 6:30 pace for those three.

Lake Nokomis with Anders. I forgot what time my first meeting was today, and my boss is on the committee that was meeting, so I didn't want to miss it. So, I skipped my morning run. Turned out the meeting wasn't until 10. Oh well. Paid homage to the calendar gods today, and I don't recall the specifics of the conversation, but I think everyone on Kings got an education today. Felt really good today.

Day 1 of the worst 4 is over. Not sure when I'm going to run tomorrow, but I got a lot done at work today, so I think I can figure out a way to get a few miles in.
Woof. My legs were so heavy out there today. And it never really got better during the 'run'. But hey, I covered the distance.

Had to sneak this in between meetings - so I figured since I was in St. Paul, I'd check out Fort Snelling. It was open! Snelling/Pike Island Loop. Gosh it felt good to be back down there. The first 4 miles didn't feel great but then I was able to  click right along. Only saw 2 other people the whole time - such a nice change from the lakes. I love it down there.

It was noticeable that it had been flooded - a few sandy spots on the south side of Pike, and some trees down throughout, but hurdling them brought me right back to my 2009 2nd place finish in the MIAC steeple. Glory days.

Had a few sciatic twinges during the run, but they went away really quickly. I'm sure my legs are just tired. I had a fleeting thought to do some hill repeats on that awful climb below the fort... Nope.
No morning legs today! Maybe last night's strides helped. Felt good though :)

Really torn on how I should be training right now, and for whatever reason it was bugging me this whole run. I feel like I'm doing the run-slighty-too-hard every day and get nowhere plan. Maybe it's just work stressing me out. There are still 9ish weeks left. There's time.

Exactly 90 minutes. Crazy. 

It's amazing how much of a motivator self-loathing can be. I half-heartedly planned to do a workout this morning, but when my alarm went off at 6, I had no legitimate intention of even waking up. Then I hit the weather app on my phone, and saw it was going to be 83 today. 'Just go for an easy run', I told myself. No. eff that.... I closed my eyes. I laid there on the cusp of sleep for a few minutes thinking of how much of a wimp I would be if I skipped running. 'Just sit up and see how it feels'. I sat up, put my feet on the floor and scanned my body for reasons why it'd be best to just take the morning off. I found none. 'Walk downstairs and put on some coffee, you can decide then'. Man, I hated myself. I hated myself for wanting to skip it, for contemplating skipping it, for knowing in my heart of hearts that in a very short time those shoes would be slipping over my feet. I knew how much better my afternoon would be, though, if I just went and did it.
 
I settled on 8 miles @ just slower than threshold. Fast enough that it wasn't fun, slow enough that I could still daydream. I didn't know what that would be, but I was guessing 5:40's. Rolling hills for most of the way.

3 mile w/u, 3 mile c/d

5:31, 5:41, 5:41, 5:37, 5:39, 5:34, 5:41, 5:36 = 45:00 for 8 miles

Parish came up on me on his bike mid-workout, and we chatted for a bit. He's in a tough place right now, but it'll get better. It was reassuring that I could converse at that pace.

'You can remember it, but you can never experience it like this again'

Grindin' on.
Shortest lap of Calhoun. Got high-fived by some random guy, and missed being locked out of our house by about 30 seconds.
Morning run up at Marit's cabin! Went a little over 6 with her, then added on. Got attacked by flies, but otherwise felt pretty good. Nice weather, rolling hills.

With Marit after sitting on the lake all day, and deciding swimming across a bay wasn't the worst idea. Body felt tired, but everything felt alright. Really good dinner after, and too many gummy worms.

Early morning run before Howling Moon Music Festival. Got up, had some coffee, ran 4 solo, then picked up Marit and did a 14 mile loop from her cabin with her. Tired, but I got my hills in for the week, and a 110+ rolling 7! Really nice to have company, and different scenery than the cities. Done for the day and finished the run with coffee and donuts :) 

Fueling like a champion. Great weekend.

Hodgepodge with John. Jaunted around the St. Louis Park neighborhoods until we wound up at Benilde, then crossed 7 to the greenway and home. My stomach was upset, my legs were tired, but nothing hurt. First Monday-to-Sunday-legal 100+ week in probably close to a year. Good to be back? I guess?

John had some wisdom about breaking rocks, and it sounds like his trip was fun. West Coast bound  in 15 hours. Running isn't going to be my focus the next week, and that's fine by me.

Felt pretty good! John got up at 6 with me to run this before flying out west! Super excited. The run went by quickly and John and I had some good conversation about a lot of things out there. Why do we run? 'I dunno, really. To put off being old I guess. You grind until you can't anymore.'

First morning run on vacation! Started below the Golden Gate Bridge with Marit, and ran along some trails in a general out and back for the first few miles. Really pretty, but also like an uphill beach in places. Then we went across the bridge and back, which was cool, but really scary to look either up or down. The vertical beams of the bridge went into the low-hanging clouds. Added on two miles solo, and 6 strides after. Felt good! Had the best meal I've probably ever had at a restaurant last night. To anyone going to San Francisco: Pacific Catch at Golden Gate Park.

Not really sure of the distance on this one. After a charming stay in Garberville (and learning that the awesome hippy chicks from Cafe Aquatica were returning Mar's iPad) we parked just off the road somewhere in the Miranda Redwoods State Park, and got on a single track trail. Lots of weaving through some pretty cool trees, and then when it popped back out to the road we sort of just explored. A bit on the roads, a bit on some more trails, then I added on 3 or 4 miles solo. Felt really smooth and ran a bit fast at the end. Followed this up with a nature hike at Trillium Falls, I fell off a tree that I was climbing down from (full yard sale, in the words of John), ate tons of wild blackberries with Marit, and contemplated the lives of bears. Slow, but gorgeous drive from San Francisco to the Redwoods on Highway 1.

From our hotel in Grant's Pass. Lots of hills out here - Marit and I ran together for the first 5ish miles, then I did a light workout to just stay in the routine of things. 3xmile at threshold pace with 60sec. recovery. Ended up being 5:13, 6:06, 6:03 (see: hills). Cooled down with Marit as she finished her run, and then Headed to Crater Lake for some incredible views and cool hikes, followed closely by quite a bit of soreness :)

After a day of hiking at Crater Lake with Marit, we decided that sleeping in, making blackberry pancakes in our little cottage (actually, she made them for us), and getting on the road wasn't the worst idea. So we did that, and drove to Eugene for our run. Did this run mostly on Pre's trails, with an out and back in the middle to pay homage to Pre's rock. Lots of hill climbing once we left the trails, but I suppose I should have expected that. Seeing where Pre died helped shed some light on why it happened. driving drunk, at night on those tiny, twisty, hilly roads would be suicide. There's no way you'd see a car coming from the other direction. The trails were cool, a really nice surface, but they kind of just went through a flat open field for a lot of the way. Parts were cool, but it mostly felt like running through a fairground. My GI tract was pretty upset during this run, and Mar wan't feeling great after either. The coffee? Anyway, cool to say I've run there now. Strides after.

PORTLAND! After a super fun night - probably the most memorable of the trip - and a whole pizza/app/cake/ice cream, this run felt really good. We started just walking for a few blocks while looking for some parkway that I'd read about. We never found it so we just started running, and less than a quarter mile in, we found ourselves in the middle of a farmers market that was probably 4 blocks long, both sides of the road, and had live music and food vendors. We ended up cutting down to the river and running along that until we got back to our car. We then walked back to the farmers market for really yummy peaches, coffee, and breakfast bagel sandwiches. It was sunny, 70 or so, and perfect out. I had a lot of fun in this city, and I think Mar did too. Definitely had a Minneapolis vibe to it. Superficially, we have more places to run, but it also seemed like they had fewer lululemon joggers. I think we'll be back :)

From our B&B in Seattle. Felt a little sad that the trip was coming to an end, and wasn't motivated to spend more time running than I had to. Ran down the hill from Queen Anne and back with Marit, and then had breakfast on our porch. Last night, and again this morning we walked around Pike Island Market, which was cool, but a confusing layout - as it turns out, I have no spatial representation abilities. Luckily Marit has that part figured out and we managed just fine. Lots of good seafood last night overlooking the Sound, and a cool sunset over the mountains. What a week.

You can skip runs, but not miles. First 6 with John, then solo. Had a great down week, and though this wasn't exactly springy, I feel ready to get back into it. Did a handful of half-hearted strides after - just enough to realize I am not fast right now. Missing vacation life.

Solo run, because I can't seem to get my sleep pattern back under control. I didn't hear John knock on my door this morning to get up for morning run. Oh well. Right IT was a little tight for the first mile, but felt really smooth after that. Good run! Workout later :)

Well, that was tough. Ran down to SW, only to find a girls' soccer scrimmage going on. I only brought spikes, so I ran home and got flats, then up to the greenway. So after an unplanned 7 mile warmup, I got going. I wanted to do 16x400 w/90 seconds recovery at 70 or under, but my legs were tired when I started it, and I kind of just checked out when it got hard, which was by rep #3. I ended up jogging home, humbled, after only 8.

71, 68, 70, 70, 72, 71, 74, 72

Just not my day. I'll get there.
Another really good run! After yesterday, I was prepared for this to be a death march, but I felt pretty strong!

SLP/Bass lake loop with Marit. I was really hungry at the start of this, and felt kinda flat during, but I'm sure they go hand in hand. Afterward, we made a really tasty caprese pizza and some onion/pepper/tomato salad, but I didn't get to eat as much as I'd hoped because i got full really quickly. Probably didn't help that I was snacking on chips and salsa and tomatoes the entire time we were cooking. 

So, I feel good and heavy now. Good day!
Just a morning shakeout. Felt ok.
Late morning run with John, feeling pretty darn crappy. Made it 10, somehow. Stomach was still really messed up when I woke up - I didn't really sleep last night. Half day of work.

So this was a trip... My phone somehow reverted back two hours...? I was planning to get up at 7, got up at 6:53 (actually 8:53) and realized I missed Marit's race :( I threw on some shorts, jumped in my car, and got there in time for awards. Then I was standing on the side of the course for the men's start, and 2 minutes to the gun, Bill Miles walked over to me and asked what my excuse was. I told him I just woke up, my alarm didn't go off, and I hadn't warmed up, brought racing stuff, etc... He said, 'Sounds like a poor excuse, jump in!' Then Anders ran off the line and told me to 'learn how to not be a bitch' and that he brought extra flats. I said I couldn't, said it was a bad idea, and then said screw it. I sprinted to his warmups and tied on his flats (a half size too big?) threw off my shirt, my hat, and stepped on the line. I asked Anders and Josh how long the race was - two miles - and how I should run it. Anders said go out fast. So Literally one minute from putting on the shoes to the gun. No warmup. The gun went off and I went out pretty hard, maybe 72 through the quarter. I was in 8th-10th going into the woods, and around a mile 3 varsity kids went by. I didn't get passed up suicide hill, gave it what I had from 800 out, and finished 13th. Not bad, considering the circumstances. This was awful, and fun at the same time. I think I was 6th of Alumni? I ran 10:55 (course record prior to today was 10:18) and I'm not exactly fresh. I like to think with a proper warmup I could move up a bit, but I'll have another shot in two weeks. With my own shoes this time :) Marit was 3rd in her race, and Alayna won. Then Bill Miles sent me TWO Facebook messages. Pretty cool day :) cooled down 4ish with Anders and Jeremy Drenckhahn.

Well, time to stop being a wimp. Right before I went out, John said, 'Are you seriously going 20?' when I said yeah, he replied, 'Well, be optimistic. Think, you could drive to duluth by the time you'll be done.'

Encouraging?

So, It wasn't super hot, but it was humid, and then it rained for the middle 14 miles.
