I was going to do the standard progression, but after a pretty drastic jump in the frequency of quality days this week, I thought just sustaining would be good enough if I didn't feel like racing at the end - and I suspected I wouldn't. 

went:

7:12, 7:04, 7:05, 6:48, 6:31,
5:50, 5:40, 5:42, 5:43, 5:29,
5:40, 5:43, 5:30, 5:40, 5:41,
5:44, 5:35, and then a few easy to cool down. 5:39.xx average for 12 miles. 2:28 marathon pace, but I have work to do.

Ran most of this on the TC course (creek to the west river, north to franklin, across to east river, down to LSB, back to West River, and north to the greenway) and got a stark reminder that there is really nothing truly flat on that course. 

Felt comfortable for most of it, but by the last 2 or three I wasn't too happy anymore. Dehydrated, soaked, and my shoes were filled with water. I took a gel at mile 13, and that helped, but I still was pretty dizzy by the end. I felt mentally tired today. I had a great weekend, but I still felt sort of purposeless out there.

Finan made me get up at 6 to run with him this morning. Luckily I believe in coffee, and coffee believes in my ability to be a morning person. Had some good conversation, and it distracted me from the tiredness of my legs. Happy to see that kid on the porch again.

Ran this one with Joe, and felt surprisingly alright. Had a lot of drawn out discussions about stuff, the first 5 or 6 miles being the Gustavus training program. Sounds like there's a lot of quiet frustration among the current runners, and honestly, rightfully so. You can't do the same thing that hasn't worked the last 6 years and expect that it'll magically work for this crop of runners. Period. Is it going to take another decade of being 8th and 4th?

Then we got into med school, post college training, life, love, and the pursuit-of-we-aren't-sure-what.

Good to run with Joey again.

Started reeeeeeeally slow, and just progressed as my body felt like it. I'm solidly back into the place where everything is sore, all the time. Cumulative fatigue; I really love/hate marathon training.

Heavy legs today, and the humidity wasn't helping. I also felt... swollen? Like I was sting too much water or something. Anyway, 7x rolling 1200 @ threshold in the cemetery. I was only going to do 6, but then I thought, hey, one more sounds fun. But I backed off during it because I started to feel sick.

I was shooting for 3:55, because that's the number that was in my head without really thinking about it. Ended up running them all between 5:05 and 5:20 pace, and looking back - threshold pace being what you could reasonably sustain for 50-60 minutes, I should have run them all around the upper range of that. I couldn't do 5:05's for an hour.

Survived, anyway.

3:49, 3:53, 3:57, 3:54, 3:54, 3:59, 4:00

60 seconds recovery.

Had dinner afterward with Greeno and Finan - lots of laughs and a solid dose of bewilderment at how Dan gets himself in the situations that he does.

With John. Felt surprisingly alright. Tired, but not too sore. Would have gone farther, but I ran out of time before my meeting today. Reflecting on yesterday, I don't know what I expected - it was 48 hours after my sub-LT 20. In that light, I'm pretty happy with it. I wish Finan, in his ever-present rationality, would have pointed that out at dinner last night. He must have been distracted by Greeno's dazzling teeth.
Didn't force anything today- just tried to stay relaxed. My legs are pretty tired. Looking forward to getting through this week and resting up for alumni. But for now, grinding on.

A little longer, because I don't want to have to do a long cool down tonight. There were so many high schoolers on the lakes this morning - I felt like I was running Milaca in reverse. Good to see the participation though.

Really frustrating long day at work today. Came home, put the shoes on, and went right out to 80 degrees and 80% humidity.

16 or 17x SW hill sprints, all out. between the heat, tired legs, and a long day, these weren't great.

Feeling emotionally drained.

With John. Feeling pretty beat - this might be my only run today. I have this soreness that is on the side of/under/behind my left knee? Maybe IT band stuff? calf/hamstring?I feel it as the angle behind my knee is made more and more acute.

Not sure, really, but I'll work on all of them.

Feels really good to maybe, MAYBE be done with running for the day!

Got out the door this morning to a pleasant 94% humidity- felt like we were drinking our oxygen. First, John and I stopped to buy some gels, just for the sake of practicing. John and I were soaked before we even finished our warmup. Had slated the good old 3x5k, starting at threshold pace, and hoping for more. Splits were as follows:

5:19, 5:20, 5:25, :31 = 16:35
5:13, 5:15, 5:15, :30 = 16:14
5:07, 5:18?, 5:09 :30 = 16:04

Not sure where the 5:18 came from in the last rep, I just imagine it was in the turns and transitions of the north end of Calhoun. Got yelled at by some bikers, and encouraged by some others. After our last 5k, a guy who was running and pushing a disabled girl in an adapted wheelchair stopped and told us how inspiring we were. I told him the same- there are still some good people in this world. Merchant met us for the cool down, and that helped pass the miles. Good day, and I did what I wanted in the workout: felt good throughout, and pretty relaxed until the very end - and it didn't help that my shoes were filled with sweat, and this puts me over 107 miles in the last seven days. Now it's time to rest, do some short speed, and get ready to roll at alumni. Alums, what time is it?
Just enough to get to 100. First 5 were with John, then I went to Nokomis and back solo.  Down week time!
Easy ten with Renner and JL. Felt heavy, but manageable. Getting excited for alumni :)

Woke up to about 55 degrees and sunshine... Even if just for the morning, those small glimpses of Minnesota Fall make me feel like I have electricity in my veins. Just a shakeout this morning, and though I felt sore, it's definitely recovery soreness - a good thing.

I had visions of blustery, leaf-covered cross courses the whole way, and even if my reality this year is 26 miles of pavement, it sure felt good to imagine being out stampeding over some grass :)

On the Blake track with Anders and Dave was there for a bit. 

12x300 w 60 seconds recovery (100m jog back to the start, 20 seconds walking/standing)

Goal was 'mile pace or a bit faster' And I have no idea what that means, so I ran as fast as I could without sprinting. Like... Aerobic, but entirely uncomfortable. I figured 48-50's. Ran:

49.2, 49.4, 49.2, 49.3, 49.5, 49.7, 50.1, 48.9, 48.7, 49.1, 47.8, 47.4

So they were all between 4:12 and 4:27 pace. Anders ran the first 10, and of course fairly dusted me on them.

I'm ready for Saturday :)
Ran John's warmup with him over to Kennilworth, scampered around solo for a half hour, and then met back up with him for his cool down. Nice day out there!

Quick lap of Harriet. Didn't feel great, didn't feel awful. This is probably all I'm going to do today - one extra rest day just in case Aaron Haley is fit right now. I didn't know he'd be racing this weekend until yesterday. Do I feel guilty about taking two consecutive down days? Absolutely. Am I willing to lose the alumni meet? Absolutely not.

Morning. Easy jaunt to 46th, then the east side of Harriet. Found out Bobby Davis lives a block from me, so thats... something. 

4 strides, feeling good!

Ready set ;)

Challenge with different groups for different parts. Ran with the team for the main loop, Then bridges with Anders and Hartman, then just Hartman and I doing some back and forth hodge-podging around town. First 6 were unremarkable, but then my legs felt really good for the rest.

Thankful to start this run nice and easy with Marit, as some of the soreness was catching up with me. 5 miles around golf cart with her, then a really mentally awful series of out and backs to get to 10 solo while she lifted. Followed this run with River Rock, a caf picnic, nothing-talks in the Arb, and ice cream. 

Summer 2014, you've been one for the ages.

Do it with everything you have, or don't do it at all.

'The thing itself is the absence of compromise. There are no...deals available. I wish there was someway to explain that. The thing...doesn't dilute. You can either do it, or not do it, but you can't talk about it worth a damn.'

Last week was a nice break - back to the marathon grind for a just few more.

Classes start today, so getting in speed work is going to become more challenging.

Didn't feel snappy, but I felt strong.

After going to class tonight to find out that the graduate semester doesn't start until Wednesday, I came home with extra daylight out to run. 8 more to bring the 3 day total to 54. Loading up mileage this week because this week and next it's now or never, and there's an off chance that I might run John's half marathon with him this weekend. I can't decide if it'd be better to go into that tired and work for it, or back off a little. By front-loading, I can do either one and decide later in the week. Or I might not do it. We'll see. If I did do it, it'd be controlled - 5:35 to 5:40 through 10, then maybe, MAYBE peek and  find out how well the ol' carrot farming operation is going..

Finally! I have a morning 5 mile loop that isn't just a lap of Calhoun.

It's really everything I want in a morning run - mostly neighborhoods with nice houses to look at, very few runners, a small bit along the lakes, not flat but all the hills are gentle, plenty of shade, option to run on grass, and it's exactly 5 miles.

Gray and raining this morning, but it didn't bother me :)

800s with John at SW.

I didn't really know what to expect going into this - All I knew is that I wanted to do about 10 of them, and had to start edging down from threshold to vO2 pace this week. I felt 'Comfortable' the whole way, in so far as I was in control, and not digging too deep. General goal was mid 2:20's - maybe 2:25, I figured. The only part that really sucked was the humidity. I was soaked by three, and by 7 my shoes were wet to the point that my feet were slipping around inside of them.

2:25, 2:27, 2:23, 2:26, 2:25, 2:24, 2:24, 2:25, 2:24, 2:19.

On the last one, I just picked it up for the last 300. 71/68? Good workout!
My left foot was bleeding through my shoe by the end. That'll probably feel good tomorrow morning.

Easy jog - Cedar Creek loop.

Woke up pretty early and didn't feel like running, so I laid in bed and read for a while. Even after I finally did get moving, I just stared out the window at the sidewalk for quite a while before finally getting out the door. Running is so empowering, and can also make you feel helpless sometimes.

After warming up a little, I actually didn't feel bad at all. My legs were sturdy, and not at all sore (granted I was running fairly relaxed). I think next fall I want to do shorter, faster races. I was pretty tired by the last few miles of this run, and you can chalk that up to marathon necessity, I suppose. Not that I'd even run less frequently if I were doing mile-10k's, but I would definitely not have to do 10 mile morning runs. I did reflect a bit on the trial-by-fire, all-in training that I've been doing for the majority of the last 4+ years, and someday I know I'm going to miss it. So, to 50 year old Nick - here's to you: a couple more tired, long, weeks, months, and years of training.

I'll probably double up tonight if Balke doesn't crush my soul, which his syllabus suggests he plans to do.

Felt like I had some snap tonight - physiology is weird. 

I ran rather slow for how I felt, just because it was after class (dark) and I didn't want to break an ankle. One stride at the end, and I could just about fly.

Yesterday I soaked two pairs of shoes with sweat. This morning, I saw my breath. Minnesota.

Legs felt good, stomach still hurt.

Long route down to SW, 12x hill sprints, 3.1 home. 

Feels like fall :)

Seriously though, there is one Maple tree just west of 48th and Xerxes that has already changed colors and is dropping leaves. Wtf?

Woof. I was pancake-flat today, so I didn't make it too far; it was a really tough run. There's a handful of reasons why, so I'm not overly worried. Also, I was starving out there. I think I haven't been eating enough. Hopefully tomorrow I can jog (yog? soft J?) a 1:14 and it will feel as easy as I imagine it feeling.

Thankful for today :)

Ran the CIty of Lakes half marathon today as a marathon-pace workout. Greeno and two others went out hard, then it was me and a few guys leading a huge peloton of folks that apparently didn't want to lead. The goal was to just run 5:35-5:40, pick it up at the end if I felt ok, and run 1:14.

At the mile (5:40) some guy got antsy and broke the little cocktail party we were having. Generally, this is no problem. But this guy moved HARD, was from lifetime fitness, and was wearing earbuds and an iPod. I didn't go with, because I wasn't racing (no small task. It was pretty difficult to let guys run away/not cover moves that I knew I could easily manage.) our second mile was 5:28 - but I told myself no faster than 5:30 before 10, so I eased up. By now it was Merchant and me, and we settled in. We ran side by side a bit, and he drafted off me for quite a while (hitting tangents, I suppose). We were fully conversational for the first ten miles. It felt good to have someone to talk to, and to be able to talk comfortably at sub 5:40 pace. Aerobically I felt really strong. My legs were tired by the end, but I think that has more to do with the training load than the pace of the day. I took powerade a few times, water once, had a Gu at 7, and another just before 10, but I didn't finish that one, because there was work to be done at that point. I got side aches from both Gu's. Sucky.

I had ONE goal during this race: To catch and beat the headphones guy from Lifetime. Spite, perhaps. By mile 9 I couldn't see him any more, and by 10 I figured he was 600m ahead, but coming back. Turning south on Calhoun (mile 10.5?) the last time, I looked at Merch and said, 'It's time to go get this guy.' So we picked it up, and right before WIlliam Berry, we had pulled him in. I backed off a tad at that point, because there was no one else in range, and I didn't feel like I had to race Ben. So he and I cruised in the last 4 or 5 hundred meters, and I finished a step behind him.

I was only looking for 1:14, ended up 1:12:59 and 6th place (I think)...

Really good crowd support - two specific categories of people: Circuit runners that weren't racing, and 20 something white girls with yoga pants clutching their Starbucks. No joke. Oh, and Little Kate :) 

I haven't seen results, but with the exception of Greeno, I feel like I could have run with anyone in the field had I raced. Legs were tired, and I felt like I could have held pace for 20, but not 26. Hopefully taper will make Summit bearable. 

Felt strong enough.

Splits: 
5:40, 5:28, 5:36, 5:38, 5:36, 5:39, 5:36, 5:37, 5:38, 5:37, 5:32, 5:21, 5:24, 32.x

avg: 5:34

Started out toward Wirth with John, and crossed paths with Scanlon before mile one. He came with, which was awesome because it forced us to run slowly. Ended up running the beautifully named Maggot Squirrel loop through Wirth, and Scanlon ran the whole thing with us. Some enlightening stories were told on this run. It felt good to run slowly, sit back and listen to people banter. My knee hurt all day, but was good on the run.

Still looking for a big(ish) mileage week, but I didn't think it'd be a bad idea to not double this morning.

Morning jaunt before an impressively unnecessary regional meeting. I felt really good today, the legs are definitely coming around from Sunday. Part of this was run on the TCM course, and of course I thought about/pictured the race quite a bit out there - and I didn't feel nervous at all. I don't really think you can ever be ready for a marathon, it's asymptotic. That said, with where I am now, and how my next 3 - 4 weeks of training look, I feel ready enough. 

It feels good to be at peace with it, now hopefully a little excitement will even start to creep in.
Felt really good again tonight, which I wasn't expecting. Run, work, class, run. I'm glad this isn't every day - I was really hungry during the run.

50 degrees, windy and raining. Maybe it's because they were numb, but my legs felt really good. I felt fast this morning. Marathon fast, but still fast.

50 makes me wonder how we ran TCM with the 29 degree start temp in '12. Eesh. Hoping for 42, calm, and blue skies :)

Such a great workout. After just running the half-marathon 3 days ago, having 3 (now 4) good runs in a row, and being greeted by 15ish mph (and increasing) winds I didn't have high expectations of this one. 5x mile at the SW track with Anders and John. Recovery was 3 minutes of mostly jogging (which is a lot, don't get me wrong). Splits were:

4:52, 4:52, 4:49, 4:48, 4:43

Felt in control the whole time. Got a little tired by the end, but definitely had more in me. I couldn't really tell you what was getting tired, but I was getting there. Really encouraging workout, and John and Anders killed it too. 14 mile reps between the three of us, and zero of them were over 5 minutes. Not that there's a huge correlation between mile repeats and the marathon, but I couldn't have done this before my 2:31 in 2012. Getting fast at the right time :)

Felt so smooth, so strong, and still over 100 miles on the week.
Kenya shuffle. I ran those 8 minute miles like it was my job.
Easy jog with Elder Prieve for 2.5, then solo. My legs felt back to normal today :) Another good run.
Felt great  today. Ran into Lyndsi and Kate out running and chatted a bit. FRIDAY!!!

Got it done early with JL. Had 22 on the mind, and figured that somehow doing a workout during it would be easier, and mentally, it was. 4 warmup, 5 'fast', 1 easy, 4 'fast', 1 easy, 3 'fast', 1 easy, 2 'fast', 1 easy.

The fast portions were just... light pickups. Looking for just a hair under 6 flats.

Splits:
4.08 easy in who knows what,
5:57, 6:00, 5:50, 5:42, 5:45
7:17
5:52, 5:53, 6:00, 5:57
7:20
5:51, 5:53, 5:55
7:37
5:42, 5:43
7:35

Legs were tired by the end, but it's 22 miles. Otherwise this felt pedestrian. Good workout :)
Snelling Lake/Pike Island with Marit :) More than happy to keep the pace in check and enjoy the beautiful weather. Good run, good breakfast... I wish it was the weekend every day.

Easy after work run with Anders and John. Dave biked with for a few miles too. started slow, but got faster as we went. I drank a ton of water today, and felt really swollen and heavy, but nothing hurt. Just another one for the books. We talked about how there should be no overlap of error bars between Mark Petersen and James Sorenson, and how Comcast is the Raychel Zupan of internets. Lovely weather for a nice scamper and talking about things that don't, and never will, matter.

Morning solo jog. My legs still felt less-than-great, and my knee/achilles stuff was stiff, but I'll massage it today, and hopefully get out for a short shakeout/few strides tonight after class. High 40's this morning! Chilly.

Also, since this is something of a diary to me, I forgot to mention this: last week when JL, Anders and I were doing our last mile repeat, this little blond boy (4 years old?) just comes tearing across the infield toward us, with his arms out, screaming 'I NEED TO HUG YOU!!!!!!!!!' His mom apologized and ran after him, scooped him up, and when we finished our rep, apologized to us, saying 'he's a hugger.' We laughed, put our trainer back on, and ran a cool down. When we got back and were standing at my car talking, the kid - still there - comes around the corner of the SW fence and says, 'Can I hug you now?' and proceeded to jump on all three of us, giving us hugs. He says he'll be a runner someday!

Easy run after class. Nothing hurt until the strides at the end, when my knee gave me some trouble. Ran slowly tonight not because I was tired, but I had this abnormally strong fear that since it was dark I'd step in a pothole and break my ankle.
Legs did not feel good this morning. Just a shakeout, but my legs felt pretty rough. I don't know how last week was so great, and this week is a struggle.

Workout with Anders at the SW track. JL ran a few with us too. Good workout, but nothing extraordinary. Since it was 400's, of course Anders blew me away, and he had probably the best workout of his life. I did 10x400, then 6x SW hill sprints.

Goal for the 400's was about 68. Fast, but not straining.

67, 69, 66, 69, 68, 67, 68, 68, 67, 67

200m jog, 15 seconds standing recovery.

On the whole, things felt ok today. Knee was giving me some issues - it just dawned on me that I may need some new trainers. Last night I was fretting about the taper, and had an internal battle going over only doing 10 400's last night. The training workhorse in me wanted to just keep cranking until I couldn't, but I know the time for that has passed. Maybe that's what makes me nervous: that I can't do anything to get in better shape anymore, and the only thing of benefit that can be done is to rest. Unnerving. Anyway, I had a dream last night that I was running TC, went through the mile sub 5:20 and felt so good. But the course became less and less marked, and eventually I took a wrong turn and no one knew where I was supposed to go. I ran a 5:58, then saw a police office at an intersection on top of this huge hill, and I ran a 6:12 to get there, then he wouldn't let me cross the street because of traffic, so I had to stop and wait... Talk about frustrating.

Going to have to study that course map...

But hey, I think I put the work in this cycle. I hope. My cake is baked, and all I can do now is decorate it. And I love me some frosting. Time to be fast.

Finally got some new shoes. Legs weren't perfect, but they're where the should be. Hopefully the shoes will alleviate my knee problem - the old pair made it 850 miles! A few strides, during which I met an old lady named Marlee who lives on my street, and she talked with me a while about the marathon. She also introduced me to her two dogs - both boys, but Tully has gender identity issues, I guess. First day under 90 miles for my rolling 7 in a long while.

Olaf! Lets see if us old guys can remember how to run cross country.

Slow start with the Guys team at GAC, then split off with Paulie and Benson to Golf Course who knows where we are. Paul loved this route, for whatever reason. I just thought about how I missed Ramble On. Picked it up by the end, finished solo, and capped it with some Uhler laps in memory of Dan Foley.

Lakes with John. I think I figured out my plan for eating during the marathon. Those powerbar gels are just superior to Gu. Maybe not nutritionally, I have no idea, but they are much thinner, and not sticky at all. If they are remotely warm, you can just drink them. They will be my go to. Then I got some Skratch today, which actually tastes really good (they are only flavored with pulverized real fruit), it's super light, and easy on the stomach. Lower osmolarity than blood, too. So I think that'll be my drink. I just need to keep the side aches away. That's my only concern now.

Early morning stumble interrupted by hearing footstep quickly approaching behind me. I decided I was going with whoever it was... Turns out it was Jon Petersen. Glad that I was able to turn around shortly after that.
Just a Calhoun lap after a really long day.

Did John's workout with him over on Harriet. 3x(3min,2min,1min) No idea what pace we were running, but my stomach was really upset. My legs are still feeling heavy and garbage-y, which makes a lot of sense since this is the lowest mileage I've run in... months?

Such a strange feeling run. I thought my watch was off, but it was beeping at the mile markers, and I mapped it after to make sure. I think I had a 6:02 in there? I didn't feel like I was running NEARLY that fast - not because I felt good and springy and all that, but I felt like I wasn't covering ground at 10 mph. Like I actually wasn't moving forward that fast.

I'll take it I guess? Still didn't feel miraculous. Kept it short today (the devil's distance), in hopes of feeling fresher soon.

Again, with the pacing problem. I ran a route of known distance, and just tried to keep it relaxed. Figured I was running 7's, maybe 6:40's by the end. Actually went 6:52, 6:35, 6:21, 6:25, 6:18, 6:10, 6:09, 6:07. Hopefully this mean all my paces will feel easier?

Morning workout before heading to Griak. It was already pretty hot out when I got up, relatively, but it wasn't awful. 2x2 miles out on lake Harriet. I wanted to run 10:30's with short recovery, but see the past few days - I have no gauge of pace.

I went through the mile in 4:50, then hit the brakes to run a 9:59 for my first rep. I felt frustrated and a little nauseous after? So I sat down on a bench and thought about life for a few moments. Then I did my second rep (trying to be more controlled) in 10:41, overshooting it the other direction. Confusing workout, and I'm not sure what it means.

Legs felt pretty tired the rest of the day

Early afternoon run with John after coming home and spending the morning with Bart wearing flannel, smoking a turkey, and having too many cups of coffee of the porch. This run was tough; a calm 81 and clear skies - I drank well over a gallon of water afterward. The fountain at West River and CLBT was on, and John found Jesus today, I think.

Nick: Any chance the water fountain is on?
John: Don't even try it, it's just disappointing. That one hasn't been on, ever, since I've lived in the cities. OR try it, just so we know for sure. Again.
Nick: Maybe there'll be a miracle.
John: I did go to church this morning.
(Turns the handle, water comes out. Shocked, we both drink)

We turn back toward the road, and immediately a van drives by with huge lettering that just says, 'Try Jesus'

John: I'm saying a prayer before dinner tonight. I have some words for the man upstairs. And I don't mean Kurt.

My body is tired.
Morning jog on the lakes with Finan. As always, splendid conversation - deep soul searching to mocking Jon Grey and everything in between.

41 degrees! Chilly morning run today, solo frolicking around Harriet and the south side of the creek. Eff TCM is a hilly course. Anyway, I wasn't going to run this far today, but before going out I read Tyler Pennel's most recent blog about how he isn't really tapering much, and I got nervous that I was doing too little. So I ran an extra 10-15 minutes :) 

Also, I see I haven't taken a day off in over 11 weeks. I think it's almost time!

Tune up at SW with John and Anders. Standard 4x800 @ quick, pace, pace, quick.

2:14, 2:51, 2:45, 2:13

Felt easy. On the cool down, some little kid with a fishing pole was on the path and yelled 'you guys are awesome!' as Anders and I ran past. I thanked him and told him that was the nicest thing anyone has said to me on that trail. When we ran past him the other way, I gave him a high five and he said, 'Remember! You're awesome!' Kinda made me happy - a little of my cynicism dissolved there. Cool weather, and my body feels about as ready as it ever has. Let's see what happens next.

Morning saunter looking at some fall colors. Legs felt yesterday a little, but as I write this I'm already brimming over with energy again.

So much for sleep the rest of the week.

Way overslept this morning... Oh well, I can stay late at work if I have to. It was mid/low 40's and 23 mph wind today with a light on and off rain. That felt pretty cold, but now Sunday is looking like 35 and breezy, so I guess it's time to get used to it. Still praying for 44 and a light west wind.

Did a lap of Harriet, and repeatedly was splashed by whitecaps coming over the wall on Calhoun. I was freaking out today that I'd do something stupid and I kept thinking, 'Watch for potholes, don't roll your ankle, don't slip on those leaves, slow down, slow down, focus, focus, focus.'

At 9:49 (I checked my watch) I passed my stalker on his bike on the East side of Harriet. I know for a fact hes a student at SW, how the heck was he out on his bike at almost 10? I swear I see him 5 times a week, in random places at times when he shouldn't be there. He's seriously following me.
Shake out with John. Had to walk home from the tin fish. Glute/Hamstring/Sciatic issues.

Well... here goes. I tried. 

And that's what makes this hard. It's not even that I tried this morning, which I did, but I mean, I tried. I tried in June, and July, and March and those awful hot nights after class and before work and instead of sleeping and at 6am before going on vacation and instead of brunches and late nights and a social life, I tried. Running is an absurd pastime, in the intellectual sense, as there is nothing to be achieved, and no greater purpose, other than the training itself. Even goals are arbitrary. Improvement is all we have. 

The morning before this race, my hamstring was giving me issues, but I honestly wasn't worried. Phantom taper pains, as Jiggy reminded me. I felt ok doing strides before the start, and lined up having put it out of my mind. I wore shorts, and I wish I'd have had half tights, because my legs stayed cold for a long time. The field immediately broke into a lead pack of 10 or so, and a chase pack. I tucked in with the chasers, hit the mile in 5:37, and tried to go to sleep. After an uphill second mile in 5:41, the chase pack panicked, and dropped a 5:29 third mile. By this point, we were strung out, single file heading down lake of the isles. How does a marathon string out in three miles? I was surprised. mile four was a 5:33, then I think we finally settled in. Merch and I were alone by this point, the chase pack either strung out in front, or dissolved into the back masses. from there we went 5:35, 5:33, 5:35, 5:37, 5:38, 5:33... you get the point. We were sleeping. My legs were heavier than I'd hoped, and I knew it was going to be a grind, but it was still tolerable. We rolled through the half in 1:13:2x, and Merchant left me, hooking on to some guy who was running much faster than I wanted. The creek sucked, and it was too early for that. I remember coming into the falls and thinking, oh boy. There are still 11 miles left, and I'm starting to feel stiff. Then Marotz was out there and told me to quit feeling sorry for myself. He was right - In my head I said I needed to quit being a baby and do what I came here to do. And then I was back in it. This went off and on for the next 3 miles. Heading toward lake street, I felt something change. At first there was no pain, but my stride was getting shorter in my right leg. I tried to take longer steps, and then the pain came. It was like with each toe off, my muscle would return to slightly less of a relaxed state. Going under the bridge, I saw Marit, and I knew then that I wasn't going to make it. I felt like crying. I took my water bottle, drank some, and thought maybe I could get over Franklin and back to the other side. So I kept limping on, but somewhere north of the greenway, just short of 19, I couldn't do it anymore. I couldn't lift my leg, I was running almost 7 minute pace. I stepped off the course, stopped my watch, and felt positively shattered. I started walking back toward lake street, knowing Mar would be at mile 20. People kept talking to me, offering help, condolences, talking about how strong I looked and this is the marathon and even to the strongest in the marathon These Things happen. When I saw Marit on the far side of the bridge, I lost my composure a bit. It was a matter of time, I suppose. I'm glad I wasn't alone.

I'm left with questions. 2012 felt so easy for nearly 20 miles. Even without my hamstring problem, I was going to fall apart. My legs didn't feel anything like last time. I wasn't floating. I'll take a few days off now, but I'm torn on where to go from here, as far as running. Part of me wants to chase my losses, put in two more hard months and run CIM in December. I could do it, I know I could. But even if it went well, would it outweigh the toll it'd take on my soul? Cold morning runs, probably treadmill workouts, late night runs after class in the dark? Or do I hang it up for 2014? Find contentment in the few good races I ran back in March and April and take the Summer and Fall as a casualty of putting all the eggs in one basket? I really want to run 10k and down next year - that was the plan, but I think that was subconsciously contingent on TC going well. Or do I give up spring track and run grandmas? Some of this is rhetorical, but I wouldn't mind input.

It's just hard, you know? And maybe this is dramatic, but hey, it's my log. And the marathon is... It's consuming. What's possibly most frightening is that I didn't even really feel that great. Maybe it was the cold, maybe my goals weren't realistic on that course? I don't like to doubt my training, but it makes me wonder if I actually know what I'm doing. Though it seems to work for everyone else. I don't like to be unresolved. That's a big part of why this is particularly challenging. 

I am exceptionally grateful for the support network I have, though. The number of people who came to the race to cheer, watch, or help me was incredible. And all the text messages/calls/emails after was humbling, too. I'm really thankful that even when things don't happen how they should, I have so many people that are proud anyway.

I came home from work today, and I decided I was going to live one day as a normal human being. I walked in the door, opened a beer, sat on the couch, played some video games, took a nap, ate junk food (later a stuffed crust pizza) and all it made me feel was awful. Seriously, I don't know how people live like that. They must feel gross all the time.

So I went for a 2 mile run with John. It was rough. Time for a few down days.
With Finan in Chicago. My Sciatic/hip/hamstring thing hurt a lot. Walked in.
With John through the newly ruined bird sanctuary. Tight at first, loosened up in the middle, and really, really awfgul in the last mile.

In the dark after class. It's that wonderful time of year again where evening (and soon, afternoon runs) are in the dark and the paranoia of stepping in a hole and breaking my ankle sets in for the season.

Started with a sharp, pinching pain in my sciatic, which slowly wrapped around to the front of my hip though out the run. It was one of those pains that I think would stay at bay, mostly, but if I had to stop for any reason I wouldn't be able to restart.

Because I'm a jerk and Im'm looking for any way to get rewards for my summer training, I slow-rolled a dude today. Toward the end of the run, I was slowly gaining on a guy (he was probably running 7:05 pace, maybe 7's. When I got 20m away, he looked over his shoulder and his cadence increased. I didn't think anything of it, it was dark, and maybe my footsteps startled him. Then he did it again, and the cadence noticeably increased, again. I didn't even slow roll, really. I just went over the top, sub-6, and held it until I was out of sight. Substitute gratification does not vent completely the deeper yearnings, however, and it made me want to get on a track and race. In time. There is time, and time and time.

Seeing Folske tomorrow, hopefully we can get a grasp on what's going on.

Got a little fast today, mile 3 was 5:50. I saw Folske this morning, and I don't know how he does it, but the dude worked his witchcraft and I felt good today. I was sore, but I had no pinching or any of that, except at mile 4 I had one spasm on the front side of my hip. Got some things I can do to work on it, and I'll see him again soon. I want to run for fun a few times before the snow flies.

Just going to throw this out there, because I don't remember what I've done the past few days. I ran on most of them - a few pretty miles up in Hayward with Marit, and more around the lakes. I figure it's time to start logging again, as I'm healthy enough that if I miss a day of running now, it's because I'm weak, not because I'm hurt. Some days were better, some were worse.
Morning shake out. I figure if I'm cramping around 7 miles, I'd try doing two shorter runs and add workload that way.
Harriet with John. Things felt fine. 9 mile day!!!
Morning jaunt. My legs were pretty tired by the end. That kinda sucks.
Solo lap. Right achilles is sore, but otherwise everything felt pretty good (except for the being out of shape part).
Yogging around with Anders. Had some enlightening chats - peculiar, the way some things play out. Absolutely no pain on this run.

Morning lap, and first run of the season below freezing. 28, windchill of 18, and it actually felt really nice. I like the 20's, I hate the single digits. Everything felt really off and creaky and tight starting out. My whole right side was tight until the last 200m of this run, and then I felt perfect. Riddle me that. More to come.

Morning on the Greenway with John. The run went by really fast as we were solidifying our conference predictions. Honestly, we could do this for a living if anyone wanted to pay us. We were pretty much on the money within 1-2 places for eaasentially the top 25, the whole gustie varsity, and the team finishing order with rough point totals.

We need a new hobby.

jogged around the arb at Gustavus while Marit was working.

Such a good weekend.
Quick morning lap. Felt good, but a ways out of race shape.
Lakes action with John. Felt good until the very end. I strongly dislike the space between the weekends.

morning jaunt up to Wirth Park. The windchill was only like 32, but I was freezing until I got out of the wind. Things are coming around with my leg, but I still feel really heavy and cumbersome. Time to make the furnace hotter, I suppose. I'm excited to get into shape again, I just feel like I have a bit to overcome before I start doing consistent workouts. A bit groggy this morning, as I don't think I fell asleep until well after 1, but that's why God invented coffee.

The sun is out today :)
Cruising by the end. Felt pretty good, actually.

5,4,3,2,1 speed ladder on the greenway in the dark/rain with JL and Finan for the first bit. Didn't wear a watch, no clue on paces, just wanted to try out the different gears. My legs were actually fairly responsive, and my hamstring was a non-issue. It actually was less noticeable the farther into the workout I was. 

Tonight was a good night..

Slow morning jog. I felt great for three miles, then my glute/hamstring felt like it was pinching. It never got worse, but it never went away. This run took forever, it seemed. I'm reasonably sure that the amount of time I was out there was similar to circumnavigating any of the inner planets. 

One car switched lanes to swerve at me. That was unnecessary.

ended up being something like 7:30, 7, 6:30, 6. Right Achilles was a little stubborn at first, but it got better as the run went on. There are single-digit temperatures predicted in the next week, which should be fun. It's that time of year where the two inches between the bottoms of my tights and the tops of my socks chap, crack, and freeze every single day... Sorry guys. 

On an unrelated note, Milner offered to coach me again, which is perfect because this is the exact point of the year where I care the least about training.

I was ready to go out after hunting in the morning, but then I thought (here comes the excuse train) 'I live so much of my life around training, and right now it doesn't matter that much.' so I made a pizza and talked with my mom for a while instead.

Back in Hastings. Still not really sure if this was a good workout or not - I wasn't planning to do speed, but a few miles in I figured it wasn't in the top 5 worst ideas, so I was henceforth bound to do it. I hodge-podged 5 miles around the river, over to the dike, and back to the start line of Gobble Gait. I ran the 8k course doing 4 minutes on at thresholdy-ish pace, 1 minute jogging recovery for the whole thing. I think I was like 5:0x-5:20 for most of it, but I know I was over 5:40's for the half mile hike up CP Adams hill. Ended up hitting the finish in 28:10. I think considering the workout nature, the rest intervals, and wear Pegasus', I'm reasonably happy with it.

Just an easy shakeout through the first snow of the year. Predicted was something like 14 inches, and through it was still snowing when I ran, there was maybe 3 on the ground accumulated. Surprisingly, I wasn't even mad about it. Crossing slippery roads sucked, but where the snow was untouched it was fine. I only have 2 weeks left of needing to be 'serious' about running, unless I feel like racing indoor (that just depends where my heart is at in December), and the whole run I just pictured early, dark evenings in front of wood stoves or sitting on radiators while wet clothing dried next to it, feeling limbs slowly warming back up, and complete exhaustion after a long workout that is only trumped by the starving hunger waiting for gorgonzola pasta to finish cooking. Long skis with friends through the woods, or under the lights at French, endless quiet laps at Hyland... I feel happy.

Well, it was super icy and cold and sleeting and snowy out, and my bright-eyed optimism from this morning had run out. That said, I went to the hamster wheel and approximately 2 or 2 and a half minutes into my run I was bored. I quickly went through my rolodex of workout thoughts - generally I do 2 up, 2 down, with 15/10/5 in the middle and it always comes out to be 10.5 miles. That seemed too long, so I just did 2 up, 2 down, and a relaxed 5 mile tempo/progression in the middle. Went 5:42, 5:3x, 5:24, 5:18, 5:00 for a 27:01 5 mile. Some curly-haired guy got on the treadmill next to me and started to match my paces in the second mile of my warmup, and due to sheer boredom I decided to play a little game. He'd match my pace, and then go one click faster, so I'd let him for a bit, and then click it 2 times, let him go back past, and then when I went down to 5:42 pace, he tried, and I've never seen running form fall apart so fast. That must be what it'd look like if I tried to run with Finan. I mean, this guy made it at that pace for a minute or two, but he was literally throwing his legs out in front of him. It looked really painful.

Then I kept picking it up, he backed off and at some point near the end of my tempo, he  stopped running. I'm sure that makes me a jerk, but so do a million other things, and I needed something to distract myself.

I lifted and did core as long as I was there, and remembered how hard lifting is. Onward and upward.
back logging the runs that were deleted.
back logging the runs that were deleted.
back logging the runs that were deleted.
back logging the runs that were deleted.

back logging the runs that were deleted.

2 easy, 2 in 10:40, 2 easy

back logging the runs that were deleted.

At Gustavus. Ran into Slob. Cold.
Easy morning 10. Just cruised along.
Easy around the Lakes with John and Lillihaugen.

Morning spin on the hamster wheel. Keeping par with my adherence to not changing the TV channel unless I'm doing a run over an hour, I had the real housewives of Orange County this morning. The only thing more messed up than those women are the people who watch this show. Unbelievable. These moms talking to their kids about minimum wage, and then listening to the kids describe it was unsettling. I actually felt disgusting after 5 minutes, so I threw in my headphones, shuffled a dance music playlist, and stared at the wall. Infinitely better than that OC garbage.

About two minutes into this run I ran into Dave on the greenway, so he biked with me for four miles at a good clip. Sub 6:30 anyway. Then I ran to Finan's house and joined him for 5 around Isles discussing egresses and other things. Who needs practicum when I do weekly therapy with Finan? I'm not sure that my post-run blessing with holy snow did him much good, in fact I doubt my services really do him much good to begin with.

Beautiful and sunny. If it gets any warmer I'm planting palm trees. ELLLLLL NI�OOOO!!!!

7:30, hamster wheel. About how you'd expect it'd go. Except that about 2 miles in, I started to feel really angry. I'm not sure why, either. But I didn't like the feeling at all... The pace started to go south and I think I had a 5:18 mile in there. I turned off my music to see if that help - figuring maybe there was just too much stimulation. It made a difference, but as I type this I still don't feel quite normal.

Yuck. Get me through this week.

Downtown/skyscraper loop with John. We spent an inordinate amount of time plotting a really complex prank on Kurt. and yes, I'm putting this out there to live dangerously. His last login was in June. So... Here you go Pab: It's coming.

90 minute skate at Hyland with Anders, Zach, Eric, and Erica. Erica said I looked really good skiing, and I do appreciate the kindness of her lies. Anders made fun of my elbows, I felt awkward as heck, and Jed made some funny, very truthful comments.

One of those mornings that is somehow separate from time, you know? You wake up and everything is gray and dripping and it's light out but not really and it stays exactly static until it's dark again. On the whole, it wasn't bad. I got up, had my coffee, charged the watch and tied my shoes. Lacking motivation a little, but it wasn't cold out - that helped. Things were stiff and sore starting out - they got better but I always felt kind of heavy. Ran into Parish after 40 minutes, and just tacked on here and there with him, catching up on life. He's in the twilight of his 20's and it's cool to hear how he lives these days. 'Aside from my bikes, I don't really own much.'

That and spending $2500 to go to New Zealand to meet with a girl he had a connection with, only to find out that... not so much.

Not exactly pleasant, but a good conversation and I got my miles in.


'Another godawful eight miles in the books.

The questions recur, or at least they should. They are old ones that we chew on, the cud of experience. What the hell is this all about, this onwards, this forwards, this march to who knows where? 

I barely got out the door after a day at work chasing my tail around. There are always good reasons, rational reasons, hella good arguments for just staying put. Like: I ran too hard last week and my legs are tired. Like: The grass really needs to be mowed. Like: Isn't this supposed to be fun? Like: What's another eight miles in the grand scheme of things?

When you carve a life up into the little bits that we actually feel and see, it's hard to figure the meaning. Only rarely does a vision appear of how the whole fits together. Most of the time it's just keep your head down and trust that it will all work out. The other option is to drive yourself crazy with questions, and there's even less point to that. The best argument for God's existence: there must be a higher power because I sure as hell don't know much.

After about 10 too many minutes of indulging these sorts of thoughts, you realize that shit if you are gonna sit around and wonder about the meaning of life, you might as well be getting those eight miles in. So, you head to the door not expecting much at all but at least you've got your shoes on now and turns out it's not even raining.

Down the front steps and you begin a sideways trot. The familiar sequence: the stiff achilles, the stumbling gait for the first mile. Up the first hill still not warmed up. Onwards you go, through the quiet city, past the strolling couples and the goofy dogs. There's even a pink sunset. The stiffness dissipates and the stumble gathers itself into something like a flow, the mind clears, and you've got something approximating authentic experience. 

And even if it's not, at least it's another godawful eight miles in the books.'

-Jeff Edmonds.

Just a jog with 4x half-mile pickups in the middle at 5:00 pace. 90 seconds jogging between. Thursday is going to suck, but I'll jive if I have to. 

I tried to do strength and core after - mostly successful but my right elbow hurt from skiing so I couldn't do many pushups, and maybe 4 dips. That can go away any time now.
Morning Harriet loop. Clear paths, but cold. Not looking forward to Thursday.

slow going through lots of snow. Pretty low visibility, but there were a bunch of swans on Calhoun which was cool, and a few lone muskrats out sitting on the ice eating sticks. Life could be worse :)

3 degrees with a WC of -8 at the gun tomorrow.

Maybe I'd rather eat a stick.

The seasons have officially changed, as I switched my watch from miles to kilometers today. Skied at Elm with Kory and Anders, then solo after them for a little bit. Worked on technique for a while, and it really seemed to help, but then after we actually skied a while I'd gone back to being sloppy. In time. A little over 30k of actual skiing (not going back and forth doing drills) in a little under 2 hours. My elbow/wrists/R knee hurt.

Third ski of the year. Anders and I seriously or not so seriously adopted our 50k every day training plan. I wasn't probably ready for this, but you get it done, you know. Took a short break at 23 to eat a sandwich and appreciate the sunshine.

body hated the 18th, 19th and 20th time up the main hill.

Nothing like 20 2.5k loops to keep a person entertained.

Not sure how far this actually was, I just put a number there. Easy hour with the Sonnesyn's  (minus Alayna) at Hyland. My elbows still are sore so I'll probably just run tomorrow. I need a few more miles to limp to into a sad 3,000 for the year - In retrospect it's been a good year and I've had some good training. It's just the second lowest mileage year since my freshman year of college. 

Marit's home! Happy to have survived another WYSF.

0 degrees, windchill -17. It stung my hands just walking to the treadmill.

5 miles easy, 1.0 incline. Because like Andy Rishavy always said, 'You don't get faster...'

Easy freezy with John and Finan. Endless banter about nothing at the very least helped the time go by quickly. Tomorrow Finan goes to California for 10 days, then to Boulder for a month. And all after the traveling he just got back from today. Rough life.

Morning on the wheel. Other than Blake Gust watching Fox news for the first 10 minutes (then he left) I had the whole place to myself. 2 easy, then I kept clicking the button until I was sub 6 pace (5:39-5:4x) for 5 miles. Felt reasonable enough.

It wasn't even cold out this morning. 15, W/C 0. I just didn't feel like it.

Morning strength/core. Upper and lower body.

Getting stronger.
90 minute ski at Elm with Adrian. Somewhere in the middle we did 3x1.5k fast. I'd give it an 'L' number, but I don't have L's. Maybe 4? 3.6?. Skiing is hard.

Morning easy run around the lakes. Mostly clear paths, which was nice. I stood at the door for a minute today and thought, 'Really, what would be the consequences of not doing this?' 

I shook that off and went on my way.
little over an hour ski at Hyland with Marit and her dad. Elbow was screaming on any climb. Otherwise, things were fine.
at Hyland with Marit and the gustavus team. Complete guess on distance. Ended up skiing a bit with small Anders, Jill, Adrian, Marit. Nothing flashy today, just more time on snow.

Just over an hour at Hyland with Marit, a guess on distance. My elbow felt a little better, but the majority of this ski was spent getting pelted in the eyes with ice pellets. Brunch before, donuts after... hard to complain about that :)

Had to run from work in the afternoon to get this done, since I didn't have time this morning. Harriet Island, Lilydale, and back on Shepard Rd. I briefly entertained the idea of the trails in lilydale, or crosby farm, but they were all ice. Shepard seemed a fitting way to celebrate Marotz's CIM victory anyhow. It was clear, except the mile and a half from Randolph to Washington, which was pure, uneven ice. No idea why that part didn't get plowed.

Overall it felt good, but the first 2+ miles my hips and hamstrings didn't know what was going on. 

Also, not that I'm even close to a suit and tie guy, but running from work is always awkward. Any fraction of professional reverence dissolves when your employees see you in spandex tights.

Skate at Hyland with Marit, Mata, Josh, and Scott. Guess on distance.

I really thought my elbow was doing better, but 5 minutes into the ski it was back. I did some threshold intervals with Marit and Mata, and it was kind of deflating because it hurts too much to actually use my arms to V2. I also was sloppy, but that's a different can of worms. 

Oh well.
Morning lap of Harriet. I feel pretty fit aerobically, but I tried to imagine that light-footed indoor track feeling you get running the 3k or something, and I'm a long way away from that....

Started out running relaxed, 7:10 for the first mile. Then I passed a guy who decided to run with me for a little while, and by the time I dropped him I thought, 'If I can just run 5:40's for the next 8 miles, I'll break an hour for 10', so I had a goal, which I needed because I didn't feel like being out there. I ended up doing 3 laps of Calhoun, and splitting 59:25 at 10 miles.

Then I went home. I feel aerobically pretty strong (not that this was even really sub threshold work), so in all this was a good night.

Ran from Marit's house after watching her and Mata win their ski race, and a quick nap. Felt stong, but my calves are sore. Pretty sloppy now that all the snow decided to melt. It's like March in December right now.
Skate ski with Marit at Hyland. Elbow is still a nuisance,..

Isles/Calhoun East with Finan in the rain. What he really needs to do is flip Mahoney the bird and go dancing off into the sunset with sketchers. They the real MVP.

You heard it here first: First sub-4 in the shape-ups.
Slow, heavy morning run around Cedar. 9 degrees. It was cool watching the sun come up over Cedar Lake heading east to Kenilworth.

Over across stone arch and back home. I'm in a strange place of fitness: I don't feel quick, but I can change gears, run fast, hold it, whatever (except uphills) and my breathing doesn't change. But hills are hard. I'm not sure what all that means.

Kinda just cruised along out there. I was planning to ski today, so I had eaten a peanut butter sandwich which didn't sit well at all during my run. Also worth noting, I had one line from 'Blank Space' in my head on repeat the whole time, which no one but Paul Keinberger would find enjoyable.
I'm not sure why I ran 8 minute miles this day... I have a bit of backlogging to do.
Just a Calhoun lap before stealing a Christmas tree from Wirth, making cider and lefse with Marit :)
I skied today, but I don't remember how long/far.
Out and back east on the greenway. I felt antsy.
2 and a half laps on some pretty challenging ice/snow at Elm with the Sonnesyn/MYSL family. Christmas morning skiing :)
2.5 hr Skate Ski on the Birkie trials north from OO with Marit, Alayna, and Bonk Master Anders for a bit. I love the whole body tired that skiing brings.

Skate intervals with Marit and Small Anders (+Alayna for the first one) south of OO. 2x10minutes, 4x2 minutes. I fell in the first 10 minute interval as there were several inches of ungroomed powder and I don't know how to ski. I felt pretty good during the 2 minute L4's, though. This workout brought to you by gummy worms and christmas cookies.

1 hr classic on the north end trails with Alayna and Marit. Marit kept dumping snow on me, so under the guise of a hug, I pulled her into a snowbank :) Really beautiful ski, actually. My elbow hurt by the end, but it's ok as I type this now. Second classic ski since high school.... US team, here I come. Followed this ski with pizza and beer and a fire and reading under a blanket. Perfect much? I feel lucky.

3 hour skate toward Telemark on the Birkie Classic trail while Marit and Alayna classic skied. The first half was a bit tight, but the way back felt really good, and we discussed the merits of homeschooling and factors that would exclude guys from Lana Del Sonnesyn, which apparently includes having a stutter and being shorter than 6'7'.
90 minute skate at Hyland with Marit. Elbow felt pretty good! Saw John Dewall out skiing - that guy hasn't changed.

Elm Creek skate race - 

maybe 2 laps for a warmup. Mass start with 90 people on those trails made it pretty tight, so my first 2.5k loop was just sking and feeling frustrated that I couldn't get free. Lots of falls, but I didn't see any poles break. I tried to take the inside heading to the donut, but then I got trapped behind a bunch of 40 year olds that think they are just outside of US ski team material. Marit and Mata went past me, and I caught back up over by northern lights, and I think that's when it finally quit being crowded. I hadn't been on fast skis yet this year, so I wasn't used to it- couple that with the icy snow, and the ridges on the course, and I was slipping all over the place. I wanted Marit to go back around me just so she couldn't see what I looked like...

Sloppy, but finished. Vakava beat Gustavus by 17 points, but they had 14 skiers and GAC had 5. One of whom was me (and I don't believe I scored). Felt good to compete again, I missed that. I was 46th, which is far from shiny, but it's a start. 

And Nate Porath is still a wiener.
1 hour easy at Hyland in the morning with Marit before driving to Hayward. She slept, Kiddie ate 7 Jimmy John's and I learned all about Ski*go C22 Fluoro Powder.
On the Tech trails with Marit and Jill. 1hr 15 maybe? I need to get better at keeping track of this stuff. Nice day out!
I don't recall how long this was exactly, but in Houghton, broken into two skis in the remaining warmth on the Tech trails/someplace called hirohati maatasaki or something...

Sort of a Hodge-podge at US Nationals in Houghton - skated with Marit on her warmup, then sprinted around watching her and Alayna, then somewhere between 8-10k as a cooldown with Steve, Jill, Marit, Alayna, and Anders. Slow snow, and a windchill of... -20? This would be a terrible place to live. BUT we then went to see Unbroken and get Bloody Marys :)
1 hr skate at Hyland with Marit after driving home from the UP. 0 degrees, but somehow warmer than Houghton. Lots of High Schoolers, and apparently the seat-heaters in the car get too warm.

I went to work at 7:15ish this morning, knowing I had class tonight - but I thought class went until 7. While at work I wanted to make sure I knew where my class was (MOH 403, who would have guessed...) and it turns out it goes until 9:30. So much for going to Elm afterward :/ Not really positive how working out will go on Tuesday/Thursday for the next 4 weeks, or why this class needs to be 5 hours long. Oh well... I can't do much about it.

The plan was to do a long thresholdy ski today, but then I woke up to -35 degree windchill, and it really didn't get a whole lot warmer throughout the day. John went out for a 30 minute run, but I didn't see the purpose of getting dressed up to run for 30 minutes, and I didn't want to go ski and freeze in this. That said, I felt like crap from being lazy yesterday and not being sure what tomorrow will be, and I think I'd be self-conscious in running shorts on the hamster wheel right now. Plus I'd have to content with the new year's resolution flocks at the gym. So I lifted/ did core/leg strength pretty much until failure. I still feel wimpy. 

But my arms are shaky, so I at least accomplished something.

10pm after a really flipping long day, and total dietary intake of ~11 gummy worms, and 2 cups of coffee.

Luckily Anders decided to be a masochist and run with me, so we ran from his place. Average snow depth on this run: 5 inches. wind speed: 20mph. Peen temp: 32.1 degrees F.

Slow going, and I was sore the next morning. Aerobically I'm strong, but these legs... are not mine.

At Highland with Marit and Mata, but they classic skied (try to spelled classiced? classicked? classic'd?) and I did a kind of workout. 1x20, 3x3, 3x1 minutes. My elbow got to be hurting a good bit by the end, which of course is annoying. Tillman, John and Kate were out too, and I skied with Tillman and John for a little while. It's good to catch up with Tilly - sounds like he's doing a buttload of racing this month.

At Wirth with Marit on some questionable snow for the first hour, manmade loop for the second. It was pretty cold out, and I felt a bit tired. Not the best day of skiing I've ever had, but the rest of the evening was enjoyable :) Marit made me dinner, and I made her cerebellum heavy. The physiology is questionable, but it was a fun night.

On and off solo - I started with Marit while she did a harder classic ski, then with Steve and Jill (Steve later told me I'm finally looking like less of a runner out there, which is equally good and bad.) Mostly though, this was on my own. I did 2 laps easy, 1 lap sort of progressively speeding up, 2ish laps at a good, sustained cadence, and then another easy. I felt a lot stronger on the hills than I have in the past, which is a good thing because gradual erosion has yet again failed to make the Birkie trails flat.

Single digit temps, but I warmed up after 15 minutes or so. I was able to sneak this in prior to going to class, so I'm feeling thankful. My legs were awfully cumbersome, and somewhat dishearteningly my R hamstring had the same pain that it did in the TC marathon last fall. But 2015 is going to be a year of appreciating the gift of running, and today I was happy to just be on my feet and circling those lakes for the 11 millionth time :)

a little over 2 hours at Hyland on my way home from work. I saw Marit, Mata, and Daria finishing their ski, so I skied with them for a few minutes before shuffling off on my own. There was a high school, individual start skate race race going on, and I had an idea to make a workout of it: catch 5, wait until one passes me back, catch another 5, wait for one, and so forth. After catching my first 5, the 'one' never seemed to come, so I just did 4x4mins, 4x2mins, 4x30seconds with 2 minutes after the 4s and 2s, 1 minute after the 30s. elbow hurt by the end, but it wasn't too awful. 5k cooldown and I was on my way home!

Just short and relaxed. The paths were fair at best, as the warm weather made them pretty sloppy. I did see one guy/girl duo get out of their car on the west side of Calhoun in full running attire, trot over to the path, the girl took a picture of the guy, then they got back in their car. I guess if it looks like you ran, you ran, right? Hamstring was apparent, but not painful. You know what though? 30 degrees and sunshine? I think I'll take it. Lifting and the like after.

A few days of good skiing ahead.

One loop of the race course at Telemark in the dark with Marit, Steve, and Anders 'I wear lenses in the dark because the sun never sets on cool' Sonnesyn. The course is scary in the daylight - I wasn't a huge fan of the downhills in the dark. Never fell, but was close a handful of times. Notable moment of this ski - while we were getting dressed, Anders walked over to the woods to pee. ...And Steve followed him with his 9 trillion megawatt beacon headlamp. Ha.

A hodge podge of warmups and codlins and sprinting around during two races... though I guess I was on foot for one. Then I skied from Telemark Lodge to OO with Steve - 23km? something like that? We did some of the Korte trail too so no idea how long it took/how far we went. It rained on us, and then that turned to snow, which really took a toll on my eyeballs. I was happy to get to OO and be picked up.
Pieced together ski of intervals to watch a race, a warmup, more sprinting, a cooldown, another race, and then 40 minutes or so continuous before leaving Telemark. Awesome races today.

A good ski at Hyland on some pretty awful snow. It was just this slow, heavy, packed slush. I shuffled my entire iPod, and gosh... that resulted in a pretty interesting mix of songs. But it was good. The ski felt really controlled, I felt smooth and like I had fairly good balance. Somewhere around the middle I crashed head-on into a 10-12 year old boy. By Jan's place, he was skiing towards me on the wrong side of the trail (lots of people going the wrong way tonight). I went right to avoid him, but he went the same way. I cut back left, but so did he. Then we must have both thought to ditch to the tracks, and we collided. Fortunately for me, 150lbs vs 80lbs means I won that battle. No one was hurt though.

I started off really relaxed and got a little faster each lap until my last one where I just sort of dawdled. My 9th 5k was 14:00, which I'm happy with because at no point did I feel like I was skiing hard. By that time, the snow had become a bit icy, which I'm sure sped things up.

Marit made me dinner when I got home, and even though we argued over the story of Thanksgiving, this night was perfect.

Just a quick lap around the lake before going to work. I wasn't planning to run this morning, but after thinking about my schedule, it was either this or take the day off. Hamstring wasn't amazing, but at this pace it didn't hurt; I definitely need to increase its range of motion though. A good run :)
30 minutes solo, then 90 minutes with Anders, Kory, and Dan DeRoma after work at Elm Creek. I said it then, and I'll say it now: Rossignol Deltas are rockets.
Highland with Anders. He tried to make me V2 a whole lap - the outcome of that was me realizing how weak I am. Meanwhile, he V2'ed up the back hill like it was nothing.
Sking around Wirth before/after the JNQ classic race. Super exciting race!

10k skate race at Wirth. Rocket fast snow, so much so that there were a few iffy corners. I didn't fall, but I was close more than once. I ended up 17th in 25:03. I got out fairly slow, and it felt really conservative. I don't mind that approach, in fact I probably prefer it, but I don't like being stuck behind people. So it took 2k or so to shake free of the congestion, but then things went pretty well. I ended up skiing in a pack with Hans, Corey Brinkema, Spencer Davis and Drew Holbrook. We traded spots a few times, but on the last time up the long climb by the tubing hill I went past all of them, and got about a 15m lead - I don't think I was ever passed on a gradual climb today. Then on the downhill above the par 3 lot, they stuck it to me. Old man Brinkema climbed to fast - his feet looked positively frantic, and he beat me by 11 seconds. Oh well. It was a good learning experience, and it felt awesome to make myself hurt a bit again. I don't think that competitive fire will ever go away. Technique definitely held me back in the later stages, I couldn't V2 at all once my legs went to rubber. I still tried, but I cringe thinking about how it must have looked. Really happy about racing today, in retrospect.

Jed, Mar, and Small Anders were out cheering for me, which was cool :) 
I apparently beat some reasonably fast guys, and i'm really getting excited for the Birkie now. I still need a bit of training, but that'll come.

Story of the day: A middle aged guy in a yellow jacket started next to me in the mass start, and said 'good luck' to me. I said thanks, and wished him luck too. He said something about luck not mattering because he's already over 1000km for the year in training, which isn't actually that much. And he had a drink belt on (remember this is 10k), which he drank from around 8k.

And he beat me.

You live you learn, I guess.

Then Marit collected another top 5 in the CCSA wave. Awesome.
really mushy, slow going snow at Hyland today. 40's is just too warm to ski, anyway. I'd hoped to go a lot farther, but these 20k were a lot of work.

Ran from work over lunch, instead of having lunch. Oh well. This was on the heels of a yucky 25 minute phone conversation - or... I don't know. A conversation usually implies two people are having a dialogue. I was being spoken to.

South St. Paul is a really ugly place. But the fresh air made the day better.

With John. Gosh it's been a while. Running with company is so much better most of the time. Felt nice to just clip along in the dark and talk about whatever we talk about. Looking forward to spring/summer training and that effortless feeling that pops up once in a while.

Felt like a really long day today, but it was a good one. Life changes are on the horizon :)
2ish hours at Hyland with Marit, Anders and Steve.

Easy* ski on the Birkie trail from OO to Lake Hayward and back. With Jill, Anders and Marit for the first 1:15 or so, then Marit the rest of the way.

By the time we got to Rosie's field on the way back I was pretty cashed, and we still had a long way to go. Made it, though. It was a good lesson that pancakes, coffee and happy thoughts may not be the best idea in a few Saturdays. The afternoon was perfect though - chips, salsa, pizza, and a nap on the couch in front of the fire.

From OO to North End on the classic trail, back on the skate trail. Not sure how far this was, but my legs were tired today. Not much the way of elbow pain, but my left wrist hurt by the end. A good weekend of ski training, happy about that.

Morning jaunt before work. Pretty cold out, but overall I guess things felt good? My stride feels normal, and aerobically I'm just fine. I can't really point to what feels different, but something of course does. I think I need to run more frequently now that that's coming up. Even if it is just short jogs like this. Good to be out there.

5 laps at Hyland. I did 2x15 seconds of all-out V2 each lap, and sprinted 2 hills each lap as well. New snow, so it was slow, but I felt like a rocket. Maybe because I was skiing alone and had no one to compare myself to, but it felt good. I felt strong.

Nothing for the record books here. I think it's a good idea to start building in short runs to get my running legs back under me. Less than 3 weeks! My hamstring is still not right, and I froze my toes out there today. It was probably 10 degrees, but the wind was wicked coming off the lake.

Building blocks and baby steps.
Hyland skate workout while Marit did a classic workout. I did 5k hardish, then 8x30seconds L5. Felt a bit sloppy, but overall ok. Beautiful day! :)
Morning shakeout. felt really good.

Pre Birkie skate ski marathon in Hayward. I Had no expectations, really, for this race - less a few quiet thoughts that I kept to myself based on past year's results. Got to the race 10 minutes to the start, which turned out to be more than enough time, actually. Looking at the competition, I felt like starting in the second row was reasonable. Turns out I was right next to Nicolette Reker, who won it for the women last year. We started, and what a cluster. Sure I'm not great at double polling, but it was like everyone in the field thought they could win it. Within a kilometer, I bet I was in 300th place (including the 26k skiers who started with us). That was fine, until we got off the lake, and the trail narrowed down, and I had to get around people who clearly were not going to hold their initial pace. It wasn't until just after 8k that I felt like I could start skiing my own race. The majority of the race was: Sit with a pack for 500m before feeling antsy, spend the next 4ish km trying to catch up to the next group, repeat. The majority of the time, I was skiing alone, and couldn't see anyone ahead of me. From 14k-22k, I was completely alone, and I must have eased up, because around 22 I looked back to see this huge conga line sashaying their way toward me. I caught one solo guy and told him the peloton was coming, and he said 'Good, we'll have people to ski with soon then'. So I hit the gas, left him, took my only gel, and got across OO, putting space between myself and the parade behind me. I spotted a group with some Johnnies, 2 LNR guys, and a few others that were moving pretty quickly, and I thought they'd be a good group to race with. right around then, my gel kicked in and I felt fresh and like I had boundless energy. I think I spent the first 25k waiting to actually race, so when it finally got to be within 15k of the finish I was getting excited. I caught the group, and started moving up a few spots on each climb. I finally decided to set off on my own again, caught one more guy, and when I saw 32k on my watch, I started to hammer. I felt so fast. My technique probably was poor, but my cadence was remarkable. There weren't many people left to catch, so I started to make a game of catching the classic skiers. With maybe 4k to go (I'd spent 3k trying to reel in Drew Holbrook, and closed the gap to maybe 25-20m) and I just randomly fell on an uphill. No reason, I just fell. I lost probably 10 seconds in the snow, a few more getting up to speed, but what I really lost was my contact with Drew, and I no longer had time to catch him. I caught 2 more guys in the last Km, but im the final 20m, one of the guys came roaring back past me, and V2ing as hard as I could, I couldn't sneak back past him. He was the only person who passed me for the entire race.

I finished 29th overall, 4th in my age group.

I'm happy with this race, and it was really fun. I love the excitement of getting to the late stages of a race, and knowing that I've got more left, that I'm stronger than the people around me. I felt like I got stronger as the race went on, and the feeling of pushing yourself as hard as you can is awesome. 2 weeks until the race is bigger, more competitive, I start farther back, and it's 9km longer, but I'm up for it.

I learned a lot today. I need to figure out how to get out a little quicker, simply for the sake of space. I also learned that the hardest part is biding my time before I can start hammering. The first 25k felt like a really awful formality I had to get through in order to race.

Onward and upward. Skiing is alright, I guess :)

Easy ski with Steve, Anders and Jill. I skied with Anders from OO to Boedecker, then he started his workout. Against my better judgement, I decided to ski from there to Hayward with Steve, but had to sprint north another almost 2k to catch Jill/Anders and let them know to not wait for me. Then back to OO, and off to Hayward with Steve. Talked a lot about everything under the sun, so it went pretty quickly. My body was tired, but I still felt alright. Coming across the lake for the last k was less than enjoyable, but I'm going to need to be used to that. Longer than I was expecting, but I can't let Steve get in extra training without me.
Out and back jog on the greenway with John. Felt good, feels like I'm not THAT far out of running shape. really nice weather, too.

Easy ski after a meeting at Hyland. About half of this was just double polling, because Adrian said so. My arms don't feel super strong, and they'll need to be in a week and a half. Today after the ski I did a within-groups linear regression analysis of the last 5 years of the Birkie results, as they related to finishes in the Pre-Birkie. The regression itself predicted I'd finish 212th for men (the top 200 make the next year's elite wave). Adding in a control to the equation (y=4.9117x+69.926 if any men wanted to predict their finish) for competitive variance between fields, it suggests a finish of 208th (turns out this year's pre birkie was quite a bit more competitive than 'average'). The plus side: The margin of error to remain within a high (85%) confidence interval is high, and allows plausibility of a <200 finish.='' the='' down='' side:='' wave='' 2.='' i'm='' going='' to='' have='' to='' not='' get='' trapped='' at='' the=''></200>

*I will say that in figuring out the control for competitive variance, there was an outlier in the data points, ~50% higher than the others. If that single point is omitted, and the control (a percentage of time back from the winning time) is figured without it, it suggests a 193rd place finish. But that's falsifying data ;)

Not sure how long this was. I met Adrian at Wirth for a ski workout, but that quickly fell apart. I don't understand ski training, and the shot in the dark was 10x3 minutes at 10k pace with equal recovery. Well, Wirth blows right now - packed ice for the entire course, 30 mph winds, and they did an impressively poor job lighting the course. After 7 attempts at 3 minute segments, I just went home. I don't have the balance to ski on ice like that. I didn't get a workout effort today by any means. I'll have to try again...

You lost some points today, City of Minneapolis.

Guessing on the distance. Another longer day of work, but I went straight to Hyland after and tried round 2 of the workout that I pulled the plug on yesterday. 30 up, 10x3 minutes at 10k race effort with equal recovery. I wouldn't say I hit this one out of the park, but I did it, and I'm satisfied with how it went. Fairly chilly out there, but not terrible. I saw the Gustie guys out skiing so I skied with them for my warmup. From there it was solo; I should have brought my iPod. 

Gotta love the standard company of a cup of coffee and a bunch of happy thoughts :)

Running around Wirth watching Marit's 15k classic race in my snow boots. Not exactly a workout, but there was some strength component, those things are heavy. 5th place!! and beat the whole UAF team. Crazy. Like small anders said, 'So... you lost to foreigners and NMU'

Pretty darn swell.
More Wirth sprinting. 4th today :)
Easy skate at Hyland with Marit, Steve, and Kiddie. My quads are sore, and I felt a bit lethargic, but those days come and go.

Hyland solo.

Thoughts about life :) Kind of a stressful day, actually. But I think it all worked out?

Out and back with Jack. Cold as nuts but it was really a fun run catching up with him, even if the majority of it comprised my personal topics of late. I have to admire his ever positive outlook on everything. Looking forward to warm weather runs and meeting up at 36th and Girard for a lake or two.

Super cold, windchill of something like -18. The snow was dry, hard and squeaky slow. 20 minute warmup, 2x3 minutes of 'threshold' - my heart rate was up but I'm not convinced I was moving any faster, then 10x15 second sprints. Again, not moving very fast. The wind and hard-packed conditions made it challenging to get moving very efficiently. But it's in the bank now, we'll see what the weekend brings!

Early run around the lake - single digits and the wind was really rough coming off the lake. We got an inch of new snow over night, so I was slipping all over the place which irritated my hamstring a bit. But whatever, it's game time tomorrow. I don't know what to expect - I could be 150th or I could be 700th. What I do know is that I'm ready to go to that place that I haven't been to since... Kraft last spring? First or last, I'll give it everything I have tomorrow :)

I just hope I can get through 42k still feeling alive. The fire is hot. 51k on the sticks, here we go!

At Rock Lake, classic skiing on the single-tracked trails. I started out following Anders, Wes, and Millan, but quickly gave up the ghost and nordic walked with Marit. I don't know how to classic ski, so giving up the idea of skiing, and instead just coasting along, enjoying the woods, and talking with Marit was more than welcomed. It was below zero, but the sun was shining and it was peaceful. It's been a great ski season.
Calhoun, Isles, Greenway with JL. Good conversations the whole way. My hips felt tired, and of course my legs aren't race-ready, but I was happy to be out running.

With Marit in the windy city. It was probably the 5th time I've run wagon wheel in my life, and that's being generous.
