Felt really good to have company, and to just run really relaxed for a while, even though the wind was ridiculous. Marit seems to be getting sick, and my hamstring still doesn't want to cooperate, but the sun was out, I could put one foot in front of the other, and it was followed by pizza and a movie. Good day.
Morning, -16 wc and I really overdressed. I feel super strong but my legs are going to be a little while before they find their spring. Got it in, no pain, good run!

Easy run with John and Jack. I guess Jack sprinted a while to catch us, but it was fun having a group, however small. A bit windy, but it was pretty nice out. Looking forward to there being less ice on the paths, but it was a good run, and another good day.
With John around Cedar, up to the bike path, and home via the sculpture garden. Legs feel heavy, but they'll come around.

Just drove up into the Tualatin Mountains - more like enormous, densely forested hills because they are from the Cenozoic period and have eroded so much over time - and stopped at the first trailhead I found. Ended up doing an out and back on the Wildwood trail, which was awesome. The footing was good, and the trail didn't require much fancy footwork. I kept feeling like I was in Jurassic Park, though. Lots of ferns, enormous, sweater-wearing trees... AND it was hot out! 57ish degrees. I could have run shirtless but I feel like some blimpy sea mammal that had an unfortunate experience with some Clorox, so I kept the shirt on. Shorts, though, and I got hot! Crazy. Finished this with a pizza and bloody mary at the Thirsty Lion, then walked back to my hotel. Found out I had a huge blister on my foot afterwards, but I'll live.

After a really good interview at Pacific U, I ran from my hotel. Wove a few streets until I hit Evergreen Parkway, and rode that across Rock Creek and then back to Hillsboro. Shorter run, my hips/hamstrings were sore. Another beautiful, sunny, mid 50's day! After this, I showered and lounged a bit, before going into the city to maybe one of the coolest, most Portlandy restaurants I could imagine with a few of the other doctoral candidates (brought to my attention by a resident with purple hair, so I knew it would be legit). Under all the suits and formalities, they all just really loved their beer and at least two of them were smoking weed (outside).  I had two beers over the course of four hours, with a meal, and my head still hurt the next morning. I know I haven't been good about drinking water out here, and have had way too much caffeine so I'm sure that doesn't help. Maybe I was just dehydrated? Anyhow, a good day :)

Coolest route of my life. This run was really good for my soul. Back in the Tualatins, I met up with Dustin Franta and Gina Luke at the Leif Erickson trailhead, and did a breathtaking loop with Dustin. Such a cool run. It was first on a trail, then the second half was this old logging road - it was sunny and 46 (which is my favorite running temp - shorts and a long sleeve) - but in the forest the trees were so dense that it wasn't that bright. The ground was dry, but everything felt damp, and quiet and like the woods just enveloped us. Had a good chat with Dustin about Oregon life, coaching, how crazy AlSal is, life, love, and happiness. He said he misses things about minnesota, but how he quickly forgets them on runs like this one. It's easy to get lost, figuratively, out there. It was really good to banter with him again, and talk about how only a handful of our generation from the MIAC are still chasing the dream. Such a nice guy. I wish he was closer.

After the run, He, Gina, and myself hung out in the parking lot and talked a bit more - the healthcare system in Portland, and how inadequate in number mental health clinics are.

Then I drove downtown, parked, walked to VooDoo Donuts, ate two massive ones, talked to some dude named Cole (likely was drunk) for 20 minutes about the Taxi industry, and headed off to the airport!

Until we meet again, Portland :)

With Finan (greeting by his sexual maneuvers on the porch, once again) for the first 5, then solo for 3. Talked about his time blood doping out west, and the overuse of his selfie-stick, among other things. When we got to his house to drop him off, I had to pee, so I went inside.  I walked through the door and yelled, 'SCULLY!!!' but no answer. Finan said he must be in the basement. So I walked over to the bathroom, and the door was closed and the light was on inside. So I hesitated, and said, 'John, are you in there?' No answer. so I knocked. no answer. So I opened the door, and what do you know? Scully is sitting on the toilet with his pants down and headphones in. After staring at each other for several seconds I walked away, and he come out and said, 'Honestly, I was done like 15 minutes ago.' ...So he must have had a good playlist. I went back outside, and my legs felt really good. I actually did 4 really light pickups down the greenway, just to test things out. Not perfect, but promising :)

Good day.

a touch over 4 miles with Marit, then out and back on the greenway to round this one out. Points of note from this day - Tasty dinner at the Lowry, and then Marit had her first (only?) Wondrous punch. And she didn't get sick. John, on the other hand, did.

And I coasted along unharmed :)

5 miles with Marit and Finan around Isles in that beautiful springtime sunshine. Felt good, but I felt really anxious after dropping Marit off and running up to pick my car up with Finan. A lovely afternoon of napping, guacamole, a walk around uptown, dinner and a movie night with all the roommates, and all the girlfriends :)

The day just got progressively better until I fell asleep.

AND I did not see John Scully naked today,

Slushy, slow ski with Marit at Hyland - crazy to think that 2 weeks ago I was in the best ski shape of my life, and today was a struggle. Kept it easy, skied in a t-shirt, and afterward we went down to 50th & France, walked around the shops, and Marit bought me ice cream :)

A good, relaxing end to a really great weekend.

Long day at work, and I was too exhausted to go right out the door when I got home, so this didn't start until probably 6. At least daylight savings dictated that it would be sunny throughout the run still. I felt pretty decent - legs still heavy - but I was able to finish up with 4 strides at... oh 80% and feel fine.

I'm ready to get serious again :) Trials and miles and such.

'Workout' with Anders. Warmed up a bit under 3 miles, and then did 6x 80:60 at 'threshold' - but I don't really know what that is right now. Based on the distances we covered in the 80's, we were running between 71-79 per 400. 

Nothing to be proud of here, but we dipped our toes back in, anyway. Hopefully the road back isn't too long. 63 and sunny though? Hard to be unhappy about that.

I don't know why I suck at 'nutrition' as Finan calls it, but I really do. I think I just forget, because I'm not hungry in the morning, and then when I start feeling hungry it's already too close to when I want to run. Anyway, I didn't run today until after 6, 6:30 maybe, and to that point I'd eaten part of a scone, part of a cinnamon roll, a donut, and 6 or 7 peanut m&m's. I was hungry and felt gross at the start of this, but it was nice out, so I let myself run however fast or slow I felt like.

After a mile I warmed up for about 3 more, but the last 3 miles were in the top 5 hardest/most sore run's I've ever finished - up with the morning run after my 2011 25 mile double workout, the last 4 miles of the TC marathon 2012, and the all-time most difficult run of my life August 22nd, 2010. It was a three mile run that lasted an eternity, the morning of early camp so I could hit 1,200 miles for the summer.

I just looked back at my log, and that senior summer, in 13 weeks I ran 1200.xx miles at an average pace of 6:52/mile. I spent a total of 137 hours, 25 minutes, and 29 seconds running during those 13 weeks, and didn't have many weeks below 100. 3 weeks over 110, 1 over 120.

I need to get back to training. I want to be that Nick again (just a lot faster). Reading my log, maybe it's nostalgia, but I miss training in Hastings. And the routine I had back then.

West Greenway into St. Louis park with JL, back on CLBT. My right IT band hurt. Like really, really hurt. I had to stop and stretch a few times, and eventually my right foot went completely numb, minus some tingling.

After reading my old log entries, I really want to have that type of training again. I know it's a process, but the pain on today's run left me feeling pretty down.
day off for the IT

Great weekend. Last night Marit and I went to Acme for a comedy show which was actually a ton of fun :) After sleeping in a bit, we had coffee and got rolling on this. Beautiful weather, and a lot less crowded than I expected. We took Isles to CLBT, cut through the sculpture garden, did a lap around Loring park, and back via Bryant. My IT band was ok at first, rough around the lake and bike trail, and then felt good on Bryant. Sunny. mid 50's maybe... loved being out running. Especially a brief moment around 24th and Bryant that I can't shake. Oh springtime :) After getting home we raked (mostly Marit) the way-too-many leaves in our yard, planted grass seed, prepped (both!!) gardens, and then went out for Ethiopian food with the Gustie girls and their respective male counterparts. That was followed by Sebastian Joes, followed by Scandal... Ugh. Weekends are just too short. Finan, I'll make an appointment with your guy Monday. 99% promise.

Things I learned this weekend: I like baking, I dislike cake, and I love a very specific variety of banana.

Well... This wasn't happening. Made it almost to 36th, but my IT started hurting almost right away. It spasmed and pulled in tandem with my sciatic. I'm starting to get worried about whether I can be ready in time to do the things I want to in track/on the roads. I don't want to lose the aerobic fitness I have, because that's kind of all I have right now :/

Went to Sportworks today to see Finan's pal, and he seemed like he's a good fit. He really got into some of my stuff, and it was almost comical at times. Once, he said, 'Let me know if it hurts too much', and I laughed. He said, 'You laugh... you think it can't be too unbearable?' I told him to do his worst (I couldn't imagine he could do more than I do to myself). Something about endurance sports conditions us to learn to deal with, if not seek out extreme pain. Anyway, promptly after that he jammed into my hip pretty hard and I kept a straight face. He asked my pain on a scale of 1-10, and I asked if anyone ever says 10. He said non-runners say it every single time. I wouldn't give him more than a 6 ;)

I should have just run 5. It felt reasonable for the first 30 or 35 minutes, but then it became pretty awful. limping and such. I was with John, but he let me stop to stretch a little, which allowed me to limp 2 miles home. This can go away any time now!

BUT I got in 8 miles, and that's a day of training that no one can take away.

Harriet west around the rose garden. I've had better, I've had worse. My knee hurt a reasonable amount by the end. But mid 40s are my favorite weather to run in, So... it felt really good to be out there :)

Painful. Really painful. Tried a lap of Calhoun, walked the last part home. I'll fight a little longer, but I'm ready to hang it up for a while.

Nice weather today.
Tried, it hurt. First half mile was pain free, but then it just crept in the rest of the way. Don't really know what to do but I'm going bonkers sitting around all day.
Gave it a try. Didn't work out. My soul needed it more than my legs today. Tomorrow is a new day, though.
2 miles. Had to stop twice. Shuffled home.
Id be lying if I said this run was completely pain-free, but the first mile felt good, and I was able to get home without needing to stop. The right direction, I hope.
hurt.
Better than it's been.
easy morning shuffle in Florida with Mar. Not perfect, but manageable.

Not sure the time on this - Ran Marit's workout with her on the Cross Seminole trail. really warm, but I liked it. It felt good to get moving and sweat a little bit. We did 1x2mile, 3x1 mile, and then another 400m or so pickup. 6ish minute pace for the reps. Glad I could be running with Marit over break, if nothing else.
Just an easy jog around winter springs with Mar. Surprisingly, my knee felt pretty good.

Really cool run in Gainesville with Marit while visiting Val. We ran the La Chua trail and got really close to some alligators, saw a wild horse really far off, and a boar with its two little boarlets. boarlings? I don't know. Spent the day sitting by the pool and seeing Gainesville.
morning 4 with Val and Marit. I'm not sure who planned this run, but we had to jump over like 25 fences.

Woke up too early (thankful for coffee) for this run, and then did a lap of winter springs with Marit. My knee wasn't perfect, but it was decent, and didn't get worse, really, until the very very end. A beautiful day, followed by hanging out at the beach with the Myers. A pretty darn reasonable week of training.
with Anders. Painful.

I'm so tired. Of this, of fighting, of hurting. I haven't had an actual week of running training in 6 months. MONTHS. I feel like I'm just done. Even if I magically am healed tomorrow, what's the point? Track season is over in 4 or 5 weeks, and grandma's is two months away. Plenty of time if I was healthy, but I'm not, and in all reality I'm not fit.

I don't understand how I can run almost 40 miles last week, with a day off, and come back to MN and not be able to run 2 blocks without it hurting. I realize I'm pouty and pissy and I should just deal with it but I'm so frustrated. SIX MONTHS. There's no reason anything should be hurting. I was at work today for 10 hours and I still couldn't do the things I needed to or please people, my boss keep pressing unrealistic deadlines that I can't meet because my portion is contingent on other people getting stuff done and they keep pushing it off, and all I wanted to do today was come home a run a few goddamn miles to clear my head. I got to the rose garden and literally just yelled. I couldn't run anymore. So I walked home. I want to scream, I kind of want to cry, I want... something to blame, but there is nothing. Sometimes crap like this just happens, I guess, and I feel hopeless. I don't think Lezon can help me, and I don't know who or what else could. I'm tired. I'm just tired of failing. I don't know when I'll run again.

Not a single percent better than last week. Not one.

I feel so out of shape.

75 minute skate ski with Dr. S. Had some good conversations about everything from cross training to retirement to why the US sucked at running from '77 to 2000.

Didn't fall.

Skate ski at Elm.

I was tired when I went to do this, kinda pissy when I started, but while I was out there I felt thankful to just be on my feet and breathing a little harder. Just myself and my thoughts today. 10 minute run after, barefoot, no noticeable pain. Strength and rolling in the parking lot after, I was the last car there. Beautiful night.

Really missing running right now. I don't want to be the guy who talks about when he 'used to.blah blah blah' just yet.
Ran barefoot around the cemetery - no pain until the very end.

Morning ski. Kennilworth to CLBT over to St. Louis Park somewhere. Planned another 20 minute run today, but work ran right up to class, and class is going until 10 or 10:30 or something. Not looking good. Also, today I saw Folske and while he tells me about his patients every time, we reached a new level of hipaa violation today: halfway through my treatment, Kelly Mortenson just walked into the room I was in with Folske because he 'thought he heard my voice', and we just started talking about why we both were there. Obviously I don't care, just thought it was.... Interesting.

At this rate, I'm thinking I should join the Wayzata Ski Club this summer and just try to win the Birkie next year.

Absolutely gorgeous out this morning, wish I was running, but really happy to be at it one way or another.
Felt super good today, which was encouraging.

Marit came up for the weekend so we ran together. I was hoping to do the first 4 miles of her run with her, but... My leg wasn't having it. Still struggling with a lot of questions about this, and I really feel like I'm defeated by something outside of my control. It's going to be a bit of a road back if/when I ever can run again.
If Ricky can do it...

I've been basically running 4-5 miles/day for the last week or so. I decided I wouldn't log again until it felt sustainable, and I think [hope] it is. I'll backlog the rest later. My knee got sore, but not too terrible. Isles to 36th and home.
Noticeable and irritating, but only occasionally painful. Best run in a while. Even did a stride at the end!
portions with John and Kurt. Felt more consistent, less pain early on!
Morning run, but my knee was hurting so I cut it short.

A bit sore for the first mile, but then the pain totally went away so at 2.5 I did a mile uptempo, cautiously accelerating throughout. The first quarter was maybe HM effort, then 5k, then letting loose a bit (not kicking). Split 4:54 in trainers, so I can't not be happy with that. Even though I felt sloppy as heck and it was aerobically challenging.

Bass lake loop plus a little. Started out ok, a little sore from .5 miles to the 1 mile, then it cleared up (still didn't feel normal, but there was no pain) and my form felt good, so I just went with it.

6:44, 6:10, 6:07, 6:08, 5:55. 5:45, 5:42, then a half mile at 7:22 pace back to the house after bumping into John.

This was promising, informative, and a harsh bit of truth. Being honest with myself, I'd guess (based on today) that my current HM pace is right around 5:45. So I have a long ways to go to be in shape again. That said, I'll finish off this week with some modicum of caution, and then I have 4.5 weeks to fitness and a 3 day taper. Let's see what happens, I guess :)
a bit more pain than it has been showing, but still ok. Ran with Anders and John - they're racing tomorrow and I'm.... not.
backlogging a bit... I don't remember anything about this run.
This didn't feel good. Went home early.

ABR!! This was spread out over many hours, of course, and a tad shorter this year as City Grill was closed. Felt reasonable at first, and if it hurt after that, I didn't notice. Overall a great weekend down at Gustieland.
Good for a mile, then excruciatingly painful. I had to stop twice.

I wasn't going to run today - I could feel my knee when I was just sitting around my house. But I decided I'd try it one more time, and if it hurt I'd come home, call Bud, and get an order for an MRI. ended up running essentially painlessly the whole way. Even did 2 of John's mile repeats with him in 5:01, 5:00 out on the Kenilworth Corridor. They didn't feel 'hard' per say, the first one was actually quite enjoyable, but my lungs feel really small. That became challenging during the second half of the second interval. Legs are alright, though. Cooled down home. Really confused by this run, but I'm not in a position to complain.
